headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to UDR's Fourth Quarter Financial Results Conference Call. Over fourth quarter press release, supplemental disclosure package [indiscernible] and 2-year strategic outlook document were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investors Re
componenttext:
Welcome to UDR's Fourth Quarter Financial Results Conference Call. Over fourth quarter press release, supplemental disclosure package [indiscernible] and 2-year strategic outlook document were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investors Relations section of our website, www.udr.com. In the supplement we have reconciled all non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements. Prior to reading our Safe Harbor disclosure, I would like to direct you to the webcast of this call located in the investor section of our website, www.udr.com. The webcast includes a slide presentation that will accompany our 2-year strategic outlook commentary. 
On the Safe Harbor. Statements made during this call which are not historical may constitute forward-looking statements. Although we believe the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions [indiscernible] will be met. A discussion of risk and risk factors are detailed in our press release and included in our filings with the SEC. We do not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to our President and CEO, Tom Toomey.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's fourth quarter and 2016/'17, strategic plan update conference call. On the call with me today are Tom Herzog, Chief Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will
componenttext:
Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's fourth quarter and 2016/'17, strategic plan update conference call. On the call with me today are Tom Herzog, Chief Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss our results, as well as senior officers Warren Troupe and Harry Alcock, who will be available during the Q&A. During this call, we will present our updated 2-year strategic outlook as we have done in the last 3 years. In 2015, we again met or exceeded all primary objectives of our strategic plan and they have meaningfully outperformed each of our prior plan. Tom will adjust this outperformance and the next 2 years strategic outlook in detail later in the call.
Turning to 2015, was another great year for UDR and we continue to see strength in all aspects of our business. A quick recap of the team's accomplishments during the year. 
First, our operations continue to run on all cylinders and delivered strong state same-store results across-the-board with same-store NOI growth of 6.7%, a full 220 basis points ahead of our initial expectations. 
Second, we delivered over $300 million of developments which leased up well and we expect to hit our targeted returns of 6.2% or better at stabilization. 
Third, we entered into 2 accretive problem-solving transactions, mainly the $559 million West Coast development joint venture and the $901 million Washington, D.C. acquisition, in which we kept our principles of self-funding, accretive to cash flow growth and continued strengthening of our balance sheet. 
Last, we grew AFFO per share by 12%, a strong rate, which resulted in a 7% dividend increase and meaningful consensus NAV per share growth of 15%. We continue to believe that growth in these 2 metrics translates into strong total shareholder return overtime.
Looking towards the future, we feel very positive about our business and our prospects. Multifamily fundamentals remained extraordinarily strong. The positive demographic trends amongst our private renters, the 22 to 35-year-old population cohort, is expected to grow through 2030 and is not reversible. This, coupled with a steady job growth, leaves us confident that our operating platform which is our primary driver very cash flow growth, should continue to generate impressive results in the future.
Our self-funded development pipeline is expected to generate the incremental cash flow and value creation we originally forecasted. Expected additions to the pipeline in 2016 will maintain our targeted size at $900 million tough $1.4 billion and are forecasted to be highly accretive. Our ability to fund this pipeline with asset sales largely reduces our dependency on capital markets. And as we've said in prior years, we will continue to focus on improving our debt metrics.
In summary, there remains a long runway for growth that UDR and we have the right plan and team in place to capitalize on the opportunity. 
With that, I'd like to express my sincere thanks to all my fellow UDR associates for their hard work and producing another strong year of results. We look forward to a great 2016, and now I will turn the call over to Tom.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Our fourth quarter earnings results were in line with our previously provided guidance. FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share was $0.41, $0.42 and $0.37, respectively. Fourth quarter same-store revenue, expense and NOI growth remained stron
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Our fourth quarter earnings results were in line with our previously provided guidance. FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share was $0.41, $0.42 and $0.37, respectively. Fourth quarter same-store revenue, expense and NOI growth remained strong at 6.2%, 5.2% and 6.6%, respectively. 
For full year 2015 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share were $1.66, $1.67 and $1.51, respectively. Full year same-store revenue, expense and NOI growth of 5.6%, 3.0% and 6.7% exhibited continued strong demand for apartments and were above our initial expectations provided last February. 
At year-end, our liquidity as measured by cash and credit facility capacity, was $987 million. The financial leverage on an underappreciated counts basis was 34.6%. Based on our current market cap, it was approximately 26% and inclusive of JVs, was approximately 30%. Our net debt to EBITDA was 5.7x and inclusive of JVs was 6.7x. All balance sheet metric improvements were ahead of plan.
On to first quarter and full year 2016 guidance. Full year 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share is forecasted at $1.75 to $1.81, $1.75 to $1.81 and $1.59 to $1.65, respectively. For same-store, our full year 2016 revenue growth guidance is 5.5% to 6.0%; expense, 3.0% to 3.5%; and NOI, 6.5% to 7.0%. Average 2016 occupancy is forecasted at 96.6%. Other primary full year guidance assumptions can be found on Attachment 15 or Page 28 of our supplement.
First quarter 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance is $0.42 to $0.44, $0.42 to $0.44 and $0.40 to $0.42, respectively. 
Finally, with our release today, we have increased our 2016 annualized dividend to $1.18 per share, a 6% increase from 2015 and represented a yield of approximately 3.25%. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jerry

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. In my remarks I'll cover the following topics: First, our fourth quarter portfolio metrics, leasing trends and the continued success we realized runaway growth again this quarter and into January; second, the per
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. In my remarks I'll cover the following topics: First, our fourth quarter portfolio metrics, leasing trends and the continued success we realized runaway growth again this quarter and into January; second, the performance of our primary markets during the quarter and expectations for 2016; and last, a brief update on our lease-up developments and the Washington, D.C. acquisition.
We're pleased to announce another strong quarter of operating results. Our fourth quarter same-store revenue growth of 6.2% was driven by an increase in revenue per occupied home of 6.5% year-over-year to $1,794 per month, while same-store occupancy of 96.5% was 30 basis points lower versus the prior year period. Our fourth quarter strategy of holding rate high, along with aggressive rate increases throughout 2015, benefits us in 2016 as we enter the year with almost 2.75% of our revenue growth already baked into our run roll. [ph] Our robust full year same-store revenue growth of 5.6% was driven by a 5.5% increase in revenue per occupied home and flat occupancy. We see strong rate growth continuing in 2016.
Turning to new and renewal lease rate growth, which is detailed on Attachment 8G of our supplement, we continue to push rate in the fourth quarter. New lease growth totaled 3.8% or 170 basis points ahead of the fourth quarter of 2014. Renewal growth remained resilient, improving 170 basis points year-over-year to 7%. This year-over-year acceleration was accomplished with only a 40 basis point increase in fourth quarter turnover. 
Next, move-outs to home purchase were up 120 basis points year-over-year at 14%, in line with our long-term average. Importantly, our full year 2015 turnover rate increased by just 20 basis points versus full year 2014. Even with renewal increases had a seasonally strong 7% -- of only 7% of our move-outs get rate increases as they [indiscernible] for leaving in the fourth quarter. However, we expect turnover to increase roughly 100 basis points in 2016 as our revenue growth is heavily predicated on the rate growth and not year-over-year occupancy gains. 
Moving on to quarterly performance on our primary markets, which represent 69% of our same-store NOI and 75% of our total NOI. Metro D.C., which represents 18% of our total NOI, posted positive full year revenue growth of 1.7%. We expect improving full year revenue growth in 2016 of around 2.5% as we continue to benefit from our diverse exposure of 50% B assets and 50% A assets located both inside and outside the Beltway. 
Orange County and Los Angeles combined represents 15.4% of our total NOI. Orange County posted sequential revenue growth of 160 basis points and continues to outperform our budgeted expectations early in 2016. L.A. is materially stronger due to our heavy concentration in the Marina del Rey submarket as new jobs have continued to migrate to this highly desirable submarket. Fourth quarter revenue in LA was an impressive 10.2%. Our current expectation is that both of these markets will generate revenue growth in the 7% range in 2016.
New York City, which represents 12% of our total NOI, posted full year revenue growth of 5.6%. We saw a seasonal weakness of the fourth quarter and early January but future trends are pointing to strength within our submarkets. We continue to expect new jobs from technology, finance and media which will benefit our lower Manhattan properties. Our 2016 forecasted revenue growth of 6% is above 2015. I would remind everyone that View 34 is our same-store pool beginning in first quarter of 2016.
San Francisco and San Jose, which represent 11% of our total NOI, posted full year revenue growth of 9.7%. Although we saw weakness in the fourth quarter, is indicative of the first and fourth quarter seasonality that we have seen in this market in the past. With that said, we believe this weakness is possibly more than just seasonal, and we do not expect this market to posted double-digit revenue growth that it has in recent years and we have forecast that a deceleration in 2016 to revenue growth of 8% or so. Future trends are slowly improving from what we saw in the fourth quarter but we are keeping a close eye on the job growth and absorption levels within our submarkets. Keep in mind, San Francisco job growth has been above 4.5% for the past few years. AXIO Metric's current forecast calls for job growth to decelerate to 2.5% to 3% but still well above the national average of 1.75% to 2%.
Seattle, which represents 6% of our total NOI, benefited from strong growth in suburban B assets for less exposed to new supplied and A assets downtown. Although new supply will challenge someone in Downtown Seattle and to a lesser degree in Bellevue, we expect 2016 to be slightly below our 2015 numbers or roughly 7% growth.
Boston, which represents 7% of our total NOI, should continue to see new supply pressure Downtown, but our suburban assets in the north and south shores should fair relatively better in 2016. Long term, we like downtown submarket and look to continue to grow through development in this submarket. Most recently GE announced the relocation of their global headquarters to the Seaport district. This will bring another 800 jobs into the submarket which should directly benefit our 369-home, 100 Pier 4 community and our future 345 Harrison development in Boston Southend. Our forecast calls for revenue growth to accelerate slightly from the 5.5% growth posted in 2015.
Last, Dallas, which represents 5% of our total NOI, posted 5.1% year-over-year growth in the fourth quarter. We expect new supply pressure in Uptown and Plano in 2016. January results indicate that these submarkets are performing slightly better than initial budgeted expectations and 2016 revenue growth is projected to improve to roughly 5.5% from 5% in 2015.
As you can see on Attachment 7B of our supplement, our 320-home Los Alisos community located in Orange County, our 196-home Waterscape community located in Seattle and our 740-home View 34 community located in New York City will join the same-store pool in the first quarter of 2016.
Turning to our in-lease up developments. Katella Grand 1, our 399-home, $138 million lease up in Anaheim, California, in the West Coast development JV, was 16% occupied at quarter-end and as of today is 20% occupied and 27% leased. We are currently offering less than 1 month of concession with this community and leasing has been very strong in January with 25 applications.
CityLine, our 244-home, $80 million lease up in Seattle Washington, was 9% occupied at quarter-end. We are on budget and meeting our lease-up expectations. 
Finally, 399 Fremont, our 447-home, $318 million lease up in San Francisco began leasing during the fourth quarter. At quarter-end, we were just 2% leased and today, we are over 10% leased with rents exceeding pro forma. We will have our first move-ins in March 2016. 
Now a quick update on the Washington, D.C. acquisition. We're 3 months into owning these communities and everything is going as according to plan. Currently, we're making CapEx improvement to 2 of the properties to either cure deferred maintenance or drive a higher return to revenue-enhancing improvements. We still expect these committees to perform in line with our D.C. portfolio this year with revenue growth right around 2.5%. Currently we would expect 5 of the 6 communities in this portfolio to enter our same-store pool in the first quarter of 2017. 
With that, I will remind those listening that there is a link to our updated 2-year strategic outlook document on the Investor relations page of our website. We will pause for a moment so that everyone can gather the 2-year outlook materials.
I will now turn the call back over to Tom Toomey.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jerry, and please turn to Page 3 for some high-level thoughts.First, we view this year's update as continuation of last 3 plans. We believe this continues to be the right path for UDR, here's why. The plan's primary objective is to drive high-qu
componenttext:
Thanks, Jerry, and please turn to Page 3 for some high-level thoughts.
First, we view this year's update as continuation of last 3 plans. We believe this continues to be the right path for UDR, here's why. The plan's primary objective is to drive high-quality cash flow growth while incrementally improving our balance sheet and portfolio. In other words, consistent, sustainable growth that is funded in a safe, low-risk manner. We believe that successful execution of these objectives will drive strong total shareholder return. 
There are 4 key points I'd like to highlight while we think there's a long runway of accretive growth ahead. First, fundamentals. You have seen plenty of published data on this and, clearly, demographics, supply demand characteristics, are in our favor and any good business that is going to grow for a number of years need solid fundamentals. The second is strategic position. Where do we start? Well, we're in 20 markets, 50% A-B quality mix. We like this position. We think it solves for the #1 critical element of any future growth, which is the positioning of our portfolio such that our residents will continue to be able to grow and pay higher rents. The third is the team and the skills. It's operationally, we'll continue to innovate, invest in technology and training programs, all of which are designed to increase our margins which now stand above 70% of the NOI line, extraordinary for any business. On the development side, we'll remain focused on looking at our risk-adjusted returns and staying disciplined. Fourth is problem-solving. Clearly, we operate in a cyclical economy. And along that line, there will be challenges and opportunities. We have a team that is very experienced of managing through these cycles, if not anticipate these cycles and these opportunities. Certainly I feel confident that the team has the ability to capitalize on these opportunities as they become available. And lastly and just as important is managing risk. And we see ourselves managing this through first, our diversity of our market mix, our discipline around our development and certainly our continued improving balance sheet set of metrics and lastly, our transparency and disclosure and communication style.
We believe these main objectives can continue our cash flow growth in optimizing our total shareholder return. We remain fully focused on executing them. 
With that, I will turn over to Tom to discuss in detail the updated outlook.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Please turn to Page 4. As Tom mentioned earlier, we have met or exceeded all of our primary financial and operational objectives to date as set forth in our prior 3-year plans published in 2013, 2014 and 2015. In particular, our same-store growth and deve
componenttext:
Please turn to Page 4. As Tom mentioned earlier, we have met or exceeded all of our primary financial and operational objectives to date as set forth in our prior 3-year plans published in 2013, 2014 and 2015. In particular, our same-store growth and development deliveries have outperformed over the past 3 years and has served us primary drivers in our better-than-expected cash flow growth and improvements in balance sheet metrics.
Turning to Page 5. Perhaps the most critical driver of UDR's value-creation strategy is our best-in-class operations. We are continuously implementing new revenue growth and cost efficiency initiatives throughout the organization to improve how we do buys. As noted on this page, we have consistently produced better overall top line growth versus peers and the U.S. average since the initiation our 3-year plan in 2013. During this time we have grown our total revenue per occupied home by 26%, increased occupancy by 100 basis points, reduced turnover by 310 basis points and improved our margins by 220 basis points. So how will we maintain our operational advantage and how do you intend to keep it in the future? Please turn to Page 6.
Many who listen to this call are familiar with the primary revenue generation expense control initiatives that are underway. These, along with potential future initiatives, are presented in the table of this page. Importantly, all of our growth and efficiency initiatives have one thing in common, they either provide our customer wanted service or allow our associates to do their jobs better. Current initiatives should continue to drive our bottom line and our list of potential future initiatives is extensive.
Please turn to Page 7. This page lists some of our operational projects that have been implemented over the past couple of years and their impact on our NOI. As is evident, we have made solid progress on each initiative to date and our bottom line has benefited greatly. We will continue to capture additional NOI efficiencies from these initiatives. Operations has been and will continue to be significant limited of advantage for us. This is not just because of our superior blocking and tackling in the field, but also because of the creativity our operations team employs to continuously improve the business.
Turning now to capital allocation and development on Page 8. Development remains a vital component of our value creation strategy. While management [indiscernible] deals [indiscernible] in today's environment, [indiscernible] remains accretive and will continue to be a primary mean in which we continuously improve our portfolio. At year-end, our underway development totaled 670 million towards the equity requirement of 55% funded. Additionally, our share of the West Coast development joint venture going in value was $271 million towards 100% of the equity has been funded. This pipeline is concentrated in our primary coastal markets. Inclusive of the West Coast development JV, we expect to deliver $375 million and $220 million of projects in 2016 and 2017, respectively. 
Our annual targeted spend of $400 million to $500 million per year and our targeted trended spread versus cap rates in 150 to 200 basis points have not changed. While construction costs continue to increase, so do rents. To mitigate my good risk around new development projects, we employed the following disciplines: first, prior to a development commencing, we generally seek entitled land, demand full drawings and a GMAX contract thereby locking in cost and reducing risk. 
Second, we diversify our geographic exposure. Our goal is to commence a new development in a target market as the previous development's leasing up. 
Third, we utilize conservative top line growth assumptions to underwrite our projects. 
And lastly, we employ our self-funded strategy to fund our development pipeline and reduce the penalty on capital markets.
To our free cash flow and non-core asset sales, we can fully fund our annual development spend. In other words, we are match-funding our risk as we recycle older, non-core assets to develop new core assets in our primary markets.
In 2016 and 2017, we will continue to mine our current land bank as well as add new land sites. We are planning to 2 to 3 search in 2016 which include one large wholly-owned project, 345 Harrison in Boston, and 1 to 2 smaller 50-50 JVs with MetLife. As of year-end 2015, our shadow pipeline was approximately $900 million at our pro rata ownership and represented $425 million to $475 million evaluation, assuming current spreads. Please turn to Page 9.
We anticipate that upon full stabilization, which occurs at different periods for each project, our pipeline of underway and completed developments is expected to generate accretion of $0.07 per share, with growth thereafter. On an NAV basis, we expect our pipeline to generate $1.75 per share at stabilization or approximately 35% to 40% value creation of our cost. Page 10 exhibits some of our recent developments.
Please turn to Page 11. As focused as we are on operations and development, maintaining the strong balance sheet, along with a self-funded plan are just as important. We have seen the balance sheet metric goals provided in our 2013, 2014 and 2015 strategic plans, we expect further improvements from 2016 and 2017. This has also been acknowledged by the rating agencies. In 2014, we received a credit upgrade from Moody's to Baa1. And in 2015, we received an upgrade from S&P to BBB+. 
On the capital markets front, our 2016 and 2017 capital needs will be funded through a combination of asset sales and new equity and debt, of which we'll utilize the most advantageous source depending on our strategic objectives, market conditions and pricing at the time the capital is needed. 
Please turn to Page 12. In 2015, our AFFO per share of it was a strong 11%. In 2016, AFFO per share growth is expected to average in the 6% to 9% range. This growth will continue to be driven primarily by favorable same-store growth and development therein. And these will be partially offset by fewer items including non-core dispositions, higher expected interest rate and 421-a and g property tax impact. 
In 2017, AFFO per share growth is expected to be in the 5% to 8% range. This 100 basis point delta is primarily due to lower same-store assumptions. As in our prior strategic plans, we rely on third-party data providers for our future growth expectations in the out years. And of note, these estimates have proven conservative in the last several years and our team has been able to outperform.
We expect the business to 9% to 11% NAV growth in 2016 and 8% to 10% NAV growth in 2017. Please turn to Page 13.
This page provides our 2016 guidance, initial 2017 expectations and detailed modeling assumptions. In 2017, we are expecting solid same-store and cash flow growth based on still strong third-party job growth expectations against moderating new multifamily supply growth in our markets. In addition, our expected asset sales and entrance to our same-store pool in 2016 and 2017 will enhance our same-store mix toward higher growth markets.
And finally, Page 14. Our 2016 top line growth assumptions for our markets are presented on the map. We expect the West Coast and Southeast to grow at a rate above the portfolio average. The Mid-Atlantic will continue to perform below the portfolio average but will improve slightly, and we still expect to outperform relative to our peers due to our 50-50 mix of As and Bs in D.C. and less direct risk exposure to new supply inside the Beltway. 
With that I will turn it open to Q&A. Operator.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Nick Joseph of Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Nick Joseph of Citigroup.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering what the 2-year plan assumes for the broader macroeconomic environment and if it makes it any over recession over the next 24 months?
componenttext: I'm just wondering what the 2-year plan assumes for the broader macroeconomic environment and if it makes it any over recession over the next 24 months?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now, Nick, this is Jerry. We really look at the AXIO and Moody's data to start with. What they're forecasting is continuation of job growth not too far off from what it was in 2015, call it a little over 200,000 per month. Supply is going to impact us thi
componenttext: Now, Nick, this is Jerry. We really look at the AXIO and Moody's data to start with. What they're forecasting is continuation of job growth not too far off from what it was in 2015, call it a little over 200,000 per month. Supply is going to impact us this year, probably a little more than it did last year and in '17 there's a drop-off. So we look at the macro data. And then we start looking at specific submarkets where we operate and take into account how directly we're going to be affected by that. In addition, when you really go through it, so there's of the other things to consider. We will continue to spend about $35 million to probably low to $40 millions in revenue enhancing improvements to our properties, so add probably between 50 and 25 basis points into 2017 or probably about that much in 2016. And as we look further out into 2017, there's probably only a couple of markets that look to us like good they would be decelerating from the growth rates that we anticipate in 2016. Those are northern California, Seattle for the most part. And then we see some that we think are going to be improving and that would be the Mid-Atlantic. We also see Boston most likely improving for us. And then the rest of our portfolio, whether it's SoCal or the Sunbelt, we would expect to be modestly down. And when you blend all that together, it takes you from our midpoint this year of about a 5-7-5 growth down to that 5. So again, we don't really anticipate a recession. We don't claim to be economists. We subscribe to what they say, but that's how we look looking at the business.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you're clearly benefiting from strong operating trends in the developments delivering ahead of expectations, but I'm a little surprised that your expecting 2016 core FFO growth isn't higher given expected same-store NOI growth, the benefit from t
componenttext: And then you're clearly benefiting from strong operating trends in the developments delivering ahead of expectations, but I'm a little surprised that your expecting 2016 core FFO growth isn't higher given expected same-store NOI growth, the benefit from the 2 accretive 2015 transactions and the benefit of leverage. So can walk through what is driving expected core FFO growth that's actually below expected same-store NOI growth for 2016?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes sure, Nick. It's Tom Herzog. Yes, to your point that the same-store comes in with a $0.12 positive number, development comes in at $0.02 which is lower than what we had in 2015 and that's purely due to timing on what that delivered. In 2015 you had ch
componenttext: Yes sure, Nick. It's Tom Herzog. Yes, to your point that the same-store comes in with a $0.12 positive number, development comes in at $0.02 which is lower than what we had in 2015 and that's purely due to timing on what that delivered. In 2015 you had channel View 34, 27, 75. 2016, you're looking at Pier 4, Beach and Ocean which have got some drag from 399 X City, Jamboree 30, 33 in the main Mountain View over projects but at this point there's some drag. So that lowered the development by a bit from what we had seen in 2015. Some of the items that would've leaned against FFO growth relative to the NOI, it would have been -- floating interest rates are up about 40 basis points, in our model that's $0.01. The average revolver balance is going to be down some, call it $150 million or so, that's $0.015 and was also due to the timing of mid-September debt issuance. The tax benefit goes from $3.9 million to $1.5 million, that's $0.01. [indiscernible] 31 exchanges picks up another $0.01. And then to your point earlier, that is partially offset by the accretive West Coast JV and some accretion on the home transaction, and those are all the moving parts. So this is as we would've expected, our core and base growth going forward it's just as strong but we just had a few items that caused -- that to come a little bit lower relative to the same-store.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jana Galan of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jana Galan of Bank of America.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, I wondered if you could expand upon the comments you made earlier on the fourth quarter softness in San Francisco and San Jose that what you're seeing could mean it it could be more than just seasonal?.
componenttext: Jerry, I wondered if you could expand upon the comments you made earlier on the fourth quarter softness in San Francisco and San Jose that what you're seeing could mean it it could be more than just seasonal?.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's hard to tell at this point, Jana. We did see [indiscernible] occupancy and pricing power hit pressures in the fourth quarter, but as we've rolled into January we started to see signs of improvement. New lease rate growth in the fourth quarter wa
componenttext: Yes. It's hard to tell at this point, Jana. We did see [indiscernible] occupancy and pricing power hit pressures in the fourth quarter, but as we've rolled into January we started to see signs of improvement. New lease rate growth in the fourth quarter was 5.2%, renewal growth 9 3. As we look at January, our January new leases are up 4.2% in San Francisco, San Jose and that compares to 3 3 in December, so it is improving. And our January renewals are still well above 8% at 8.4% our occupancy's at 97 so it has strengthened. Now as we look at good job, which is the primary concern in those markets right now, it's been running about 4.5% for the past couple of years. And when we have talked to AXIO Metrics, they're forecasting for job growth to decelerate to 2.5% to 3%. And while that's about 150 to 200 basis point deceleration, it's still well above the national average of job growth of 1.75% to 2%. So we'd like to think it's all seasonal. We're going to know in the next 60 days if it is. And over the last 3 to 5 years, there's probably 2 or 3x in the first quarter when that group concerned about the strength in San Francisco only to see things turn around as we got into the month of March and April so it's a subtle bit early to tell. But on the ground, we're not seeing any significant job loss from many single employers. And as I've said as we've come out of the fourth quarter and answered the first quarter, we have seen fundamental start to strengthen again.

componenttext: And then on the operational initiative, very impressive to get to your 7% NOI margins. I guess how much room is left in terms of reducing these vacant or maintenance staff deficiencies?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes I think [Indiscernible] vacant, we've come from about 26 days to 20. We're not going to get it much lower, I don't think. Call it may be another 2 days, but we've been chopping 1 day, 1.5 days off each of the last 3 to 4 years. It's starting to slow a
componenttext: Yes I think [Indiscernible] vacant, we've come from about 26 days to 20. We're not going to get it much lower, I don't think. Call it may be another 2 days, but we've been chopping 1 day, 1.5 days off each of the last 3 to 4 years. It's starting to slow a bit. Now the only thing you can do to [indiscernible] quicker is to cut rate. That's how you can really move to compartment homes. And we're more focused on driving rate so we'll let that vacant day stay about where it is. The staffing efficiency, I think we can continue to drive that metric even better. There's a few things technologically we're working with our property management software provider to help us go to the next step on. But I would tell as we created our expense budgets for 2016, we do have our repairs and maintenance coming in flat. Once again this is probably going to be the third or fourth straight year that it's been negative to positive -- either negative or up 1%. So we've kept that in pretty good control while we've been able to achieve turnover which remained flat. So we use those guidelines not just to push price down, but to enhance service which helps us maintain a steady turnover.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: You guys put out, I guess, guidance for the year of about budgeted spend of $550 million to $700 million combination of debt equity and sale proceeds, I think for the balance of this year. But maybe they just talk about the attractiveness of each in this environment as we sit here today.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ian, it's Herzog here again. I think about it this way. If we're looking at debt, let's just start there. Typically, we're going to use unsecured debt to refinance debt that's maturing. And that might be coming in at, call it, 4 2, 4 3 range. In our model
componenttext: Ian, it's Herzog here again. I think about it this way. If we're looking at debt, let's just start there. Typically, we're going to use unsecured debt to refinance debt that's maturing. And that might be coming in at, call it, 4 2, 4 3 range. In our model, it'd be cheaper right now. But I think of debt in terms of that type of a cost on unsecured basis, that's on a 10 year. Let's go to equity. Equity, I'm going to look at an AFFO yield on a current year basis and just based off of AFFO projected toward at the midpoint of a share price, that comes in at about a 4.5 [indiscernible] of course, we're going to add growth to that so I have to look at it at a cost of equity basis and that's probably going to be somewhere just shy of probably 8% or something like that on a cost of equity basis. And then you to sales of assets, and again on our current yield, it depends on what cap rate of assets that we're selling. I think our sales for 2015 came in at the 5.8% cap rate here, is that correct?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: 5.8%. But again it depends on the mix of what we're selling and as we think about how we fund our business, the debt maturities, which are rather modest over the next couple of years, probably comes from refinancing of debt. When you think about the devel
componenttext: 5.8%. But again it depends on the mix of what we're selling and as we think about how we fund our business, the debt maturities, which are rather modest over the next couple of years, probably comes from refinancing of debt. When you think about the development spend, call it development spend, $500 million including redab [ph], including land, we can fully self-fund that, as I said on my scripted remarks, through our free cash flow, through our 1031 exchanges on land and on a portion of our development spend, with the balance funded through sales and gain capacity at about $125 million, $130 million. So if we choose to we can fund the entire development spend on a self-funded basis and our debt maturities through refis. In the meantime, we have $1 billion of capacity right now on the revolver and cash. So again, back to the point of our business being quite self-funded. But when we look at each decision as it comes to pass during the year against these various forms of capital, those are the different decisions that we -- so those are the different data points that we look at when you make a decision on how we fund the activities.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Sure. This is Harry. So for asset sales, right now they're still at tremendous amount of capital chasing assets -- A assets, B assets cap rates are very favorable, capital is readily available to acquire these assets. But we don't see that changing anytime soon. Debt remains readily available. Cash flows continue to grow. And we're seeing investors not just pension fund, but also sovereign wealth funds, [indiscernible] changes potentially have opened, of additional invested investment in U.S. real estate to foreign entities. So at this point, the disposition market continues to be very liquid.

componenttext: Austin, this is Jerry. I would expect it to be a little bit less. We do not anticipate, as you get to the backup of this year, to have quite as much ability to drive new lease rate or renewal rate. Our expectation within our budgets was that market conditions would be a little bit weaker across the board -- well not across the board but in aggregate. I'll call it 70, 80 basis points. So if I had to guess right now what I think we would go into next year with, instead of being in the 2 75, it's probably going to be somewhere closer to the 2 40, 2 50 in order to get that deceleration from midpoint to midpoint of about 75 basis points.

componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Right now, they're going out between 6% and 7% January, probably in that 6% -- well that's what we achieved in January. As you look out over the next 2 months, it's probably a hair less, call it 6% to 7% but we are seeing strength -- I won't s
componenttext: Absolutely. Right now, they're going out between 6% and 7% January, probably in that 6% -- well that's what we achieved in January. As you look out over the next 2 months, it's probably a hair less, call it 6% to 7% but we are seeing strength -- I won't say strength. We're seeing a stable environment in our New York portfolio. And our occupancy today in New York is at 97%. You look at New York, we're in 3 submarkets, we're in Chelsea. We have 2 assets -- or 3 submarkets. We have 2 down in the Financial District, we have 1 in Murray Hill that we have our last 1, which is a Met JV, is in the Upper West Side. The Upper West Side is definitely the weakest of the group where we are in fourth quarter we had revenue growth of about 1%. When you look at the other 3 that were on our same-store pool which is the 2 downtown, as well as Chelsea, revenue growth was 5.5% to 6%. So we're not seeing supply issues anywhere except the Upper West Side. You're not really seeing affordability to a great extent right now and you're not -- we're also not seeing job loss anywhere.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's helpful. I mean from a demand perspective, I guess you mentioned you're not seeing any job loss. But as you look out, I mean do you think if job growth were the slow that some of the demographic trends in New York, do you think that, that be en
componenttext: No, that's helpful. I mean from a demand perspective, I guess you mentioned you're not seeing any job loss. But as you look out, I mean do you think if job growth were the slow that some of the demographic trends in New York, do you think that, that be enough to backfill demand given the supply that we're seeing in New York?

componenttextpreview: Yes I do because a lot of our portfolio is B, with the exception of probably our Chelsea property is also Upper West Side, our Murray Hill and our 2 downtown properties really do cater to that B renter. And I think could people trade down if they wanted t
componenttext: Yes I do because a lot of our portfolio is B, with the exception of probably our Chelsea property is also Upper West Side, our Murray Hill and our 2 downtown properties really do cater to that B renter. And I think could people trade down if they wanted to from the As to come to us. And several of our floor plans, especially over at View 34 are very large so people did feel the [indiscernible] and had to double up anything that would be an alternative, too.

componenttext: I'd probably just cut to the chase and tell you what the benefit is to my same-store. It's about 20 basis points. It's predominantly coming from View 34 and these other 2 but -- and just to give you a little indication. Our New York, which when Herzog was going through the 2-year outlook, we have said New York revenue was going to come in really in that -- within our midpoint, 5.5 to 6. It's much closer to 6 than 5.5. But View 34 was adding roughly 80 basis points to New York, so without that well I would have been in the low 5s. But again, when you look at the components of each one of these that's going into the full year this year, call it 20 basis points. so without those, I would have been, I guess 5 to 5.6.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then as far as maybe this one's for Tom Toomey, as far as your -- if you think about the class B piece of your portfolio and maybe it's in some markets Orlando or other places, how are you sort of weighting, keeping that as kind of hedging against new supply and assets have done quite well versus all the talk coming out of MHC which was at redevelopment value add, if you could so those properties people today you're going set of the most aggressive pricing in the market's ever seen.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess I look at it this way. Through cycles, these tend to hold up very well. And when you find markets we look at income to the ability for the residents to pay, to our ability to continue to push rent increases through to them, the Bs probably h
componenttext: Well, I guess I look at it this way. Through cycles, these tend to hold up very well. And when you find markets we look at income to the ability for the residents to pay, to our ability to continue to push rent increases through to them, the Bs probably have a bigger bandwidth in our mind to absorb it. And then on the downside, they're probably insulated more than the As. So I've always drawn to kind of a good, solid B in a great location as a good long-term cash flow driving machine. And so we'll probably always have a good mix of these in the portfolio and we'll solve really for our ability to grow cash flow over time.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: We think it's about 50-50 right now between A and B. And over time, those As will turn into Bs and we'll have to continue to reload at the top end. But we'll always probably be a company that will have that balance of 50-50.

componenttext: Great. Second question, past few quarters you've suggested the increased to G&A guidance has largely been due to higher than expected incentive program payouts from outperforming targets. It looks like G&A ended up 50% higher than initial guidance so could you just give us a little color on what specific metrics were hit that drove the $8 million overrun?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When you look at G&A there were a number of different ways -- by the way you're right, it was FTI and was LTI that drove the higher G&A. Our metric center around things like same-store, development spreads, balance sheet metrics, TSR and then on top
componenttext: Yes. When you look at G&A there were a number of different ways -- by the way you're right, it was FTI and was LTI that drove the higher G&A. Our metric center around things like same-store, development spreads, balance sheet metrics, TSR and then on top of that, we had a couple of [indiscernible] that were very good for our business including the West Coast development JV, the home transaction with the Washington, D.C. And so we hit on all of our metrics in 2015 that we had set forth higher than average LTI payouts and STI payouts. One of the thing I would have a note though that might get missed is that we have the transitional plan in place moving from the old LTI program to the new where we now have a 3-year cliff vest on the TSR portion and we didn't use to have that so the transitional piece is about $3.5 million of that $10 million variance. So just keep that in mind.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jordan, this is Toomey. I'd just tell you, '15, we had everything right out of the ballpark from ops to transactions to the financing of the company to the TSR. And so I'm grateful that we're -- that performance and happy as hell to pay out bonuses across
componenttext: Jordan, this is Toomey. I'd just tell you, '15, we had everything right out of the ballpark from ops to transactions to the financing of the company to the TSR. And so I'm grateful that we're -- that performance and happy as hell to pay out bonuses across up and down the entire organization, and we'd like to do it again, frankly. If we had all those metrics and perform that level again, we will be paying at that level.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few quick questions here. First, on the -- what slide is this, Slide 7, Jerry, where you guys talked about the benefit of reducing the downtime of days vacant. And then you also talk about going back and resuscitating fold leads both as increasing
componenttext: Just a few quick questions here. First, on the -- what slide is this, Slide 7, Jerry, where you guys talked about the benefit of reducing the downtime of days vacant. And then you also talk about going back and resuscitating fold leads both as increasing NOI. It would seem like resuscitating old leads would sort of cut down on vacancy. So are the 2 NOI impacts -- are any -- that would seem to be overlapping. Are they 2 distinct NOI benefits or you're just citing the difference of different initiatives but in aggregate, it's -- you wouldn't add those 2 together?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's probably a bit of overlap, you're right. Part of what helps us fill vacant units faster is going back after lost leads. So there probably is a hair bit of duplicity in there. What we're really looking for is, again, on the restoration of disc
componenttext: Yes, there's probably a bit of overlap, you're right. Part of what helps us fill vacant units faster is going back after lost leads. So there probably is a hair bit of duplicity in there. What we're really looking for is, again, on the restoration of discarded leads is trying to help out our site associate that at times don't have enough time to do adequate follow-up. So yes, there's probably a little bit of that, that could be occurring.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what else is driving -- apart from resuscitating old leads, what else drives reducing the downtime of the units? I mean, it takes a certain amount of time to clean the unit, there's regular marketing traffic which you guys are pretty good. So what else
componenttext: So what else is driving -- apart from resuscitating old leads, what else drives reducing the downtime of the units? I mean, it takes a certain amount of time to clean the unit, there's regular marketing traffic which you guys are pretty good. So what else goes in to cutting down that downtime on the unit?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a multitude of things. One, we spread the lease expirations throughout the month instead of having them all occur at the same time. Some -- it's much easier just to say leases expire at the end of the month, but when you do that, you have 30 people m
componenttext: It's a multitude of things. One, we spread the lease expirations throughout the month instead of having them all occur at the same time. Some -- it's much easier just to say leases expire at the end of the month, but when you do that, you have 30 people move out at a 600-unit property. Your maintenance team can't get to the 30th apartment to turn it until day 22. By spreading it throughout the month, you're able to do a little bit better. The other things you do is you try to entice people to push up your move-in date. If you know an apartment is going to be market-ready on the 26th of the month and somebody comes in and says, hey, I want to move in at the end of the month or the beginning of the month, you basically tell them when they will be moving in. So you push them closer to the 26 instead of automatically just putting them in as a move-in on the 30th and that could cut off 3 days. So some of it's strategic, some of it is putting in more demanding metrics in our maintenance team for expectations of when apartments need to be turned. Old-school way of doing it, you wouldn't go turn a  unit until it was leased. The way we try to do it is turn as quickly as you can from when someone moves out so you have ready inventory. But those are probably the major factors.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay that's helpful. And then sticking with you, Jerry. You made the comments earlier on San Francisco and too early to tell if it was just the year-end softness versus there's something that's [indiscernible] happening at the job market there. But just c
componenttext: Okay that's helpful. And then sticking with you, Jerry. You made the comments earlier on San Francisco and too early to tell if it was just the year-end softness versus there's something that's [indiscernible] happening at the job market there. But just curious, given your other tech-market exposure like in Seattle and maybe Boston as well, do you get a sense if there's linkage so that if there were a slowdown of attack, let's say in San Francisco, your team in Seattle or Boston or other tech-oriented markets would feel it or the view is that a number of these -- what could be happening at a local doesn't necessarily happen at -- in the other tech-related markets?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't it happens quite as much. There's more start-up activity honestly the Bay Area so if funding for unicorns and the other tech startups slows, I don't think it has as much of an effect in places like Seattle. Down in LA where Silicon Beach is be
componenttext: No. I don't it happens quite as much. There's more start-up activity honestly the Bay Area so if funding for unicorns and the other tech startups slows, I don't think it has as much of an effect in places like Seattle. Down in LA where Silicon Beach is becoming really a tech hub or out in Boston, those are typically more established organizations that are dependent on financing.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The point is you're not seeing any softness in any of those other 3 markets you just cited?
componenttext: Okay. The point is you're not seeing any softness in any of those other 3 markets you just cited?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're actually seeing strength in all 3 of those other markets.
componenttext: No, we're actually seeing strength in all 3 of those other markets.

componenttext: Yes. No, I think your Bs are still continuing to outperform. They have -- it's compressed at times widened but our B product outside the Beltway continues to carry us versus our inside the Beltway. When I look at our As, they're currently coming in probably close to our A urban. Had revenue growth in the fourth quarter of about 1% and our Bs which are predominantly in the suburbs came in about 2%. So on a revenue basis, call it 100 basis points.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Tom Herzog or Jerry, I mean, when I think about turnover for you guys, I mean turnover [indiscernible] up modestly year-over-year at 52%. How should we be thinking about the impact of 100 or 200 basis points of turnover in terms of the bott
componenttext: Okay. And then Tom Herzog or Jerry, I mean, when I think about turnover for you guys, I mean turnover [indiscernible] up modestly year-over-year at 52%. How should we be thinking about the impact of 100 or 200 basis points of turnover in terms of the bottom line? What does that ever send penny-wise for you guys if turnover goes up 100 basis points in 2016 over what you're expecting?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really depends on what you're getting for rate growth. If I'm pushing renewals at 8% and my turnover goes up 100 basis points, it's probably possible to my bottom line and it also depends on how quickly I can reload. I don't have the exact number off t
componenttext: It really depends on what you're getting for rate growth. If I'm pushing renewals at 8% and my turnover goes up 100 basis points, it's probably possible to my bottom line and it also depends on how quickly I can reload. I don't have the exact number off the top of my head. I will tell you might expectations this year for '16 is my turnover's going to go up about 100 basis points because we're going to continue to try to drive rate. So I don't think you're going to see it continue to come down. We're not seeing an increase in move-outs to homeownership. We're not seeing it for money problems. The one metric that is tending to migrate up a little bit is move-outs due to rent increase but it still has gotten to a level of that I see is pushing an inordinate number of people out the door. And if you look at that schedule that's in our supp,  which shows the turnover metrics comparing this year to last year attachment 8(G), there's really only one market where you see a significant increase and that's our Monterey County which went probably up from 49% to almost 57%. That's also a market where we have revenue growth this past year in the low to mid-teens, so we would do it all again. In places like San Francisco and areas like that, it's going up 100, 150 bps and I'll take that too as long as I'm getting renewal growth that's approaching double-digit.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the real estate tax side, what's the impact from 421-b expirations and what's the overall assumption for real estate tax growth in '16?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the real estate tax side, what's the impact from 421-b expirations and what's the overall assumption for real estate tax growth in '16?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll give you the second part and Herzog's going to talk more 421s. Overall this next year, our expectation is real estate taxes are going to go up in that probably 7% range. Now, that sounds like a huge number. This past year, our real estate tax expense
componenttext: I'll give you the second part and Herzog's going to talk more 421s. Overall this next year, our expectation is real estate taxes are going to go up in that probably 7% range. Now, that sounds like a huge number. This past year, our real estate tax expense we thought was going to come in 5.5% to 6%, and it actually came in at right around 3%. We benefited dramatically from appeal wins. Probably pushing to $1.8 million to $2 million that brought us down almost 200 basis points. When we factor in and budget for real estate tax growth, we do not expect or build in any refund. So again, it's going to be roughly up at that 7% range is what we're showing today. And a  chunk of that, as Herzog will tell you in a minute, is due to the 421s. Tom?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jerry. From a same-store perspective, Rob, the 2016 same-store perspective as a company we would expect that to -- the impact of about 45 basis points. And in 2017, about 70 basis points. I will mention that on schedule -- in the schedule 8 series of
componenttext: Yes, Jerry. From a same-store perspective, Rob, the 2016 same-store perspective as a company we would expect that to -- the impact of about 45 basis points. And in 2017, about 70 basis points. I will mention that on schedule -- in the schedule 8 series of our supp, we do footnote for the total portfolio and for New York specifically, the impacts on same-store expense and same-store NOI so that you can see it with and without. And from an AFFO perspective in 2016, it's about 670 grand roughly just from the burn off from the abatements and whatnot. And in 2017, it'd be about $1.3 million. That's what we have [indiscernible] right now.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Oppenheim of Zalman Associates.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit in terms of the 2016 expectations. Where do see these as greater risk. If you think about revenue side potentially here in the Bay Area where it we've certainly seen some of the deceleration as of late but then
componenttext: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit in terms of the 2016 expectations. Where do see these as greater risk. If you think about revenue side potentially here in the Bay Area where it we've certainly seen some of the deceleration as of late but then also on the expense side talking about R&M being flat or personal costs probably have to come down from where they have been lately or the in the tax side, how do you think about sort of weighing the risks as you go through 2016?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with that, this is Jerry. I see little risk of expense side. Again, we have expenses budgeted at 3.75%. When you have a margin like us, what really moves the business most is the revenue. I already told you what we have in our model currently f
componenttext: I'll start with that, this is Jerry. I see little risk of expense side. Again, we have expenses budgeted at 3.75%. When you have a margin like us, what really moves the business most is the revenue. I already told you what we have in our model currently for real estate tax is at 7. It doesn't really have refunds calculated in, and I'm confident we're going to get some of those. The other expense categories we're looking that we've build in the second largest component of our expense stack is personnel which is about 1/4 of our total expenses. We expect that to go up to 24 -- 4.25% higher than it has of the last several years as we had more competitive pressures to attract and retain our associates. All of the other categories, marketing we expect to go down. Our marketing team's done a great job both with our website, as well as working with the ISLs to -- or ILSs to bring down our cost. Repairs and maintenance, I don't see that going up dramatically. I think we have that locked down pretty well. Some of the expense side, I think it's not overly risky. The revenue side, there's always risk and probably the 2 markets that we're keeping our eyes on the most would be San Francisco because we hear all those same information you guys here. New York, we're watching that closely too and as I've said earlier about both of those markets, they both today, it's not apparent to us whether it's seasonal issues that created weakness in the fourth quarter because we're starting to strengthen [indiscernible] something more. But as I look at it there's really 3 markets that today you would say are kind of risky, and it'd those 2, as well as Austin. But what I would also say is, those constitute 25% of UDR's total NOI. When you look at all of the other markets combined, which make up 75%, we see strength. We see strength in Southern California, the entire Sunbelt with the exception of Austin is extremely strong today. D.C., while it's  still going to be a laggard by comparison, it's improving and we think Boston's improving. So while there may be risk in a market or two, the benefit of having a geographically dispersed and asset class differentiation between the As and Bs I think this is pretty good protection.

I'm just curious what you think about that in terms of managing your leverage at the joint venture level so that the full leverage story looks better than what it apps at this point.

componenttext: Rich, that's a fair question. This is Toomey. I think your map is about right. And as we think about the joint venture, what maybe the street doesn't always look through to is the strength of our partner in MetLife and their position and strength. And so they're very comfortable running these development joint ventures. And then when they're completed, they'll finance amount [ph] it 40% to 50% leverage, which would be high for UDR's corporate entity. We're comfortable with them as a partner financing around that level, and feel that they're there for a long period of time. And we'll perform if necessary and have shown a track record of doing so through many cycles.

componenttext: Okay so we'll be -- it'll be the same 100 basis point impact 2 years from now, you think?

componenttextpreview: I would put it at that.
componenttext: I would put it at that.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair. The way it looks organically right now, I would -- everything Tom said, I obviously agree with as well. One of the things you have to take into account is that when you look back at what's taken place in the company over the last numb
componenttext: I think that's fair. The way it looks organically right now, I would -- everything Tom said, I obviously agree with as well. One of the things you have to take into account is that when you look back at what's taken place in the company over the last number of years we have dramatically used leverage. But over the last 2 years it's been purely -- or substantially organically. And so you've got the organic improvements that will occur, but also as we had in opportunity to do a home or West Coast development JV, if we were trading at a place where we could issue stock at a premium, that does give us an opportunity to further delever the enterprise by acquiring assets on an accretive basis at a premium and that then lowers the  leverage of the enterprise. The other thing I'd mention is when we look at our current leverage levels with the rating agencies and we have studies done by 3 different banks as to where we're rated at the BBB+, Baa1 and what the sweet spot has been determined is at the leverage level that we're, at the BBB+, Baa1. So to go through unnatural means to further improve that leverage and do so on a [indiscernible] basis is not something that's all that enticing as we think we could continue to improve it over time in the ways I just described.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John, this is Harry. I think we view acquisitions  primarily as opportunity base, and so the significant acquisition we had last year, which was the home acquisition, really we were able to solve a problem in that we had a currency that was required
componenttext: Sure, John, this is Harry. I think we view acquisitions  primarily as opportunity base, and so the significant acquisition we had last year, which was the home acquisition, really we were able to solve a problem in that we had a currency that was required in order to get the deal done. As we look forward again, if something like that came up we certainly would take a look at it. But as we started last year, we don't have any expectations that that's going to materialize again. If it does, we'll certainly take a look at it, but we don't have any reason to expect that, that will reoccur.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what about your risk appetite?
componenttext: And what about your risk appetite?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, our risk appetite has remained unchanged. And you also asked about deal flow, I mean there are tremendous amounts of deals in the market today. You saw last year it was nearly $140 billion in transactions across the multifamily space which was a
componenttext: So again, our risk appetite has remained unchanged. And you also asked about deal flow, I mean there are tremendous amounts of deals in the market today. You saw last year it was nearly $140 billion in transactions across the multifamily space which was a record year. And they read a couple of a couple of weeks ago the broker community is indicating that they're actually ahead to this year where they were last year, so we expect there to be sort of continued frothy deal market. But again it's very difficult for us right now to compete with the pension funds with the sovereign wealth funds and assets that you want to buy. Again, if an opportunity materializes where we can solve the problem, we think that might be a spot where we could potentially capitalize.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Toomey. I would just characterize it as this way. It's not an element of risk and it's more of an element we believe the fundamentals of the industry have many years ahead of strength. It's just a function of pricing and opportunities and we
componenttext: John, this is Toomey. I would just characterize it as this way. It's not an element of risk and it's more of an element we believe the fundamentals of the industry have many years ahead of strength. It's just a function of pricing and opportunities and we would rather save our currency for where we can have ability and that's in our development pipeline today. On the acquisition front, prices are pretty good. I think assets still have some room to run, but we think we want to be a self-funded company that can internalize our growth, if you will. And the best path for that is continued development today. We'll continue to look at the market on an acquisition front but really do not feel that pricing-wise we're going to get the same type of returns that we would be getting at our development pipeline.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I think, Jerry, you mentioned you see Southern California decelerating in 2017. Can you break that down between Orange County and LA, if there's any difference.
componenttext: Okay. And then I think, Jerry, you mentioned you see Southern California decelerating in 2017. Can you break that down between Orange County and LA, if there's any difference.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I thought it would be stable to slight deceleration and that's mainly just based on how strong we see it this year. They're both going to be coming in at our current projections close to 7%. If I had to forecast between the 2, I'd probably -- it's probabl
componenttext: I thought it would be stable to slight deceleration and that's mainly just based on how strong we see it this year. They're both going to be coming in at our current projections close to 7%. If I had to forecast between the 2, I'd probably -- it's probably about even. I think they're both going to remain strong for a while. They're both late to the game. You've got fantastic tech job growth in that Marina del Rey submarket where most of our assets are located now and I don't see that slowing down. I think the jobs still haven't fully arrived. When I look down at Southern California, I just ready other do there was more job growth there in 2015 than there has been since I think the late 1999 levels, so it's picked up. You don't have any one large employer. You don't really have significant supply issues in Orange County. And in LA, most of the new supplies come down to where we're not located. So I would say, at this point I don't see the significant differentiation between how the 2 are going to perform next year. This year, I would expect our LA portfolio probably to be a  hair higher than our Orange County.

componenttext: Yes, Greg, it'll expand and contract quarter-by-quarter. Today, the differentiation is probably about 150 basis points nationally. I saw it probably reached its peak year, 1 year, 1.5 years ago when it was well over 200 basis points.
