And also can you provide some color on the volume and characteristics of potential deal flow compared to maybe a few months ago?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John, this is Harry. I think we view acquisitions primarily as opportunity based, and so the significant acquisition we had last year, which was the home acquisition, really we were able to solve a problem in that we had a currency that was required
componenttext: Sure, John, this is Harry. I think we view acquisitions primarily as opportunity based, and so the significant acquisition we had last year, which was the home acquisition, really we were able to solve a problem in that we had a currency that was required in order to get that deal done. As we look forward again, if something like that came up we certainly would take a look at it. But as we started last year, we don't have any expectations that that's going to materialize again. If it does, we'll certainly take a look at it, but we don't have any reason to expect that, that will reoccur.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what about your risk appetite?
componenttext: And what about your risk appetite?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, again, our risk appetite has remained unchanged. And you also asked about deal flow, I mean there are tremendous amounts of deals in the market today. You saw last year was nearly $140 billion in transactions across the multifamily space which was a r
componenttext: So, again, our risk appetite has remained unchanged. And you also asked about deal flow, I mean there are tremendous amounts of deals in the market today. You saw last year was nearly $140 billion in transactions across the multifamily space which was a record year. And NAREIT a couple of week or at NMHC a couple of weeks ago, the broker community is indicating that they're actually ahead this year where they were last year, so we expect there to be sort of continued frothy deal market. But again it's very difficult for us right now to compete with the pension funds, with the sovereign wealth funds on the assets that we want to buy. Again, if an opportunity materializes where we can solve the problem, we think that might be a spot where we could potentially capitalize.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Toomey. I would just characterize it as this way. It's not an element of risk and it's more of an element we believe the fundamentals of the industry have many years ahead of strength. It's just a function of pricing and opportunities and we
componenttext: John, this is Toomey. I would just characterize it as this way. It's not an element of risk and it's more of an element we believe the fundamentals of the industry have many years ahead of strength. It's just a function of pricing and opportunities and we would rather save our currency from where we can have more predictability and that's in our development pipeline today. On the acquisition front, prices are pretty good. I think assets still have some room to run, but we think we want to be a self-funded company that can internalize our growth, if you will. And the best path for that is continued development today. We'll continue to look at the market on an acquisition front but really do not feel that pricing-wise we're going to get the same type of returns that we would be getting in our development pipeline.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I think, Jerry, you mentioned that you see Southern California decelerating in 2017. Can you break that down between Orange County and LA, if there's any difference?
componenttext: Okay. And then I think, Jerry, you mentioned that you see Southern California decelerating in 2017. Can you break that down between Orange County and LA, if there's any difference?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I thought it would be stable to slight deceleration and that's mainly just based on how strong we see it this year. They're both going to be coming in at our current projections close to 7%. If I had to forecast between the 2, I'd probably -- it's probabl
componenttext: I thought it would be stable to slight deceleration and that's mainly just based on how strong we see it this year. They're both going to be coming in at our current projections close to 7%. If I had to forecast between the 2, I'd probably -- it's probably about even. I think they're both going to remain strong for a while. They're both late to the game. You've got fantastic tech job growth in that Marina del Rey submarket where most of our assets are located now and I don't see that slowing down. I think the jobs still haven't fully arrived. When I look down at Southern California, I just read the other do there was more job growth there in 2015 than there has been since, I think, the late 1999 levels, so it's picked up. You don't have any one large employer. You don't really have significant supply issues in Orange County. And in LA, most of the new supplies coming downtown where we're not located. So I would say, at this point I don't see a significant differentiation between how the 2 are going to perform next year. This year, I would expect our LA portfolio probably to be a hair higher than our Orange County.

componenttext: Greg, it'll expand and contract quarter-by-quarter. Today, the differentiation is probably about 150 basis points nationally. So I would say on a national basis for us, that's probably about what the difference is, call it 150 bps. I saw it probably reached its peak 1 year, 1.5 years ago when it was well over 200 basis points. At some point earlier this year, I remember looking and it felt like it had contracted down to about 50 but in the fourth quarter, it was about 150.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to UDR's Fourth Quarter Financial Results Conference Call. Our fourth quarter press release, supplemental disclosure package and updated 2-year strategic outlook document were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investors Relations s
componenttext:
Welcome to UDR's Fourth Quarter Financial Results Conference Call. Our fourth quarter press release, supplemental disclosure package and updated 2-year strategic outlook document were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investors Relations section of our website, www.udr.com.
In the supplement, we have reconciled all non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements. Prior to reading our safe harbor disclosure, I would like to direct you to the webcast of this call located in the Investor Relations section of our website, www.udr.com. The webcast includes a slide presentation that will accompany our 2-year strategic outlook commentary.
On the safe harbor. Statements made during this call, which are not historical, may constitute forward-looking statements. Although we believe the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, we can give no assurance that our expectations will be met. A discussion of risks and risk factors are detailed in our press release and included in our filings with the SEC. We do not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements.
[Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to our President and CEO, Tom Toomey.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's Fourth Quarter and 2016/'17 Strategic Plan Update Conference Call. On the call with me today are Tom Herzog, Chief Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will
componenttext:
Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's Fourth Quarter and 2016/'17 Strategic Plan Update Conference Call. On the call with me today are Tom Herzog, Chief Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss our results; as well as senior officers, Warren Troupe and Harry Alcock, who will be available during the Q&A.
During this call, we will present our updated 2-year strategic outlook as we have done in the last 3 years. In 2015, we again met or exceeded all primary objectives of our strategic plan and to date have meaningfully outperformed each of our prior plans. Tom will address this outperformance and the next 2-year's strategic outlook in detail later in the call.
Turning to 2015, was another great year for UDR, and we continue to see strength in all aspects of our business. A quick recap of the team's accomplishments during the year.
First, our operations continued to run on all cylinders and delivered strong same-store results across the board, with same-store NOI growth of 6.7%, a full 220 basis points ahead of our initial expectations.
Second, we delivered over $300 million of developments, which leased up well, and we expect to hit our targeted returns of 6.2% or better at stabilization.
Third, we entered into 2 accretive problem-solving transactions, mainly the $559 million West Coast development joint venture and the $901 million Washington, D.C. acquisition, in which we kept to our principles of self-funding, accretive-to-cash-flow growth and continued strengthening of our balance sheet.
Last, we grew AFFO per share by 12%; a strong rate, which resulted in a 7% dividend increase and meaningful consensus NAV per share growth of 15%.
We continue to believe that growth in these 2 metrics translates into strong total shareholder return over time.
Looking towards the future, we feel very positive about our business and our prospects. Multifamily fundamentals remain extraordinarily strong. The positive demographic trends amongst our prime renters, the 22- to 35-year-old population cohort, is expected to grow through 2030 and is not reversible. This, coupled with steady job growth, leaves us confident that our operating platform, which is our primary driver of our cash flow growth, should continue to generate impressive results in the future.
Our self-funded development pipeline is expected to generate the incremental cash flow and value creation we originally forecasted. Expected additions to the pipeline in 2016 will maintain our targeted size at $900 million to $1.4 billion and are forecasted to be highly accretive. Our ability to fund this pipeline with asset sales largely reduces our dependency on capital markets. And as we've said in prior years, we will continue to focus on improving our debt metrics.
In summary, there remains a long runway for growth at UDR, and we have the right plan and team in place to capitalize on the opportunity.
With that, I'd like to express my sincere thanks to all my fellow UDR associates for their hard work and producing another strong year of results. We look forward to a great 2016, and now I will turn the call over to Tom.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Our fourth quarter earnings results were in line with our previously provided guidance. FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share were $0.41, $0.42 and $0.37, respectively. Fourth quarter same-store revenue, expense and NOI growth remained stro
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Our fourth quarter earnings results were in line with our previously provided guidance. FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share were $0.41, $0.42 and $0.37, respectively. Fourth quarter same-store revenue, expense and NOI growth remained strong at 6.2%, 5.2% and 6.6%, respectively.
For full year 2015, FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share were $1.66, $1.67 and $1.51, respectively. Full year same-store revenue, expense and NOI growth of 5.6%, 3.0% and 6.7% exhibited continued strong demand for apartments and were above our initial expectations provided last February.
At year-end, our liquidity, as measured by cash and credit facility capacity, was $987 million. Our financial leverage on an undepreciated cost basis was 34.6%. Based on our current market cap, it was approximately 26%. And inclusive of JVs, it was approximately 30%. Our net debt-to-EBITDA was 5.7x and inclusive of JVs was 6.7x. All balance sheet metric improvements were ahead of plan.
Onto first quarter and full year 2016 guidance. Full year 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share is forecasted at $1.75 to $1.81, $1.75 to $1.81 and $1.59 to $1.65, respectively. For same-store, our full year 2016 revenue growth guidance is 5.5% to 6.0%; expense, 3.0% to 3.5%; and NOI, 6.5% to 7.0%. Average 2016 occupancy is forecasted at 96.6%. Other primary full year guidance assumptions can be found on Attachment 15 or Page 28 of our supplement.
First quarter 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance is $0.42 to $0.44, $0.42 to $0.44 and $0.40 to $0.42, respectively.
Finally, with our release today, we have increased our 2016 annualized dividend to $1.18 per share, a 6% increase from 2015 and represented a yield of approximately 3.25%.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jerry.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. In my remarks I'll cover the following topics: First, our fourth quarter portfolio metrics, leasing trends and the continued success we realized in pushing rental rate growth again this quarter and into January;
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. In my remarks I'll cover the following topics: First, our fourth quarter portfolio metrics, leasing trends and the continued success we realized in pushing rental rate growth again this quarter and into January; second, the performance of our primary markets during the quarter and expectations for 2016; and last, a brief update on our lease-up developments and the Washington, D.C. acquisition.
We're pleased to announce another strong quarter of operating results. Our fourth quarter same-store revenue growth of 6.2% was driven by an increase in revenue per occupied home of 6.5% year-over-year to $1,794 per month, while same-store occupancy of 96.5% was 30 basis points lower versus the prior year period. Our fourth quarter strategy of holding rate high, along with aggressive rate increases throughout 2015, benefits us in 2016 as we entered the year with almost 2.75% of our revenue growth already baked into our rent roll. Our robust full year same-store revenue growth of 5.6% was driven by a 5.5% increase in revenue per occupied home and flat occupancy. We see strong rate growth continuing in 2016.
Turning to new and renewal lease rate growth, which is detailed on Attachment 8G of our supplement, we continue to push rate in the fourth quarter. New lease growth totaled 3.8% or 170 basis points ahead of the fourth quarter of 2014. Renewal growth remained resilient, improving 170 basis points year-over-year to 7%. This year-over-year acceleration was accomplished with only a 40 basis point increase in fourth quarter turnover.
Next, move-outs to home purchase were up 120 basis points year-over-year at 14%, in line with our long-term average. Importantly, our full year 2015 turnover rate increased by just 20 basis points versus full year 2014. Even with renewal increases at a seasonally strong 7% -- only 7% of our move-outs gave rent increase as the reason for leaving in the fourth quarter. However, we expect turnover to increase roughly 100 basis points in 2016, as our revenue growth is highly predicated on the rate growth and not year-over-year occupancy gains.
Moving on to quarterly performance on our primary markets, which represent 69% of our same-store NOI and 75% of our total NOI. Metro D.C., which represents 18% of our total NOI, posted positive full year revenue growth of 1.7%. We expect improving full year revenue growth in 2016 of around 2.5% as we continue to benefit from our diverse exposure of 50% B assets and 50% A assets located both inside and outside the Beltway. 
Orange County and Los Angeles combined represent 15.4% of our total NOI. Orange County posted sequential revenue growth of 160 basis points and continues to outperform our budgeted expectations early in 2016. L.A. is materially stronger due to our heavy concentration in the Marina del Rey submarket as new jobs have continued to migrate to this highly desirable submarket. Fourth quarter revenue growth in L.A. was an impressive 10.2%. Our current expectation is that both of these markets will generate revenue growth in the 7% range in 2016.
New York City, which represents 12% of our total NOI, posted full year revenue growth of 5.6%. We saw a seasonal weakness in the fourth quarter and early January, but future trends are pointing to strength within our submarkets. We continue to expect new jobs from technology, finance and media, which will benefit our lower Manhattan properties. Our 2016 forecasted revenue growth of 6% is above 2015. I would remind everyone that View 34 is in our same-store pool beginning in the first quarter of 2016.
San Francisco and San Jose, which represent 11% of our total NOI, posted full year revenue growth of 9.7%. Although we saw weakness in the fourth quarter, it is indicative of the first and fourth quarter seasonality that we've seen in this market in the past. With that said, we believe this weakness is possibly more than just seasonal and do not expect this market to post the double-digit revenue growth that it has in recent years and we have forecasted a deceleration in 2016 to revenue growth of 8% or so. Future trends are slowly improving from what we saw in the fourth quarter, but we are keeping a close eye on the job growth and absorption levels within our submarkets. Keep in mind, San Francisco job growth has been above 4.5% for the past few years. Axiometrics' current forecast calls for job growth to decelerate to 2.5% to 3% but still well above the national average of 1.75% to 2%.
Seattle, which represents 6% of our total NOI, benefited from strong growth in suburban B assets that are less exposed to new supply than A assets downtown. Although new supply will challenge us somewhat in Downtown Seattle and, to a lesser degree, in Bellevue, we expect 2016 to be slightly below our 2015 numbers or roughly 7% growth.
Boston, which represents 7% of our total NOI, should continue to see new supply pressure downtown, but our suburban assets in the north and south shores should fare relatively better in 2016. Long term, we like the downtown submarket and look to continue to grow through development in this submarket. Most recently GE announced the relocation of their global headquarters to the Seaport district. This will bring another 800 jobs into the submarket, which should directly benefit our 369-home, 100 Pier 4 community and our future 345 Harrison development in Boston's Southend. Our forecast calls for revenue growth to accelerate slightly from the 5.5% growth posted in 2015.
Last, Dallas, which represents 5% of our total NOI, posted 5.1% year-over-year growth in the fourth quarter. We expect new supply pressure in uptown and Plano in 2016. January results indicate that these submarkets are performing slightly better than initial budgeted expectations, and 2016 revenue growth is projected to improve to roughly 5.5% from 5% in 2015.
As you can see on Attachment 7B of our supplement, our 320-home Los Alisos community located in Orange County, our 196-home Waterscape community located in Seattle and our 740-home View 34 community located in New York City will join the same-store pool in the first quarter of 2016.
Turning to our in-lease-up developments. Katella Grand I, our 399-home, $138 million lease-up in Anaheim, California in the West Coast development JV, was 16% occupied at quarter end and as of today is 20% occupied and 27% leased. We are currently offering less than 1 month of concession at this community, and leasing has been very strong in January with 25 applications.
CityLine, our 244-home, $80 million lease-up in Seattle, Washington, was 9% occupied at quarter end. We are on budget and meeting our lease-up expectations.
Finally, 399 Fremont, our 447-home, $318 million lease-up in San Francisco, began leasing during the fourth quarter. At quarter end, we were just 2% leased. And today, we're over 10% leased with rents exceeding pro forma. We will have our first move-ins in March of 2016.
Now a quick update on the Washington, D.C. acquisition. We're 3 months into owning these communities, and everything is going as according to plan. Currently, we're making CapEx improvements at 2 of the properties to either cure deferred maintenance or drive a higher return through revenue-enhancing improvements. And we still expect these communities to perform in line with our D.C. portfolio this year, with revenue growth right around 2.5%. Currently we would expect 5 of the 6 communities in this portfolio to enter our same-store pool in the first quarter of 2017.
With that, I will remind those listening that there's a link to our updated 2-year strategic outlook document on the Investor Relations page of our website. We will pause for a moment so that everyone can gather the 2-year outlook materials.
I will now turn the call back over to Tom Toomey.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jerry, and please turn to Page 3 for some high-level thoughts.First, we view this year's update as a continuation of the last 3 plans. We believe this continues to be the right path for UDR. Here's why. The plan's primary objective is to drive h
componenttext:
Thanks, Jerry, and please turn to Page 3 for some high-level thoughts.
First, we view this year's update as a continuation of the last 3 plans. We believe this continues to be the right path for UDR. Here's why. The plan's primary objective is to drive high-quality cash flow growth while incrementally improving our balance sheet and portfolio. In other words, consistent, sustainable growth that is funded in a safe, low-risk manner. We believe that successful execution of these objectives will drive strong total shareholder return.
There are 4 key points I'd like to highlight why we think there's a long runway of accretive growth ahead.
First, fundamentals. You have seen plenty of published data on this. And clearly, demographics, supply/demand characteristics are in our favor, and any good business that is going to grow for a number of years needs solid fundamentals.
The second is strategic position. Where do we start? Well, we're in 20 markets, 50% A, B quality mix. We like this position. We think it solves for the #1 critical element of any future growth, which is the positioning of our portfolio such that our residents will continue to be able to grow to pay higher rents.
The third is the team and the skills. Operationally, we'll continue to innovate, invest in technology and training programs, all of which are designed to increase our margins, which now stand above 70% at the NOI line, extraordinary for any business. On the development side, we'll remain focused on looking at our risk-adjusted returns and staying disciplined. 
Third is problem solving. Clearly, we operate in a cyclical economy. And along that line, there will be challenges and opportunities. We have a team that is very experienced of managing through these cycles, if not anticipating these cycles and these opportunities. Certainly, I feel confident that the team has the ability to capitalize on these opportunities as they become available. 
And lastly and just as important is managing risk. And we see ourselves managing this through, first, our diversity of our market mix; our discipline around our development; and certainly our continued improving balance sheet set of metrics; and lastly, our transparency in disclosure and communication style.
We believe these main objectives can continue our cash flow growth in optimizing our total shareholder return. We remain fully focused on executing them.
With that, I will turn over to Tom to discuss in detail the updated outlook.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Please turn to Page 4. As Tom mentioned earlier, we have met or exceeded all of our primary financial and operational objectives to date, as set forth in our prior 3-year plans published in 2013, 2014 and 2015. In particular, our same-store growth and dev
componenttext:
Please turn to Page 4. As Tom mentioned earlier, we have met or exceeded all of our primary financial and operational objectives to date, as set forth in our prior 3-year plans published in 2013, 2014 and 2015. In particular, our same-store growth and development deliveries have outperformed over the past 3 years and have served as primary drivers of our better-than-expected cash flow growth and improvements in balance sheet metrics.
Turning to Page 5. Perhaps the most critical driver of UDR's value-creation strategy is our best-in-class operations. We are continuously implementing new revenue growth and cost efficiency initiatives throughout the organization to improve how we do business. As noted on this page, we have consistently produced better overall top line growth versus peers and the U.S. average since the initiation of our 3-year plan in 2013. During this time, we have grown our total revenue per occupied home by 26%, increased occupancy by 100 basis points, reduced turnover by 310 basis points and improved our margins by 220 basis points.
So how will we maintain our operational advantage and how do we intend to keep it in the future? Please turn to Page 6.
Many who listen to this call are familiar with the primary revenue generation, expense control initiatives that are underway. These, along with potential future initiatives, are presented in the table on this page. Importantly, all of our growth and efficiency initiatives have one thing in common: they either provide our customer a wanted service or allow our associates to do their jobs better. Current initiatives should continue to drive our bottom line, and our list of potential future initiatives is extensive.
Please turn to Page 7. This page lists some of our operational projects that have been implemented over the past couple of years and their impact on our NOI. As is evident, we have made solid progress on each initiative to date, and our bottom line has benefited greatly. We will continue to capture additional NOI efficiencies from these initiatives. Operations has been and will continue to be a significant competitive advantage for us. This is not just because of our superior blocking and tackling in the field, but also because of the creativity our operations team employs to continuously improve the business.
Turning now to capital allocation and development on Page 8. Development remains a vital component of our value-creation strategy. While not as many deals [indiscernible] in today's environment, development remains accretive and will continue to be a primary mean through which we continuously improve our portfolio. At year-end, our underway development totaled $670 million, for which the equity requirement was 55% funded. Additionally, our share of the West Coast development joint venture going-in value was $271 million, for which 100% of the equity has been funded. This pipeline is concentrated in our primary coastal markets. Inclusive of the West Coast development JV, we expect to deliver $375 million and $220 million of projects in 2016 and 2017, respectively.
Our annual targeted spend of $400 million to $500 million per year and our targeted trended spread versus cap rates of 150 to 200 basis points have not changed. While construction costs continue to increase, so do rents.
To mitigate market risk around new development projects, we employ the following disciplines: First, prior to a development commencing, we generally seek entitled land, demand full drawings and a GMAX contract, thereby locking in costs and reducing risk. 
Second, we diversify our geographic exposure. Our goal is to commence a new development in a target market as the previous development is leasing up.
Third, we utilize conservative top line growth assumptions to underwrite our projects.
And lastly, we employ a self-funded strategy to fund our development pipeline and reduce dependency on capital markets.
Through our free cash flow and noncore asset sales, we can fully fund our annual development spend. In other words, we are match-funding our risk as we recycle older noncore assets to develop new core assets in our primary markets.
In 2016 and 2017, we will continue to mine our current land bank as well as add new land sites. We are planning 2 to 3 starts in 2016, which include one large wholly owned project, 345 Harrison in Boston; and 1 to 2 smaller 50-50 JVs with MetLife. As of year-end 2015, our shadow pipeline was approximately $900 million at our pro rata ownership and represented $425 million to $475 million of value creation, assuming current spreads. 
Please turn to Page 9.
We anticipate that upon full stabilization, which occurs at different periods for each project, our pipeline of underway and completed developments is expected to generate accretion of $0.07 per share with growth thereafter. On an NAV basis, we expect our pipeline to generate $1.75 per share at stabilization or approximately 35% to 40% value creation over cost.
Page 10 exhibits some of our recent developments.
Please turn to Page 11. As focused as we are on operations and development, maintaining a strong balance sheet along with a self-funded plan are just as important. We exceeded the balance sheet metric goals provided in our 2013, 2014 and 2015 strategic plans. We expect further improvements in 2016 and 2017. This has also been acknowledged by the rating agencies. In 2014, we received a credit upgrade from Moody's to Baa1. And in 2015, we received an upgrade from S&P to BBB+.
On the capital markets front, our 2016 and 2017 capital needs will be funded through a combination of asset sales and new equity and debt, of which we'll utilize the most advantageous source, depending on our strategic objectives, market conditions and pricing at the time the capital is needed.
Please turn to Page 12. In 2015, our AFFO per share growth was a strong 11%. In 2016, AFFO per share growth is expected to average in the 6% to 9% range. This growth will continue to be driven primarily by favorable same-store growth and development earn-in. And these will be partially offset by a few items, including noncore dispositions, higher expected interest rates and 421-a and g property tax impact.
In 2017, AFFO per share growth is expected to be in the 5% to 8% range. This 100 basis point delta is primarily due to lower same-store assumptions. As in our prior strategic plans, we rely on third-party data providers for our future growth expectations in the out-years. And of note, these estimates have proven conservative in the last several years, and our team has been able to outperform.
We expect the business to drive 9% to 11% NAV growth in 2016 and 8% to 10% NAV growth in 2017.
Please turn to Page 13.
This page provides our 2016 guidance, initial 2017 expectations and detailed modeling assumptions. In 2017, we are expecting solid same-store and cash flow growth based on still strong third-party job growth expectations against moderating new multifamily supply growth in our markets. In addition, our expected asset sales and entrants to our same-store pool in 2016 and 2017 will enhance our same-store mix toward higher growth markets.
And finally, Page 14. Our 2016 top line growth assumptions for our markets are presented on the map. We expect the West Coast and Southeast to grow at a rate above the portfolio average. The Mid-Atlantic will continue to perform below the portfolio average but will improve slightly and still expect to outperform relative to our peers due to our 50-50 mix of As and Bs in D.C. and less direct exposure to new supply inside the Beltway.
With that I will turn and open the Q&A. Operator?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Nick Joseph of Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Nick Joseph of Citigroup.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering what the 2-year plan assumes for the broader macroeconomic environment and if it bakes in any sort of recession over the next 24 months.
componenttext: I'm just wondering what the 2-year plan assumes for the broader macroeconomic environment and if it bakes in any sort of recession over the next 24 months.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Nick, this is Jerry. We really look at the Axio and Moody's data to start with. What they're forecasting is continuation of job growth, not too far off from what it was in 2015, call it a little over 200,000 per month. Supply is going to impact us thi
componenttext: No. Nick, this is Jerry. We really look at the Axio and Moody's data to start with. What they're forecasting is continuation of job growth, not too far off from what it was in 2015, call it a little over 200,000 per month. Supply is going to impact us this year, probably a little more than it did last year. And then in '17, there's a drop-off. So we look at the macro data. And then we start looking at specific submarkets where we operate and take into account how directly we're going to be affected by that. In addition, when you really go through it -- so there's a few other things to consider. We will continue to spend about $35 million to probably low to $40 million in revenue-enhancing improvements to our properties. So it will add probably between 50 and 25 basis points into 2017 and probably about that much in 2016. And as we look further out into 2017, there's probably only a couple of markets that look to us like they would be decelerating from the growth rates that we anticipate in 2016. Those are Northern California, Seattle for the most part. And then we see some that we think are going to be improving, and that would be the Mid-Atlantic. We also see Boston most likely improving for us. And then the rest of our portfolio, whether it's SoCal or the Sunbelt, we would expect to be modestly down. And when you blend all that together, it takes you from our midpoint this year of about a  5 7 5 growth down to that 5. [ph] So again, we don't really anticipate a recession. We don't claim to be economists. We subscribe to what they say, but that's how we're looking at the business.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you're clearly benefiting from strong operating trends and the developments delivering ahead of expectations, but I'm a little surprised that your expected 2016 core FFO growth isn't higher given the expected same-store NOI growth, the benefit fr
componenttext: And then you're clearly benefiting from strong operating trends and the developments delivering ahead of expectations, but I'm a little surprised that your expected 2016 core FFO growth isn't higher given the expected same-store NOI growth, the benefit from the 2 accretive 2015 transactions and the benefit of leverage. So can you walk through what is driving expected core FFO growth that's actually below expected same-store NOI growth for 2016?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Nick. It's Tom Herzog. Yes, to your point, the same-store comes in with a $0.12 positive number. Development comes in at $0.02, which is lower than what we had in 2015, and that's purely due to timing on what got delivered. In 2015, you had Cha
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Nick. It's Tom Herzog. Yes, to your point, the same-store comes in with a $0.12 positive number. Development comes in at $0.02, which is lower than what we had in 2015, and that's purely due to timing on what got delivered. In 2015, you had Channel, View 34, 27 Seventy Five. 2016, you're looking at Pier 4, Beach & Ocean. But you've got some drag from 399, Pac City, Jamboree, 3033 and Domain Mountain View. All great projects, but at this point, there's some drag. So that lowered the development by a bit from what we had seen in 2015. As to some of the items that would have leaned against the FFO growth relative to the NOI, it would have been -- floating interest rates are up about 40 basis points. In our model, that's $0.01. The average revolver balance is going to be down some, call it $150 million or so. That's $0.015, and that was just due to the timing of that mid-September debt issuance. The tax benefit goes from $3.9 million to $1.5 million. That's $0.01. Non-1031 exchanges picks up another $0.01. And then to your point earlier, that is partially offset by the accretive West Coast JV and some accretion on the home transaction, and those are all the moving parts. So this is -- as we would have expected, our core and base growth going forward is just as strong, but we just had a few items that caused FFO to come in a little bit lower relative to the same-store.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jana Galan of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jana Galan of Bank of America.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, I was wondering if you could expand upon the comments you had made earlier on the fourth quarter softness in San Francisco and San Jose that -- what you're seeing that could mean that it could be more than just seasonal?
componenttext: Jerry, I was wondering if you could expand upon the comments you had made earlier on the fourth quarter softness in San Francisco and San Jose that -- what you're seeing that could mean that it could be more than just seasonal?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's hard to tell at this point, Jana. We did see or had some occupancy and pricing power hit pressures in the fourth quarter. But as we've rolled into January, we've started to see signs of improvement. New lease rate growth in the fourth quarter wa
componenttext: Yes. It's hard to tell at this point, Jana. We did see or had some occupancy and pricing power hit pressures in the fourth quarter. But as we've rolled into January, we've started to see signs of improvement. New lease rate growth in the fourth quarter was 5.2%. Renewal growth was 9.3%. As we look at January, our January new leases are up 4.2% in San Francisco, San Jose, and that compares to 3.3% in December. So it is improving. And our January renewals are still well above 8% at 8.4%. Our occupancy is at 97%. So it has strengthened. Now as we look at job growth, which is the primary concern in those markets right now, it's been running about 4.5% for the past couple of years. And when we have talked to Axiometrics, they're forecasting for job growth to decelerate to 2.5% to 3%. And while that's about 150 to 200 basis point deceleration, it's still well above the national average of job growth of 1.75% to 2%. So we'd like to think it's all seasonal. We're going to know in the next 60 days if it is. And over the last 3 to 5 years, there's probably been 2 or 3x in the first quarter when I grew concerned about the strength in San Francisco, only to see things turn around as we got into the month of March and April. So it's just a little bit early to tell. But on the ground, we're not seeing any significant job loss from any single employers. And as I've said, as we've come out of the fourth quarter and entered the first quarter, we have seen fundamentals start to strengthen again.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the operational initiative, very impressive to get to your 70% NOI margins. I guess, how much room is left in terms of reducing days vacant or maintenance staff efficiencies?
componenttext: And on the operational initiative, very impressive to get to your 70% NOI margins. I guess, how much room is left in terms of reducing days vacant or maintenance staff efficiencies?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think days vacant, we've gone from about 26 days to 20. We're not going to get it -- be able to get it much lower, I don't think. Call it maybe another 2 days, but we've been chopping 1 day, 1.5 days off each of the last 3 to 4 years. It's starting
componenttext: Yes. I think days vacant, we've gone from about 26 days to 20. We're not going to get it -- be able to get it much lower, I don't think. Call it maybe another 2 days, but we've been chopping 1 day, 1.5 days off each of the last 3 to 4 years. It's starting to slow a bit. The only thing you can do to reduce it quicker is to cut rate. That's how you can really move apartment homes. And we're more focused on driving rate. So we'll let that vacant day stay about where it is. On the staffing efficiency, I think we can continue to drive that metric even better. There's a few things technologically. We're working with our property management software provider to help us go to the next step on. But I would tell you, as we created our expense budgets for 2016, we do have our repairs and maintenance coming in at flat. Once again, this is probably going to be the third or fourth straight year that it's been negative to positive -- either negative or up 1%. So we've kept that in pretty good control, while we've been able to achieve turnover that remained flat. So we use those guides at times not just to push price down, but to enhance service which helps us maintain a steady turnover.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ian Weissman of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ian Weissman of Credit Suisse.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys put out, I guess, guidance for the year about -- budgeted spend of $550 million to $700 million combination of debt, equity and sale proceeds, I think, for the balance of this year. Maybe you could just talk about the attractiveness of each in th
componenttext: You guys put out, I guess, guidance for the year about -- budgeted spend of $550 million to $700 million combination of debt, equity and sale proceeds, I think, for the balance of this year. Maybe you could just talk about the attractiveness of each in this environment as we sit here today.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ian, it's Herzog here again. I think about it this way. If we're looking at debt, let's just start there. Typically, we're going to use unsecured debt to refinance debt that's maturing. And that might be coming in at, call it, 4.2, 4.3 range. In our model
componenttext: Ian, it's Herzog here again. I think about it this way. If we're looking at debt, let's just start there. Typically, we're going to use unsecured debt to refinance debt that's maturing. And that might be coming in at, call it, 4.2, 4.3 range. In our model, it'd be cheaper right now. But I think of debt in terms of that type of a cost on unsecured basis, that's on a 10 year. Let's go to equity. Equity, I'm going to look at an AFFO yield on a current year basis and just based off of AFFO projected toward at the midpoint today's share price, that comes in at about a 4.5% current. Of course, we're going to add growth to that so I have to look at it in a cost of equity basis, and that's probably going to be somewhere just shy of probably 8% or something like that on a cost of equity basis. And then you move to sales of assets, and again on our current yield, it depends on what cap rate of assets that we're selling. I think our sales for 2015 came in at a 5.8% cap rate. Harry, is that correct?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: 5.8%. But again it depends on the mix of what we're selling and as we think about how we fund our business, the debt maturities, which are rather modest over the next couple of years, probably comes from refinancing of debt. When you think about the devel
componenttext: 5.8%. But again it depends on the mix of what we're selling and as we think about how we fund our business, the debt maturities, which are rather modest over the next couple of years, probably comes from refinancing of debt. When you think about the development spend, call the development spend $500 million including redev, including land, we can fully self-fund that, as I said on my scripted remarks, through our free cash flow, through our 1031 exchanges on land and on a portion of our development spend, with the balance funded through sales and gain capacity at about $125 million, $130 million. So if we choose to we can fund the entire development spend on a self-funded basis and our debt maturities through refis. In the meantime, we have $1 billion of capacity right now on our revolver and cash. So again, back to the point of our business being quite self-funded. But when we look at each decision as it comes to pass during the year against these various forms of capital, those are the different decisions that we -- those are the different data points that we look at when we make a decision on how we fund the activities.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the question though in terms of asset sales today, if you just think about the window of opportunity, do you think that window has changed in this environment?
componenttext: I guess the question though in terms of asset sales today, if you just think about the window of opportunity, do you think that window has changed in this environment?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harry, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Harry, do you want to take that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Harry. So for asset sales, right now they're still at a tremendous amount of capital chasing assets -- A assets, B assets. Cap rates are very favorable, capital is readily available to acquire these assets. But we don't see that changing any
componenttext: Sure. This is Harry. So for asset sales, right now they're still at a tremendous amount of capital chasing assets -- A assets, B assets. Cap rates are very favorable, capital is readily available to acquire these assets. But we don't see that changing anytime soon. Debt remains readily available. Cash flows continue to grow. And we're seeing investors not just pension funds, but also sovereign wealth funds, FIRPTA. Changes potentially have opened up additional investment in U.S. real estate to foreign entities. So at this point, the disposition market continues to be very liquid.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just lastly, just to clarify your $500 million of development spend, what does that imply for starts this year, did I miss that?
componenttext: That's helpful. And just lastly, just to clarify your $500 million of development spend, what does that imply for starts this year, did I miss that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're going to have 2 to 3 starts this year, 345 Harrison in Boston and then 1 to 2 other JV starts with MetLife.
componenttext: Yes, we're going to have 2 to 3 starts this year, 345 Harrison in Boston and then 1 to 2 other JV starts with MetLife.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ian, just to -- in terms of dollars, that'll be somewhere in the neighborhood of $350 million to $450 million, which is very consistent with our starts every year since 2011.
componenttext: So Ian, just to -- in terms of dollars, that'll be somewhere in the neighborhood of $350 million to $450 million, which is very consistent with our starts every year since 2011.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jordan Sadler of KeyBanc.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here. I was just curious, given the continued focus on driving rate in 2016, does the 27 outlook assume a similar level of revenue, I guess, as earned in headed into 2017 as you entered 2016?
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here. I was just curious, given the continued focus on driving rate in 2016, does the 27 outlook assume a similar level of revenue, I guess, as earned in headed into 2017 as you entered 2016?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Austin, this is Jerry. I would expect it to be a little bit less. We do not anticipate, as you get to the back half of this year, to have quite as much ability to drive new lease rate or renewal rate. Our expectation -- we did our budgets was that mar
componenttext: No. Austin, this is Jerry. I would expect it to be a little bit less. We do not anticipate, as you get to the back half of this year, to have quite as much ability to drive new lease rate or renewal rate. Our expectation -- we did our budgets was that market conditions would be a little bit weaker across the board. Well, not across the board but in aggregate. Call it 70, 80 basis points. So if I had to guess right now what I think we would go into next year with, instead of being in the 2.75%, it's probably going to be somewhere closer to the 2.40%, 2.50% in order to get that deceleration from midpoint to midpoint of about 75 basis points.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then I was just curious, Jerry, what -- you mentioned New York kind of strengthening as you look out a little bit. And could you just give some color on where you're sending out renewal lease rates for New York.
componenttext: That's helpful. And then I was just curious, Jerry, what -- you mentioned New York kind of strengthening as you look out a little bit. And could you just give some color on where you're sending out renewal lease rates for New York.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Right now, they're going out between 6% and 7%, January, probably in that 6% -- well, that's what we achieved in January. As you look out over the next 2 months, it's probably a hair less, call it 6% to 7% but we are seeing strength -- I won't
componenttext: Absolutely. Right now, they're going out between 6% and 7%, January, probably in that 6% -- well, that's what we achieved in January. As you look out over the next 2 months, it's probably a hair less, call it 6% to 7% but we are seeing strength -- I won't say strength, we're seeing a stable environment in our New York portfolio. You know I would add our occupancy today in New York is at 97%. When you look at New York, we're in 3 submarkets, we're in Chelsea. We have 2  -- or 3 submarkets. We have 2 down in the Financial District, we have 1 in Murray Hill and then we have our last 1, which is a Met JV, is in the Upper West Side. The Upper West Side is definitely the weakest of the group, where in fourth quarter we had revenue growth of about 1%. When you look at the other 3 that were on our same-store pool which is the 2 downtown, as well as Chelsea, revenue growth was 5.5% to 6%. So we're not seeing supply issues anywhere except the Upper West Side. You're not really seeing affordability to a great extent right now and you're not -- we're also not seeing job loss anywhere.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's helpful. I mean on a -- from a demand perspective, I guess you mentioned you're not seeing any job loss. But as you look out, I mean do you think if job growth were to slow that some of the demographic trends in New York, do you think could tha
componenttext: No, that's helpful. I mean on a -- from a demand perspective, I guess you mentioned you're not seeing any job loss. But as you look out, I mean do you think if job growth were to slow that some of the demographic trends in New York, do you think could that be enough to backfill the demand given the supply that we're seeing in New York?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do, because a lot of our portfolio is B, with the exception of probably our Chelsea property is also Upper West Side, our Murray Hill and our 2 downtown properties really do cater to that B renter. And I think people can trade down if they wanted to fro
componenttext: I do, because a lot of our portfolio is B, with the exception of probably our Chelsea property is also Upper West Side, our Murray Hill and our 2 downtown properties really do cater to that B renter. And I think people can trade down if they wanted to from the As to come to us. And several of our floor plans, especially over at View 34 are very large so if people did feel the squeeze and had to double up, I think that would be an alternative, too.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nick Yulico of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nick Yulico of UBS.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going to that attachment 7(D) where you breakout all the projects being added to the same-store this year, it looks like it's almost 1,600 units and you had about 35,000 in your same stores, so you're adding about something like 5% units. Can we get
componenttext: Just going to that attachment 7(D) where you breakout all the projects being added to the same-store this year, it looks like it's almost 1,600 units and you had about 35,000 in your same stores, so you're adding about something like 5% units. Can we get a feel for what the revenue growth assumption is for these assets that are being added to your same-store to figure out how much of a benefit to your overall same-store it is?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd probably just cut to the chase and tell you what the benefit is to my same-store. It's about 20 basis points. It's predominantly coming from View 34 and these other 2 but -- and just to give you a little indication, our New York, which when Herzog was
componenttext: I'd probably just cut to the chase and tell you what the benefit is to my same-store. It's about 20 basis points. It's predominantly coming from View 34 and these other 2 but -- and just to give you a little indication, our New York, which when Herzog was going through the 2-year outlook, we had said New York revenue was going to come in really in that -- within our midpoint, 5.5% to 6%. It's much closer to 6% than 5.5%. But View 34 was adding roughly 80 basis points to New York, so without that one I would have been in the low 5s. But again, when you look at the components of each one of these that's going into the full year this year, call it 20 basis points. So without those, I would have been, I guess 5% to 5.6%.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then as far as -- maybe this one's for Tom Toomey, as far as your -- if you think about the class B piece of your portfolio and maybe it's in some markets, Orlando or other places, how are you sort of weighing keeping that as kin
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then as far as -- maybe this one's for Tom Toomey, as far as your -- if you think about the class B piece of your portfolio and maybe it's in some markets, Orlando or other places, how are you sort of weighing keeping that as kind of a hedge against new supply, and assets have done quite well versus all the talk coming out of NMHC which was at redevelopment value add, if you could sell those properties to people today you're getting sort of the most aggressive pricing the market's ever seen

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess I look at it this way; through cycles, Bs tend to hold up very well. And when you find markets that -- we look at income, to the ability for the resident to pay, to our ability to continue to push rent increases through to them -- the Bs pro
componenttext: Well, I guess I look at it this way; through cycles, Bs tend to hold up very well. And when you find markets that -- we look at income, to the ability for the resident to pay, to our ability to continue to push rent increases through to them -- the Bs probably have a bigger bandwidth in our mind to absorb it. And then on the downside, they're probably insulated more than the As. So I'm always drawn to kind of a good, solid B in a great location as a good long-term cash flow driving machine. And so we'll probably always have a good mix of Bs in the portfolio, and we'll solve, really, for our ability to grow cash flow over time.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as far as Bs go, I mean what percentage of your portfolio you think is class B at this point?
componenttext: And as far as Bs go, I mean what percentage of your portfolio you think is class B at this point?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think it's about 50-50 right now between A and B. And over time, those As will turn into Bs and we'll have to continue to reload at the top end. But we'll always probably be a company that will have that balance of 50-50.
componenttext: We think it's about 50-50 right now between A and B. And over time, those As will turn into Bs and we'll have to continue to reload at the top end. But we'll always probably be a company that will have that balance of 50-50.
