componenttext: With regards to CapEx, can you let us know what percent of NOI you're expecting to spend in '16 for both recurring and nonrecurring?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry -- just as far as what the CapEx numbers are? I can give you those real quick. The CapEx per door on the recurring is at $1,100 a door. For revenue enhancing, it's about $550 a door. And then for K&Bs, whatever that number would be, we plan to s
componenttext: I'm sorry -- just as far as what the CapEx numbers are? I can give you those real quick. The CapEx per door on the recurring is at $1,100 a door. For revenue enhancing, it's about $550 a door. And then for K&Bs, whatever that number would be, we plan to spend about $15 million in total, so you could do the quick door calc on that. I don't know that I answered your question but...

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, this actually -- the question I think came up from a call earlier today when one of our competitors was talking about looking at CapEx as a percentage of revenue rather than on a per door basis. I don't think we have that number off the top of our hea
componenttext: No, this actually -- the question I think came up from a call earlier today when one of our competitors was talking about looking at CapEx as a percentage of revenue rather than on a per door basis. I don't think we have that number off the top of our head, but it's fairly easy for us to calculate and get back to you with.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Second question, past few quarters you've suggested the increased to G&A guidance has largely been due to higher than expected incentive program payouts from outperforming targets. It looks like G&A ended up 15% higher than initial guidance, so can
componenttext: Great. Second question, past few quarters you've suggested the increased to G&A guidance has largely been due to higher than expected incentive program payouts from outperforming targets. It looks like G&A ended up 15% higher than initial guidance, so can you just give us a little color on what specific metrics were hit that drove the $8 million overrun?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When you look at G&A there were a number of different -- by the way, you're right, yes, it was STI and was LTI that drove the higher G&A. Our metrics center around things like same-store, development spreads, balance sheet metrics, TSR. And then on t
componenttext: Yes. When you look at G&A there were a number of different -- by the way, you're right, yes, it was STI and was LTI that drove the higher G&A. Our metrics center around things like same-store, development spreads, balance sheet metrics, TSR. And then on top of that, we had a couple of major transactions that were very good for our business including the West Coast development JV, the Home transaction, the Washington, D.C. acquisition. And so we hit on all of our metrics in 2015 without exception and it did result in to the metrics that we had set forth higher than average LTI payouts and STI payouts. One of the thing I would have you note though that might get missed is that we have the transitional plan in place moving from the old LTI program to the new -- or we now have a 3-year cliff vest on the TSR portion and we didn't use to have that. So the transitional piece is about $3.5 million of that $10 million variance. So just keep that in mind.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Toomey. I'd just tell you, '15, we hit everything right out of the ballpark from ops to transactions to the financing of the company to the TSR. And so I'm grateful that we're at that performance and happy as hell to pay out bonuses across,
componenttext: John, this is Toomey. I'd just tell you, '15, we hit everything right out of the ballpark from ops to transactions to the financing of the company to the TSR. And so I'm grateful that we're at that performance and happy as hell to pay out bonuses across, up and down the entire organization, and we'd like to do it again, frankly. And if we hit all those metrics and perform at that level again, we will be paying at that level.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few quick questions here. First, on the -- what slide is this? Slide 7, Jerry, where you guys talked about the benefit of reducing the downtime, the days vacant. And then you also talk about going back and resuscitating old leads both as increasing
componenttext: Just a few quick questions here. First, on the -- what slide is this? Slide 7, Jerry, where you guys talked about the benefit of reducing the downtime, the days vacant. And then you also talk about going back and resuscitating old leads both as increasing NOI. It would seem like resuscitating old leads would sort of cut down on vacancy. So are the 2 NOI impacts -- are any -- that would seem to be overlapping. Are they 2 distinct NOI benefits or you're just citing the difference of different initiatives but in aggregate, it's -- you wouldn't add those 2 together?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's probably a bit of overlap, you're right. Part of what helps us fill vacant units faster is going back after lost leads. So there probably is a hair bit of duplicity in there. What we're really looking for is, again, on the resurrection of dis
componenttext: Yes, there's probably a bit of overlap, you're right. Part of what helps us fill vacant units faster is going back after lost leads. So there probably is a hair bit of duplicity in there. What we're really looking for is, again, on the resurrection of discarded leads is trying to help out our site associates that at times don't have enough time to do adequate follow-up. So yes, there's probably a little bit of that, that could be occurring.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what else is driving, apart from resuscitating old leads, what else drives reducing the downtime of the units? I mean, it takes a certain amount of time to clean the unit, there's regular marketing traffic which you guys are pretty good at. So what els
componenttext: So what else is driving, apart from resuscitating old leads, what else drives reducing the downtime of the units? I mean, it takes a certain amount of time to clean the unit, there's regular marketing traffic which you guys are pretty good at. So what else goes in to cutting down that downtime on the unit?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a multitude of things. One, we spread the lease expirations throughout the month instead of having them all occur at the same time. Some -- it's much easier just to say leases expire at the end of the month, but when you do that, you have 30 people m
componenttext: It's a multitude of things. One, we spread the lease expirations throughout the month instead of having them all occur at the same time. Some -- it's much easier just to say leases expire at the end of the month, but when you do that, you have 30 people move out at a 600-unit property. Your maintenance team can't get to the 30th apartment to turn it until day 22. By spreading it throughout the month, you're able to do a little bit better. The other things you do is you try to entice people to push up their move-in date. If you know an apartment is going to be market-ready on the 26th of the month and somebody comes in and says, "Hey, I want to move in at the end of the month or the beginning of the month." You basically tell them when they will be moving in. So you push them closer to the 26 instead of automatically just putting them in as they move in on the 30th and that could cut off 3 days. So some of it's strategic, some of it is putting in more demanding metrics on our maintenance team for expectations of when apartments need to be turned. Old-school way of doing it, you wouldn't go turn a unit until it was leased. The way we try to do it is turn it as quickly as you can from when somebody moves out so you have ready inventory. But those are probably the major factors.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then sticking with you, Jerry. You made the comments earlier on San Francisco and too early to tell if it was just sort of the year-end softness versus there's something nefarious happening in the job market there. But just curio
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then sticking with you, Jerry. You made the comments earlier on San Francisco and too early to tell if it was just sort of the year-end softness versus there's something nefarious happening in the job market there. But just curious, given your other tech-market exposure like in Seattle and maybe Boston as well, do you get a sense that there's linkage so that if there were a slowdown of tech, let's say in San Francisco, your team in Seattle or Boston or other tech-oriented markets would feel it or the view is that a number of these -- what could be happening at a local doesn't necessarily happen at -- in the other tech-related markets?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't think it happens quite as much. There's more start-up activity honestly in the Bay Area. So if funding for unicorns and the other tech startups slows, I don't think it has as much of an effect in places like Seattle. Down in LA where Silicon B
componenttext: No. I don't think it happens quite as much. There's more start-up activity honestly in the Bay Area. So if funding for unicorns and the other tech startups slows, I don't think it has as much of an effect in places like Seattle. Down in LA where Silicon Beach is becoming really a tech hub or out in Boston, those are typically more established organizations that aren't dependent on financing.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the point is you're not seeing any softness in any of those other 3 markets you just cited?
componenttext: Okay. And the point is you're not seeing any softness in any of those other 3 markets you just cited?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're actually seeing strength in all 3 of those other markets.
componenttext: No, we're actually seeing strength in all 3 of those other markets.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rob Stevenson of Janney.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rob Stevenson of Janney.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, either in terms of what you've been seeing in the third or fourth quarters or what's your -- what's baked into your 2016 guidance. Is there any real bifurcation between the various D.C. submarkets these days, operating performance-wise?
componenttext: Jerry, either in terms of what you've been seeing in the third or fourth quarters or what's your -- what's baked into your 2016 guidance. Is there any real bifurcation between the various D.C. submarkets these days, operating performance-wise?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think your Bs are still continuing to outperform. They have -- it's compressed at times, then it'll widen, but our B product outside the Beltway continues to carry us versus our inside the Beltway. When I look at our As, they're currently coming in
componenttext: Yes. I think your Bs are still continuing to outperform. They have -- it's compressed at times, then it'll widen, but our B product outside the Beltway continues to carry us versus our inside the Beltway. When I look at our As, they're currently coming in probably close to -- our A urban had revenue growth in the fourth quarter of about 1% and our Bs which are predominantly in the suburbs came in about 2%. So on a revenue growth basis, call it 100 basis points.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Tom Herzog or Jerry, I mean, when I think about turnover for you guys, I mean turnover ratcheted up modestly year-over-year to 52%. How should we be thinking about the impact of 100 or 200 basis points of turnover in terms of the bottom lin
componenttext: Okay. And then Tom Herzog or Jerry, I mean, when I think about turnover for you guys, I mean turnover ratcheted up modestly year-over-year to 52%. How should we be thinking about the impact of 100 or 200 basis points of turnover in terms of the bottom line? What does that represent penny-wise for you guys if turnover goes up 100 basis points in 2016 over what you're expecting?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really depends on what you're getting for rate growth. If I'm pushing renewals at 8% and my turnover goes up 100 basis points, it's probably positive to my bottom line and it also depends on how quickly I can reload. I don't have the exact number off t
componenttext: It really depends on what you're getting for rate growth. If I'm pushing renewals at 8% and my turnover goes up 100 basis points, it's probably positive to my bottom line and it also depends on how quickly I can reload. I don't have the exact number off the top of my head. I will tell you my expectation this year for '16 is my turnover's going to go up about 100 basis points because we're going to continue to try to drive rate. So I don't think you're going to see it continue to come down. We're not seeing an increase in move-outs to homeownership. We're not seeing it for money problems. The one metric that is tending to migrate up a little bit is move-outs due to rent increase but it still has not got into a level that I see is pushing an inordinate number of people out the door. And if you look at that schedule that's in our supp,  which shows the turnover metrics comparing this year to last year -- it's attachment 8(G) -- there's really only one market where you see a significant increase and that's our Monterey County, which went probably from 49% to almost 57%. That's also a market where we had revenue growth this past year in the low to mid-teens, so we would do it all again. In places like San Francisco and areas like that, it's going up 100, 150 bps and I'll take that too as long as I'm getting renewal growth that's approaching double-digit.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the real estate tax side, what's the impact from 421-b expirations and what's the overall assumption for real estate tax growth in '16?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the real estate tax side, what's the impact from 421-b expirations and what's the overall assumption for real estate tax growth in '16?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll give you the second part and Herzog's going to talk more 421s. Overall this next year, our expectation is real estate taxes are going to go up in that probably 7% range. Now, that sounds like a huge number. This past year, our real estate tax expense
componenttext: I'll give you the second part and Herzog's going to talk more 421s. Overall this next year, our expectation is real estate taxes are going to go up in that probably 7% range. Now, that sounds like a huge number. This past year, our real estate tax expense we thought was going to come in 5.5% to 6%, and it actually came in right around 3%. We benefited dramatically from appeal wins. It's probably pushing close to $1.8 million to $2 million that brought us down almost 200 basis points. When we factor in and budget for real estate tax growth, we do not expect or build in any refund. So again, it's going to be roughly up at that 7% range is what we're showing today. And a chunk of that, as Herzog will tell you in a minute, is due to the 421s. Tom?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jerry. From a same-store perspective, Rob, the 2016 same-store expenses, as a company we would expect that to be impact of about 45 basis points. And in 2017, about 70 basis points. I will mention that on schedule -- in the schedule 8 series of our s
componenttext: Yes, Jerry. From a same-store perspective, Rob, the 2016 same-store expenses, as a company we would expect that to be impact of about 45 basis points. And in 2017, about 70 basis points. I will mention that on schedule -- in the schedule 8 series of our supp, we do footnote for the total portfolio and for New York specifically, the impacts on same-store expense and same-store NOI, so that you can see it with and without. And from an AFFO perspective in 2016, it's about $670,000 roughly just from the burn off of the abatements and whatnot. And in 2017, it'd be about $1.3 million. That's what's built [indiscernible] right now.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Oppenheim of Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Oppenheim of Zelman & Associates.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit in terms of the 2016 expectations. Where you see the sort of greater risk? If you think about the revenue side potentially here in the Bay Area where we certainly seen some of the deceleration as of late but th
componenttext: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit in terms of the 2016 expectations. Where you see the sort of greater risk? If you think about the revenue side potentially here in the Bay Area where we certainly seen some of the deceleration as of late but then also on the expense side talking about R&M being flat or sort of personnel which probably have to come down from where they have been lately or in the tax side, how do you think about sort of weighing the risks as you go through 2016?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with that, this is Jerry. I see little risk on the expense side. Again, we have expenses budgeted at 3.75%. When you have a margin like us, what really moves the business most is the revenue. I already told you what we have in our model current
componenttext: I'll start with that, this is Jerry. I see little risk on the expense side. Again, we have expenses budgeted at 3.75%. When you have a margin like us, what really moves the business most is the revenue. I already told you what we have in our model currently for real estate tax is at 7%. It really doesn't have refunds calculated in, and I'm confident we're going to get some of those. The other expense categories we're looking at and then we built in the second largest component of our expense stack is personnel, which is about 1/4 of our total expenses. We expect that to go up to 24.25% higher than it has the last several years as we have more competitive pressures to attract and retain our associates. All of the other categories -- marketing we expect to go down. Our marketing team's done a great job both with our website, as well as working with the ISLs to -- or ILSs to bring down our cost. Repairs and maintenance, I don't see that going up dramatically. I think we have that locked down pretty well. So on the expense side, I think it's not overly risky. The revenue side, there's always risk and probably the 2 markets that we're keeping our eyes on the most would be San Francisco because we hear all that same information you guys hear. New York, we're watching that closely too and as I've said earlier about both of those markets, they both today, it's not apparent to us whether it's seasonal issues that created weakness in the fourth quarter because we're starting to strengthen if it's something more. But as I look at it there's really 3 markets that today you would say are kind of risky, and it'd be those 2, as well as Austin. But what I would also say is those constitute 25% of UDR's total NOI. When you look at all of the other markets combined, which make up 75%, we see strength. We see strength in Southern California, the entire Sunbelt with the exception of Austin is extremely strong today. D.C., while it's still going to be a laggard by comparison, it's improving and we think Boston's improving. So while there may be risk in a market or 2, the benefit of having a geographically dispersed and asset class differentiation between the As and Bs, I think, give us pretty good protection.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line Rich Anderson of Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line Rich Anderson of Mizuho Securities.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have one question because, I guess, everything else is perfect. But on the debt, the 5.7 debt to EBITDA today going to maybe as low as 5 in 2017 looks so great, but then when your wrap in the joint venture impact 100 basis point up now and it kind
componenttext: I just have one question because, I guess, everything else is perfect. But on the debt, the 5.7 debt to EBITDA today going to maybe as low as 5 in 2017 looks so great, but then when your wrap in the joint venture impact 100 basis point up now and it kind of muddies it a little bit maybe significantly in the eyes of some people. I'm just curious what you think about that in terms of managing your leverage at the joint venture level so that the full leverage story looks better than what it appears at this point.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, that's a fair question. This is Toomey. I think your math is about right. And as we think about the joint venture, what maybe the Street doesn't always look through to is the strength of our partner in MetLife, and their position and strength.
componenttext: Yes, Rich, that's a fair question. This is Toomey. I think your math is about right. And as we think about the joint venture, what maybe the Street doesn't always look through to is the strength of our partner in MetLife, and their position and strength. And so they're very comfortable running these development joint ventures. And then when they're completed, they'll finance them out at 40% to 50% leverage, which would be high for UDR as a corporate entity. But we're comfortable with them as a partner financing around that level, and feel that they're there for a long period of time. And we'll perform if necessary and have shown a track record of doing so through many cycles.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So will the -- it'll be the same 100 basis point impact 2 years from now, you think?
componenttext: Okay. So will the -- it'll be the same 100 basis point impact 2 years from now, you think?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would put it at that.
componenttext: I would put it at that.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair. The way it looks organically right now, I would -- everything Tom said, I obviously agree with as well. One of the things you have to take into account is that when you look back at what's taken place in the company over the last numb
componenttext: I think that's fair. The way it looks organically right now, I would -- everything Tom said, I obviously agree with as well. One of the things you have to take into account is that when you look back at what's taken place in the company over the last number of years we have dramatically reduced leverage. But over the last few years it's been purely or substantially organically. And so you've got the organic improvements that will occur, but also as we had an opportunity to do a Home or a West Coast development JV, if we were trading at a place where we could issue stock at a premium, that does give us an opportunity to further delever the enterprise by acquiring assets on an accretive basis at a premium and that lowers the leverage of the enterprise. The other thing I'd mention is when we look at our current leverage levels with the rating agencies and we have -- had studies done by 3 different banks as to where we're rated at the BBB+, Baa1 and what the sweet spot has been determined is at the leverage level that we're at, at the BBB+, Baa1. So to go through unnatural means to further improve that leverage and do so on a diluted basis is not something that's all that enticing as we think we can continue to improve it over time in the ways that I just described.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Kim of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Kim of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on your reduced acquisition guidance compared to last year's. I realized this is really just for modeling purposes. But has your risk appetite changed? And also can you provide some color on the volume and characteristics of potential dea
componenttext: I had a question on your reduced acquisition guidance compared to last year's. I realized this is really just for modeling purposes. But has your risk appetite changed? And also can you provide some color on the volume and characteristics of potential deal flow compared to maybe a few months ago?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John, this is Harry. I think we view acquisitions primarily as opportunity based, and so the significant acquisition we had last year, which was the home acquisition, really we were able to solve a problem in that we had a currency that was required
componenttext: Sure, John, this is Harry. I think we view acquisitions primarily as opportunity based, and so the significant acquisition we had last year, which was the home acquisition, really we were able to solve a problem in that we had a currency that was required in order to get that deal done. As we look forward again, if something like that came up we certainly would take a look at it. But as we started last year, we don't have any expectations that that's going to materialize again. If it does, we'll certainly take a look at it, but we don't have any reason to expect that, that will reoccur.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what about your risk appetite?
componenttext: And what about your risk appetite?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, again, our risk appetite has remained unchanged. And you also asked about deal flow, I mean there are tremendous amounts of deals in the market today. You saw last year was nearly $140 billion in transactions across the multifamily space which was a r
componenttext: So, again, our risk appetite has remained unchanged. And you also asked about deal flow, I mean there are tremendous amounts of deals in the market today. You saw last year was nearly $140 billion in transactions across the multifamily space which was a record year. And NAREIT a couple of weeks -- or at NMHC a couple of weeks ago, the broker community is indicating that they're actually ahead this year where they were last year, so we expect there to be sort of continued frothy deal market. But again it's very difficult for us right now to compete with the pension funds, with the sovereign wealth funds on the assets that we want to buy. Again, if an opportunity materializes where we can solve a problem, we think that might be a spot where we could potentially capitalize.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Toomey. I would just characterize it as this way. It's not an element of risk and it's more of an element we believe the fundamentals of the industry have many years of strength ahead. It's just a function of pricing and opportunities and we
componenttext: John, this is Toomey. I would just characterize it as this way. It's not an element of risk and it's more of an element we believe the fundamentals of the industry have many years of strength ahead. It's just a function of pricing and opportunities and we would rather save our currency for where we can have more predictability and that's in our development pipeline today. On the acquisition front, prices are pretty good. I think assets still have some room to run, but we think we want to be a self-funded company that can internalize our growth, if you will. And the best path for that is continued development today. We'll continue to look at the market on an acquisition front but really do not feel that pricing-wise we're going to get the same type of returns that we would be getting in our development pipeline.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I think, Jerry, you mentioned that you see Southern California decelerating in 2017. Can you break that down between Orange County and LA, if there's any difference?
componenttext: Okay. And then I think, Jerry, you mentioned that you see Southern California decelerating in 2017. Can you break that down between Orange County and LA, if there's any difference?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I said I thought it would be stable to slight deceleration and that's mainly just based on how strong we see it this year. They're both going to be coming in at our current projections close to 7%. If I had to forecast between the 2, I'd probably -- it's
componenttext: I said I thought it would be stable to slight deceleration and that's mainly just based on how strong we see it this year. They're both going to be coming in at our current projections close to 7%. If I had to forecast between the 2, I'd probably -- it's probably about even. I think they're both going to remain strong for a while. They're both late to the game. You've got fantastic tech job growth in that Marina del Rey submarket where most of our assets are located in L.A. and I don't see that slowing down. I think the jobs still haven't fully arrived. When I look down at Southern California, I just read the other day, there was more job growth there in 2015 than there has been since, I think, the late 1999 levels, so it's picked up. You don't have any one large employer. You don't really have significant supply issues in Orange County. And in LA, most of the new supplies coming downtown where we're not located. So I would say, at this point I don't see a significant differentiation between how the 2 are going to perform next year. This year, I would expect our LA portfolio probably to be a hair higher than our Orange County.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Van Winkle of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Van Winkle of Morgan Stanley.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned seeing some outperformance from Bs versus As right now in D.C. Are there any other markets where you're seeing a significant bifurcation, does that told true in a lot of the markets where there's a lot of new supply? And is that gap widening
componenttext: You mentioned seeing some outperformance from Bs versus As right now in D.C. Are there any other markets where you're seeing a significant bifurcation, does that told true in a lot of the markets where there's a lot of new supply? And is that gap widening at all?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, it'll expand and contract quarter-by-quarter. Today, the differentiation is probably about 150 basis points nationally. And you're right, you tend to see that differential in almost every market where new supply is coming in to compete against our A
componenttext: Greg, it'll expand and contract quarter-by-quarter. Today, the differentiation is probably about 150 basis points nationally. And you're right, you tend to see that differential in almost every market where new supply is coming in to compete against our A product. So I would say on a national basis for us, that's probably about what the difference is, call it 150 bps. I saw probably reached its peak 1 year, 1.5 years ago when it was well over 200 basis points. At some point earlier this year, I remember looking and it felt like it had contracted down to about 50 but in the fourth quarter, it was about 150.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to UDR's First Quarter 2016 financial results conference call. Our first quarter press release and supplemental disclosure package were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investor Relations section of our website, ir.udr.com. In the
componenttext:
Welcome to UDR's First Quarter 2016 financial results conference call. Our first quarter press release and supplemental disclosure package were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investor Relations section of our website, ir.udr.com. In the supplement, we have reconciled all non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements. 
I would like to note that statements made during this call which are not historical may constitute forward-looking statements. Although we believe the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, we can give no assurance that our expectations will be met. A discussion of risk and risk factors are detailed in yesterday's press release and included in our filings with the SEC. We do not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements. 
[Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to our President and CEO, Tom Toomey.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's First Quarter Conference Call. On the call with me today are Tom Herzog, Chief Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss our results, as well as seni
componenttext:
Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's First Quarter Conference Call. On the call with me today are Tom Herzog, Chief Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss our results, as well as senior officers Warren Troupe and Harry Alcock, who will be available for the Q&A portion of the call. 
The first quarter of 2016 was another great quarter for UDR, with strong same-store results and development lease-up continuing to perform well. As you have come to expect from UDR, we remain focused on executing on our previously communicated 2-year strategic plan, which is still the right plan given the long-term strength of the apartment business. 
From a big picture point of view, we are now in our sixth year of achieving 5% plus NOI growth. Over the past 2 years, most our markets have seen accelerating growth trends due to supply demand and balance. And while our overall 2016 same-store operating trends continue to improve year-over-year in a few markets as anticipated, we have started to feel the impact of concentrated new supply. We believe apartment growth is sustainable and supply can be absorbed with steady job growth and household formations. Deliveries of middle apartment homes are projected to peak in the cycle in 2016 at around 380,000 units and will subsequently drop in 2017 to 300,000 units, while job growth is forecast to be in the 2 to 2.5 million range in both years. In this environment, market mix and price points will be key, and this plays well to our overall strategy that centers around our diverse portfolio of mix of 20 markets with A and B quality communities in urban and suburban locations, which, over the long term, we expect to continue to perform well through the cycles and provide consistent cash flow growth. 
Our 2-year strategic plan issued in February showed strong expected 2016 revenue and NOI growth of 5.75% and 6.75% at the midpoints. And we spoke to an anticipated solid but slightly deaccelerating 2017 operating environment with revenue and NOI growth of 5% and 5.5% at the midpoints. Since then, there have been a number of publications speaking to flowing revenue trends in certain markets and, as such, I'd ask Jerry to provide an update on our market expectations for the balance of 2016 and how we currently see 2017 stacking up. I hope you find this useful and that you reach the same conclusion as the UDR team. It's a great time to be in the apartment business. And therefore, we are reaffirming our full year guidance provided in the initial outlook and we'll provide an update during the second quarter earnings call. 
Also let me take a moment to mention that we were pleased that in early March, we were added to the S&P 500 index, which is a credit to our investors and the entire UDR team who made this possible. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. The topics I'll cover today include our first quarter results, our balance sheet and capital markets update, a cash update, a development and transactions update and our second quarter and full year guidance. Our first quarter earnings resu
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. The topics I'll cover today include our first quarter results, our balance sheet and capital markets update, a cash update, a development and transactions update and our second quarter and full year guidance. 
Our first quarter earnings results were in line with our previously provided guidance. FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share were $0.43, $0.43 and $0.41, respectively. First quarter same-store revenue expense and NOI growth remained strong at 6.4%, 2.7% and 8.0%, respectively. 
Next, the balance sheet. At year-end, our liquidity, as measured by cash and credit facility capacity, was $1.1 billion. Our financial leverage on underappreciated [ph] cost basis was 33.0%. Based on today's market cap, it was 23.8%, and inclusive of JVs, it was 28.2%. Our net debt to EBITDA was 5.4x and inclusive of JVs was 6.5x. All balance sheet metric improvements were ahead of plan. 
During the quarter, we issued 174 million of common equity at a net price of $34.73 per share in conjunction with our inclusion in the S&P 500. In addition, in January, we paid $83.3 million of 5.25% medium-term notes.
On to casualty [ph] losses. In conjunction with the previously announced damage to our 151-home 717 Olympic community located in Los Angeles, we recorded a casualty loss of $1.1 million during the quarter attributable to business interruption and temporary housing for our residents. This resulted in a charge of approximately $0.50 [ph] FFO but was added back to FFO as adjusted. We expect to recover significant portion of this charge from the insurance providers and any subsequent recoveries will be included in FFO but deducted from FFO as adjusted. As a reminder, 717 Olympic is owned by the MetLife II JV, it has no impact on our same-store results. As of today, all damage has been fixed, the community is fully operational and we are over 88% leased.
Turning to development. We commenced construction on our 585-home $367 million 345 Harrison Street development in Boston South End, which we intend to fund with noncore asset sales. We've identified a number of assets that we will be marketing to satisfy the funding needs for the year, with a significant portion of the sales coming from the Mid-Atlantic markets. 
At the end of the first quarter, the company had an underconstruction development pipeline for its pro rata share totaled $1 billion. The development pipeline is currently expected to produce a weighted average spread between estimated stabilize yields and current market cap rates above the upper end of the company's 150 to 200 basis point targeted range.
Next, transactions completed in the quarter. During the first quarter, we sold our 95% ownership interest in 2 land parcels located in Santa Monica, California, for $24 million. This resulted in a gain to FFO of $1.7 million, which was backed out of FFO as adjusted.
On to the second quarter and full year 2016 guidance. Second quarter 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance is $0.43 to $0.45, $0.43 to $0.45 and $0.39 to $0.41, respectively. At this time, we are maintaining our full year guidance ranges for both earnings and same-store metrics. 
Full year 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share is forecasted at $1.75 to $1.81, $1.75 to $1.81 and $1.59 to $1.65, respectively. 
For same-store, our full year 2016 guidance remains unchanged with revenue growth of 5.5% to 6%, expense 3.0% to 3.5% and NOI 6.5% to 7.0%. Average 2016 occupancy remains forecasted at 96.6%.
Due to the $174 million equity issuance in the quarter, we no longer anticipate a bond issuance later this year and are updating our full year interest expense guidance to $121 million to $125 million from $128 million to $132 million. 
Other primary full year guidance assumptions can be found on Attachment 15 or Page 26 of our supplement. 
Finally, we declared a quarterly common dividend of $0.295 in the first quarter or $1.18 per share when annualized, 6% above 2015's level and represented a yield of approximately 3.3%. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jerry.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. In my remarks, I'll cover the following topics. First, our first quarter portfolio metrics, leasing trends and the rental rate growth we realized this quarter nearly results for the second quarter. Second, how ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. In my remarks, I'll cover the following topics. First, our first quarter portfolio metrics, leasing trends and the rental rate growth we realized this quarter nearly results for the second quarter. Second, how our primary markets performed during the quarter with a high-level update for 2016 and 2017. And last, a brief update on our development lease-ups. 
We are pleased to announce another strong quarter of operating results. In the first quarter, same-store net operating income grew 8.0%, our highest growth rate since the first quarter of 2012. These results were driven by a very strong 6.4% year-over-year increase in revenue against a 2.7% increase in expenses. Our same-store revenue per occupied home increased by 6.7% year-over-year to $1,897 per month. Our same-store occupancy of 96.5% was down 20 basis points versus the prior-year period. 
Total portfolio revenue per occupied home was $1,995 per month, including pro rata JVs. Stable job growth, limited impact from new multifamily supply, rental preference from both new millennial households, empty-nesters and everyone in between are all driving this continued growth.
Turning to new and renewal lease rate growth, which is detailed on attachment 8E of our supplement. We grew new lease rates by 3.7% in the first quarter, 50 basis points below the first quarter of 2015. Renewal growth remained robust at 6.9% in the first quarter or 120 basis points ahead of last year. On a blended rate basis, we averaged 5.3% during the first quarter, an improvement of 40 basis points versus the same period in 2015. 
In April, these trends continued with new lease and renewal rate growth of 4.2% and 6.8%, respectively, and our current physical occupancy is 96.5%. 
Our leasing success and stable occupancy gives us confidence that demand is more than sufficient to continue pushing rate higher throughout the upcoming prime leasing season in the majority of our markets. 
Next, move-outs to home purchase were flat year-over-year at 13%, in line with our long-term average. Even with our strong renewal increases in the first quarter, less than 9% of our moveouts gave rent increases the reason for leaving. 
Before I move on to the quarterly performance in our primary markets, I'd like to give a general update on our entire portfolio. First, third-party data indicates that in every one of our markets, we expect supply to peak this year, with the exception being New York City. Second, job growth remains robust, and we continue to have strong pricing power in the majority of our markets. The overall economic environment we see today is very similar to what we provided in our 2-year outlook.
Now moving onto the quarterly performance in our primary markets, which represent 70% of our same-store NOI and 75% of our total NOI. Metro D.C., which represents 18% of our total NOI, posted year-over-year same-store revenue growth of 2.1% compared to 1.9% in the first quarter of '15. We are forecasting the market to generate top line growth in 2016 between 2% and 3% as we will continue to benefit from our diverse 50-50 mix of A and B assets located both inside and outside the Beltway. In the first quarter, our As and Bs had very similar growth rates. Apartment supply in 2016 is expected to increase by 13,600 homes and then fall to 9,000 homes in 2017, while job growth in 2017 is expected to increase by 1.9%, up from 1.6% in 2016. Our current forecast is that D.C. will have modestly accelerating revenue growth in 2017 compared to 2016.
Orange County and Los Angeles combined represents 16% of our total NOI. Orange County posted year-over-year revenue growth of 8.4%. We continue to remain very optimistic on Orange County as the market is only expected to see 5,000 units of new supply and nearly 35,000 jobs, implying a 7:1 ratio, which is roughly 2x the long-term historical average. Revenue growth in L.A. was 8.8% during the quarter, continuation of very strong results in the back half of 2015 due to job growth and supply absorption in our Marina del Rey concentrated submarket. Lease-up pressure from almost 2,000 recently delivered apartment homes in the neighboring Playa Vista market began negatively impacting our pricing power in the middle of the first quarter, and we think this competition will continue to affect us through the end of the third quarter. Fortunately, tech-related jobs continue to come to this part of Silicon Beach. 
Overall, L.A. will see over 12,000 apartment homes delivered in 2016 or about 1% of supply, and the market is projected to create 88,000 new jobs. Again, a 7:2 ration. 2017 and 2018 are each projected currently to see deliveries slow [ph] 7,000 to 8,000 homes per year, with job growth only slowing slightly.
L.A. looks does the strong market over the next several years and after we get past the short-term lease up pressures in our Marina del Rey Playa Vista submarket, we will get back on track to above-average growth. We still anticipate full year 2016 revenue growth in L.A. to be in the 6% range and would expect 2017 to also be in that range. 
New York City represents 12% of our total NOI and posted 5.8% revenue growth in the quarter. While our Same Store Properties are not directly affected by any new developments, we are beginning to feel the impact from the new supply in the Manhattan market. New Yorkers typically have been loyal to their preferred neighborhoods or beginning to be enticed by pricing and incentives in places like Midtown West. 2016 deliveries of 25,000 apartment homes are adding 1% to existing supply. 2017 is expected that deliveries even higher at 30,000 apartment homes, but still right around 1% of existing supply. The higher deliveries in these years are directly related to the expiring 4 21 tax abatement program. Once we get through this multi-year elevated supply levels, new development should decrease significantly. Job growth in 2016 and 2017 is expected to be right around 1.3% each year. For full year 2016, we've revised our revenue growth expectations down to about 5% in our New York portfolio, which is 50 to 60 basis points below our original business plan. Because of the continuing pressures of new supply, we currently would project 2017 revenue growth in New York to be modestly lower than it will be in 2016 .
San Francisco, which represents 11% of our total NOI is feeling the effects of new supply in several submarkets, including South market. However, we still expect the Bay Area to be one of our best-performing markets this year with revenue growth of 7% to 8%. Same-store revenue growth in the first quarter was 9.6% due to the extremely strong blended rate growth we achieved in the second and third quarters of 2015. The good news is that 2016 it would be the peak of deliveries this cycle at 12,600 apartments or roughly 3% of existing stock and the number gets cut roughly in half to 6,800 homes in 2017, representing approximately 1.6% of existing stock. And job growth in 2016 and 2017 is expected to average about 2.5% each year. Although the Bay area is slowing, we still expect it to be an above-average market this year and next.
Boston, which represents 7% of our total NOI, produced a strong 6% revenue growth during the first quarter. A 1 same-store property in the Back Bay neighborhood had revenue growth of 5%. Our suburban assets in the North Shore were our strongest performers with growth of 7.5%. The Freeport District, home to our 2015 completion 100 Pier 4, continues to see more growth with additional office tenants in the submarket, including the first quarter announcement that GE will be relocating to the Seaport, about 1/2 mile from our property. We started an additional project this quarter in Boston's South end, the 585 home $367 million project, 345 Harrison Street. New supply in Boston is projected at 6,100 homes in 2016, with slight deceleration in 2017 to 5,500 homes. Both years represent less than 1.5% of existing stock. Job growth is currently forecast to be about 1.5% both years. We expect revenue growth in 2017 to be comparable to this year.
Seattle, which represents 6% of our total NOI and posted 8.4% revenue growth, continued to benefit from the strong growth in Harrington, our suburban, which are located in submarkets that are less exposed to new supply. Long term, we continue to like the Downtown Seattle submarket and believe that the ongoing creation of new jobs by companies such as Amazon, Google, Facebook and Expedia will continue to drive demand in Seattle's urban core. The Bellevue submarket is in the midst of fairly heavy new multifamily development but has not yet put up significant pressure on our portfolio as evidenced by our 7.7% revenue growth in Bellevue this quarter. Deliveries in Metro Seattle are expected to peak in 2016 at 9,800 apartment homes before falling to 6,200 homes in 2017, while job growth continues at more than 2%. We expect revenue growth in 2017 to be comparable to this year.
Last, Dallas, which represents just over 4.5% of our NOI, posted 5.8% year-over-year same-store revenue growth in the first quarter. Our B properties have revenue growth that was 400 basis points higher than our As as heavy new supply in uptown and along the toll ways impacting rent growth in those submarkets. New supply in Dallas is projected to peak in 2016 at 18,000 new units and then drop to 12,700 in 2017. Job growth in the Dallas market should remain strong both years, above 2.4%. 
Outside of our primary markets such as Portland, Monterey Peninsula, the Sunbelt, Nashville and Austin, which comprise roughly 20% of our portfolio, we are above our initial expectations provided in our 2-year outlook and we continue to have strong pricing power due to limited amounts of new supply and robust job growth. Our expectation is that these markets have a long runway of growth due to favorable economics.
April's results came in, in line with our plan. And as we look ahead in the next 3 [ph] months, we see improving pricing power along with stable occupancy. Our 50-50 A B portfolio located throughout 20 markets has enabled outperformance in our Sunbelt markets, Orange County, Portland and Monterey Peninsula to offset markets that are being impacted by new supply in San Francisco, New York and L.A. 
On a national basis, and within our core markets, apartment deliveries are expected to peak in 2016. Current projections from actual metrics have 2017 deliveries coming down over 25%. New York is the only market that we operate in that would experience a higher number of deliveries in 2017 than it had in 2016. 
Remember, that earlier this year, in our 2-year outlook, we indicated a 75 basis point deceleration in 2017, with a revenue growth guidance midpoint of 5%. Our overall view has not changed.
I'll turn now to our 4 in lease up developments, which you can find on Attachment 9A and B or Pages 19 and 20 of our supplement. Our share of these 4 properties represent $316 million or roughly 23% of our pipeline, inclusive of the West Coast development JV. In total, these properties are performing ahead of plan. 
399 Fremont, our 447-home, $318 million lease up in San Francisco, California, took first move-ins in mid-March and was 26% leased and 15% occupied at quarter end. Today, we are 29% leased and 24% occupied, with rents exceeding pro forma. We are currently operating a concession business as planned at this community, noting we will see increased competition further lease ups in the submarket in the near future. 
Katella Grand 1, our 399-home $138 million lease-up in Anaheim, California in the West Coast development JV was 37% leased and 29% occupied at quarter end. And as of today, it's 47% leased and 37% occupied. We are currently offering less than 1 month of concessions at this community and leasing has been very strong in April with 41 applications. 
CityLine, our 244-home, $80 million lease-up in the Columbia City submarket of Seattle was 47% leased and 34% occupied at quarter end. Today, the property is 66% leased and 52% physically occupied.
April Republican, our 211-home $97 million lease up in the South Lake Union submarket of Seattle was 8% leased and 0% occupied at quarter end. And today, it is 16% leased and 6% occupied. First units were available for move in, in mid-April. 
All in, we had a great first quarter and we remain very positive on the outlook for multifamily fundamentals and our ability to execute during the peak leasing season and throughout the remainder of 2016. 
With that, I'll turn the call back to Tom.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jerry. And before I open it up to Q&A, I want to take a moment to sum up our prepared remarks. We still feel very good about multifamily fundamentals and are in a phase in the cycle where market mix and price points of our portfolio are critica
componenttext:
Thank you, Jerry. And before I open it up to Q&A, I want to take a moment to sum up our prepared remarks. We still feel very good about multifamily fundamentals and are in a phase in the cycle where market mix and price points of our portfolio are critical. As Jerry mentioned, due to changes in conditions, some of our markets are underperforming and some are outperforming our original expectations. However, on balance, our outlook for the portfolio is unchanged. This is a testament to our overall strategy and market mix, which is less volatile and more predictable on average throughout the cycles. We feel good about 2016 and '17 and remain on target. UDR has the right plan with the right team in place to execute, and we feel confident about our future opportunities. 
With that, I will open it up to Q&A. Operator?

componenttext: This is Harry. Depends a little bit on a product mix. I can tell you in general the marketplace, Class As are trading at -- Class A main locations are trading at 4, sub 4. The Bs that would likely comprise most of what we sell are going to trade between 5%, 5.5% cap rates, again depending on location and specific asset type. There continues to be a strong bid for these assets, particularly in the B space but A and C continues to be readily available, Fannie and Freddie both expect to meet or actually exceed 2016 volume versus 2015. So it's a good time to sell assets right now.

componenttext: And then just touching a little bit on D.C. headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Austin. This is Jerry. D.C., again, we continue to think it bottomed about a year and a half ago, late 2014. But we continue to see supply pressures in various submarkets throughout the Metro D.C. area such as Arlington and Alexandria. What's intere
componenttext: Sure, Austin. This is Jerry. D.C., again, we continue to think it bottomed about a year and a half ago, late 2014. But we continue to see supply pressures in various submarkets throughout the Metro D.C. area such as Arlington and Alexandria. What's interesting is we've seen the compression between what As and Bs are doing. Currently, it's probably less than 100 basis points. Our properties in that 14th and Street neighborhood, including Capital View, View 14, Hanover place and Thomas Circle, those deals are all putting up probably about 3% revenue growth. And then a couple of the places over our Columbia Pike and Arlington are negative revenue growth right now. Now when you get outside the Beltway, even though outside tends to do a little bit better than inside the Beltway, we have a couple of properties out there in Woodbridge that are flat to slightly negative. So the A B mix has benefited us in the past where B has significantly outperformed, but we are seeing neighborhoods in DC where supply has subsided, react very well and starting to see good rent growth. All in, D.C.'s performing about where we expected. I'll touch on the Home portfolio that we bought back in October. It's performing pretty much within plan, in accordance with the plan that we had. We found a few opportunities to write expenses down. We're in the process of spending coming close to $20 million on some initial capital expenditures, some on unit interior, some on the exteriors of the properties. But as we chug through that, we're seeing occupancy which when we bought the portfolio, I think, was down around 92%. Today, occupancy in that portfolio has risen to between 95% and 96%. So D.C. I would tell you is going according to plan, our expectation this year, like I said in my prepared remarks, is that revenue to be between 2% and 3%. And then our expectation going further out is supply continues to be absorbed that '17 is better than '16.

But do you see revenue declining in 2017? Just wanted to ask if that's purely due to increased vacancy? Or do you see rate coming down as well?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to be more rate. I think occupancy there will stay in the 97%, 9% range. Today it's in the high 96s. The reason turnover was down really in the first quarter is we moved more of our expirations into the more seasonally high demand secon
componenttext: I think it's going to be more rate. I think occupancy there will stay in the 97%, 9% range. Today it's in the high 96s. The reason turnover was down really in the first quarter is we moved more of our expirations into the more seasonally high demand second, third quarter. So it wasn't purely that we were retaining more people, it was more that we had fewer expirations in the first quarter. So we are definitely feeling the effects of the supply pressures, whether it's Midtown, West, Brooklyn, they're starting to have an effect to our Financial District properties. And if you really stratify what we did in the first quarter, our 2 Don Financial District popped revenue growth of about 4.5% and our Chelsea and Marie Hill [ph] properties came in north of 7%. So we're feeling it a little bit more in the Financial District. And then if you go up to our MetLife JV property in the upper West Side, Columbus Square, that one is definitely feeling the effects of new supply in the upper West Side and had revenue growth of about 1%, 1.5%. So I don't think you'll see us --  the slowdown that I talked about in '17 I think is going to be more rate driven than occupancy.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: How comfortable you feel in your '16 outlook in New York just given as you mentioned we're heading into the leasing season?
componenttext: How comfortable you feel in your '16 outlook in New York just given as you mentioned we're heading into the leasing season?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: New York actually, it's doing about as well in April as it did in the first quarter. I mean, I would've hoped it would have accelerated, but it hasn't yet, but new lease rate growth in April is about 2.5, 2.6. But renewal rate growth has jumped up to 6.7%
componenttext: New York actually, it's doing about as well in April as it did in the first quarter. I mean, I would've hoped it would have accelerated, but it hasn't yet, but new lease rate growth in April is about 2.5, 2.6. But renewal rate growth has jumped up to 6.7%. So I think we did a good job pushing those into the stronger periods. But we feel good about where I expect now. I think I said on the prepared remarks that we've revised our expectations there from being high 5s to low 5s. I guess there's the possibility if we continue to encounter more significant supply pressures, that could come a bit lower. But right now, pretty comfortable in that 5 range.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the schedule of new and renewal rates in the press release, really appreciate the detail there. As it relates to the different markets with different factors, sort of offsetting one another, is there a way for the likely sitting a
componenttext: Just a quick question on the schedule of new and renewal rates in the press release, really appreciate the detail there. As it relates to the different markets with different factors, sort of offsetting one another, is there a way for the likely sitting above the midpoint of the same-store range that didn't really change these several puts and takes during the quarter in that sense?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I would say this. Overall, and maybe this hopefully this answer your question, overall, first quarter came in where we thought it would. So far in April, we are right on track also. Always going to have some markets that perform a little bit bette
componenttext: I guess I would say this. Overall, and maybe this hopefully this answer your question, overall, first quarter came in where we thought it would. So far in April, we are right on track also. Always going to have some markets that perform a little bit better than expectations, some that are below. And obviously, the 3 that we spoke to in the prepared remarks that are currently under are San Francisco, New York and Los Angeles. And the reason for their underperformance is really the effect of new supply. We've talked for years that continuing to get 10% revenue growth in San Francisco wasn't long-term sustainable. And I guess the developers and the city officials also took notice of this, and this previously undersupplied market is getting a slug of new supply right now. Fortunately for us, it's going to peak this year and start to decelerate next year. But what we noticed, too, and I had this in our remarks, is the success of new lease up properties that are putting some of those pressure on us, that our 399 Fremont lease up is well ahead of leasing velocity. We're getting rental rates that are above pro forma rents, which were $6 a foot, and we're given away 1 month free. So what really shows up is there is demand and there is traffic for apartments. We have a lease up property that's basically getting discounted down 8% because of 1 month free. Going to find it harder to push rate on Same Store Properties. But yes, those -- we do have the 3 underperformers. We also, as I stated earlier, we got about 1/3 of the company that is exceeding expectations. And those are Orange County, which is I would say significantly, but it's ahead of where we expected. Our 2 markets in Florida, Orlando and Tampa are significantly add to what would have expected we did our business plan, as is Nashville, Portland and Monterey. And I think the big difference between the ones that are underperforming and those that are outperforming, it's which ones are being affected by new supply. Those that I just said that are outperforming tend to be B product, which doesn't compete as much against new supply. And they're in markets that really are not getting heavy doses of supply.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe one quick follow-up there as it relates to the A B strategy and Bs outperforming on account of new supply. I mean is it an entirely a function of less supply with the B assets versus As? Or is there also a moment of trading down or anything else on
componenttext: Maybe one quick follow-up there as it relates to the A B strategy and Bs outperforming on account of new supply. I mean is it an entirely a function of less supply with the B assets versus As? Or is there also a moment of trading down or anything else on the demand side of the equation that might be leading to outperformance there in general?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's predominantly lack of new supply. I mean, there could be some situations of trading down. We've seen the reasons for move out being rent increase grow to about 9%. That's stable with where it was about a year ago. We've got 2 markets that are
componenttext: I think it's predominantly lack of new supply. I mean, there could be some situations of trading down. We've seen the reasons for move out being rent increase grow to about 9%. That's stable with where it was about a year ago. We've got 2 markets that are above 20%, those are San Francisco and Los Angeles. And even though you could sit there and think maybe it's because they're getting priced out of the market, when we really see address and where these people move to, they're frequently moving to that brand new supply down the street that's offering 1 month free, or in the case of Marina del Rey, 1.5 to 2 months free. The price is similar to what we were asking them to pay. So we are able to trade up, if you will, into a brand new community, but it's at the same rate. So I don't think it's price fatigue it. There's probably a little bit of that inching in there, but I think it's predominantly supply.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Nick Joseph with Citi.
