componenttextpreview: I just wanted to clarify your reduced outlook on New York. So it seems like you have 6% renewal growth this quarter and unusually low turnover of 20%. But do you see revenue declining in 2017? So I just wanted to ask if that's purely due to increased vaca
componenttext: I just wanted to clarify your reduced outlook on New York. So it seems like you have 6% renewal growth this quarter and unusually low turnover of 20%. But do you see revenue declining in 2017? So I just wanted to ask if that's purely due to increased vacancy? Or do you see rate coming down as well?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's going to be more rate. I think occupancy there will stay in the 97%, 98% range. Today it's in the high 96s. The reason turnover was down really in the first quarter is we moved more of our expirations into the more seasonally high demand
componenttext: No, I think it's going to be more rate. I think occupancy there will stay in the 97%, 98% range. Today it's in the high 96s. The reason turnover was down really in the first quarter is we moved more of our expirations into the more seasonally high demand second, third quarter. So it wasn't purely that we were retaining more people, it was more that we had fewer expirations in the first quarter. So we are definitely feeling the effects of the supply pressures. Whether it's Midtown, West to Brooklyn, they're starting to have an effect to our Financial District properties. And if you really stratify what we did in the city in the first quarter, our 2 down in the Financial District popped revenue growth of about 4.5% and our Chelsea and Murray Hill properties came in north of 7%. So we're feeling it a little bit more in the Financial District. And then if you go up to our MetLife JV property in the Upper West Side, Columbus Square, that one is definitely feeling the effects of new supply in the upper West Side and had revenue growth of about 1%, 1.5%. So I don't think you'll see us --  the slowdown that I talked about in '17, I think, is going to be more rate-driven than occupancy.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how comfortable do you feel in your '16 outlook in New York just given, as you mentioned, we're heading into the leasing season?
componenttext: And how comfortable do you feel in your '16 outlook in New York just given, as you mentioned, we're heading into the leasing season?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. New York, actually, it's doing about as well in April as it did in the first quarter. I mean, I would have hoped it would have accelerated, but it hasn't yet, but new lease rate growth in April is about 2.5%, 2.6%. But renewal rate growth has jumped
componenttext: Yes. New York, actually, it's doing about as well in April as it did in the first quarter. I mean, I would have hoped it would have accelerated, but it hasn't yet, but new lease rate growth in April is about 2.5%, 2.6%. But renewal rate growth has jumped up to 6.7%. So I think we did a good job pushing those into the stronger periods. But we feel good about where I expect now. I think I'd said on the prepared remarks that we've revised our expectations there from being high 5s to low 5s. I guess there's the possibility if we continue to encounter more significant supply pressures, it could come a bit lower, but right now pretty comfortable in that 5 range.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the schedule of new and renewal rates in the press release, really appreciate the detail there. As it relates to the different markets with different factors, sort of offsetting one another, is there a way for you to peg the likel
componenttext: Just a quick question on the schedule of new and renewal rates in the press release, really appreciate the detail there. As it relates to the different markets with different factors, sort of offsetting one another, is there a way for you to peg the likelihood of sitting above the midpoint of the same-store range that didn't really change these several puts and takes during the quarter in that sense?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I would say this. Overall -- and maybe hopefully this will answer your question. Overall, first quarter came in where we thought it would. So far in April, we're right on track also. We're always going to have some markets that perform a little b
componenttext: I guess, I would say this. Overall -- and maybe hopefully this will answer your question. Overall, first quarter came in where we thought it would. So far in April, we're right on track also. We're always going to have some markets that perform a little bit better than expectations, some that are below. And obviously, the 3 that we spoke to in the prepared remarks that are currently under are San Francisco, New York and Los Angeles and the reason for their underperformance really is the effects of new supply. We've talked for years that continuing to get 10% revenue growth in San Francisco wasn't long term sustainable. And I guess the developers and the city officials also took notice of this and this previously undersupplied market is getting a slug of new supply right now. Fortunately, for us, it's going to peak this year and start to decelerate next year. But what we noticed, too, and I had this in our remarks, is the success of new lease-up properties that are putting some of those pressure on us, that our 399 Fremont lease-up is well ahead of leasing velocity. We're getting rental rates that are above pro forma rents, which were $6 a foot, and we're giving away 1 month free. So what really shows up is there is demand and there is traffic for apartments. But when you have a lease-up property that's basically getting discounted down 8% because of 1-month free, you're going to find it harder to push rate on same-store properties. But yes, those -- we do have the 3 underperformers. We also, as I stated earlier, we've got about 1/3 of the company that is exceeding expectations. And those are: Orange County, which is I will say significantly, but it's ahead of where we expected; our 2 markets in Florida, Orlando and Tampa, are significantly ahead of what we would have expected when we did our business plan; as is Nashville, Portland and Monterey. And I think the big difference between the ones that are underperforming and those that are outperforming, it's which ones are being affected by new supply. Those that I just said that are outperforming tend to be B product, which doesn't compete as much against new supply, and they're in markets that really are not getting heavy doses of supply.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. That's very helpful. And then maybe as one quick follow-up there as it relates to the A-B strategy and Bs outperforming on account of new supply. I mean, is it entirely a function of less supply with the B assets versus As? Or is there also a m
componenttext: All right. That's very helpful. And then maybe as one quick follow-up there as it relates to the A-B strategy and Bs outperforming on account of new supply. I mean, is it entirely a function of less supply with the B assets versus As? Or is there also a moment of trading down or anything else on the demand side of the equation that might be leading to out-performance there in general?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's predominantly lack of new supply. I mean, there could be some situations of trading down. We've seen a reason for move-out being rent increase grow to about 9%, that's stable with where it was about a year ago. We've got 2 markets that are ab
componenttext: I think it's predominantly lack of new supply. I mean, there could be some situations of trading down. We've seen a reason for move-out being rent increase grow to about 9%, that's stable with where it was about a year ago. We've got 2 markets that are above 20%, those are San Francisco and Los Angeles. And even though you could sit there and think maybe it's because of -- that they're getting priced out of the market, when we really see forwarding addresses on where these people move to, they're frequently moving to that brand new supply down the street that's offering the 1-month free, or in the case of Marina del Rey, 1.5 to 2 months free. The price is then similar to what we were asking them to pay. So we're able to trade up, if you will, into a brand new community, but it's at the same rate. So I don't think it's price fatigue. There's probably a little bit of that inching in there, but I think it's predominantly supply.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Nick Joseph with Citi.
componenttext: We'll go next to Nick Joseph with Citi.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an update on the West Coast development JV? It looks like a few of the assets are now leased up and what you're seeing in those markets?
componenttext: Can you give us an update on the West Coast development JV? It looks like a few of the assets are now leased up and what you're seeing in those markets?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll start and then Jerry can jump in. Two of the assets are in lease-up, CityLine in Seattle and Katella 1 in Anaheim. And as Jerry mentioned in his prepared remarks, they're both leasing up very well. We just started leasing 8th & Republican in So
componenttext: Sure, I'll start and then Jerry can jump in. Two of the assets are in lease-up, CityLine in Seattle and Katella 1 in Anaheim. And as Jerry mentioned in his prepared remarks, they're both leasing up very well. We just started leasing 8th & Republican in South Lake Union near Amazon and we're -- we've leased, I don't know, 10% or so of the units -- 16% of the units at this point. The next ones are going to be downtown L.A. assets that we will begin leasing in the third quarter. And then the second phase of the Katella project, which would begin leasing early next year.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, I'll give you a little more color on how well those lease-ups are doing. As Harry said, they're all at or above what we expected. Katella Grand has probably been my biggest surprise. It's up in the Platinum Triangle and we're getting rents that
componenttext: Yes, Nick, I'll give you a little more color on how well those lease-ups are doing. As Harry said, they're all at or above what we expected. Katella Grand has probably been my biggest surprise. It's up in the Platinum Triangle and we're getting rents that we anticipated in, call it, the $2.25 to $2.30 a foot range. Been able to drive that thing up to 47% leased and 36 occupied using typically less than a month free. So that one's been a bit surprising to me how strong it was, but I think it is a special project. CityLine up in the Columbia City location, that one got off the ground a little bit slow and we cut rate a bit to get velocity going in the first quarter, but we caught back up to our budgeted occupancy level and today that property is 66% leased, 52% physical and we've gotten rents back above market rate and we brought concessions in at about a month free now. And the third one that is doing real well right now is 8th & Republican and we opened the doors to that one about 2 weeks ago, and as Harry -- or as I stated a minute ago, we're about 16% leased and 6% physical. And one extra benefit that we found out a month or 2 ago, we thought we were getting dropped right in between Amazon land, Google announced recently that they're going to be putting a few offices up within several blocks of this property, too, and that [indiscernible] couple of years.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Herzog, too, Nick, I'll add one other thing. Keep in mind with the West Coast Wolff JV that we do get a 6.5% pref until such time as the assets are stabilized as defined and they absorb in the operating losses during that time period. So in the me
componenttext: This is Herzog, too, Nick, I'll add one other thing. Keep in mind with the West Coast Wolff JV that we do get a 6.5% pref until such time as the assets are stabilized as defined and they absorb in the operating losses during that time period. So in the meantime, while these are stabilized and we're earning a 6.5% on our investment.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on the new development in Boston. Can you talk about the desirability of that project and expectations in terms of the spread over existing cap rates that you expect to achieve?
componenttext: And then just on the new development in Boston. Can you talk about the desirability of that project and expectations in terms of the spread over existing cap rates that you expect to achieve?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Nick, this is Harry, I'll talk about this for a couple of minutes. First, we're building a project in a location that will appeal to a broad range of renters. I'll talk about the neighborhood first and then the economics. This is a new location with
componenttext: Sure. Nick, this is Harry, I'll talk about this for a couple of minutes. First, we're building a project in a location that will appeal to a broad range of renters. I'll talk about the neighborhood first and then the economics. This is a new location within the South End, which is one of Boston's most desirable neighborhood. It's primarily a residential district with old 19th century brownstones. But this particular location is only a 10-minute walk to the Financial District, the Back Bay and GE's new headquarters that will bring 800 new employees to Boston. There's tons of restaurants, bars, galleries and boutiques along Fremont Street. Our site is located directly across the street from new Whole Foods Market that opened last year. There's been some recently built apartment projects, Ink block and the Troy totaling more than 800 units that are nearly fully leased up. The first condo building across the street sold out and prior to completion at more than $1,000 a foot. They've just started construction on a second condo building. Related companies purchased the site kitty-corner from ours and is into the city for approval of 175 apartments and 100 condos. In terms of economics, the yield based on today's rents is about 5.5%. If we get 3% revenue and expense growth for 3-plus years, the yield will grow to above 6% and more than 200 basis points above today's cap rates. Rents today are more than $400 below our Pier 4 deal that leased up in 7 months last year when you're comparing similar unit types. And like similar assets in Boston, the cap rate for this asset would be very low, likely sub-4% cap rate. We believe, in fact, that this location could outperform Boston overall, which according to AXIO averages nearly 4% per annum through 2019. In addition to Whole Foods and the retail and residential construction, our units and our 40,000 square feet of retail will help complete the transition of this new location within a very established and desirable overall neighborhood. Downtown Boston expects to average less than 1,500 unit deliveries per year through 2020, so we also believe supply is manageable.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: We'll go next to Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you're doing 8% same-store NOI growth in the first quarter, and sounds like you're going to have a good second quarter and your guidance is 6% to 7.5% still, should we be assuming that you're expecting a supply-induced meaningful deceleration in the
componenttext: So if you're doing 8% same-store NOI growth in the first quarter, and sounds like you're going to have a good second quarter and your guidance is 6% to 7.5% still, should we be assuming that you're expecting a supply-induced meaningful deceleration in the second half of the year? Is that how we should read this at this point?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, I'll start that, this is Jerry. Really, when you think about what makes up your revenue growth, it's really the -- it's any change in your occupancy year-over-year and then it's really the weighted blended average of increases for renewals and new l
componenttext: Rich, I'll start that, this is Jerry. Really, when you think about what makes up your revenue growth, it's really the -- it's any change in your occupancy year-over-year and then it's really the weighted blended average of increases for renewals and new leases over the proceeding 12-month period. So when you really look at how the revenue growth will decelerate over the years, you really haven't looked, for example, in the second quarter. What did we do in the second quarter last year on blended growth and what do we expect to do this year in second quarter on blended growth. And because last year, the second and third quarter were extremely strong, and as we go into this year's second and third quarter, the rate growth is going to be less than it was last year, you have a natural deceleration. Now I guess you could say, accurately, that it is primarily coming from new supply deceleration that is predominantly occurring in those 3 markets that I talked about earlier because they have the heavier weighting on our total revenue growth. But I guess, long story short, I think you kind of hit it on the head, but I just wanted to make sure people really understand what the components are that really drive the rate growth. And for example, in the first quarter of this year, what we achieved in the third quarter of 2015 had a more of an impact on first quarter revenue growth than what we achieved as far as rate growth in the first quarter.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me add, Rich. One of the things that I'll have you keep in mind is, we obviously had a good start to 2016 from a same-store perspective. And as we look at guidance for the balance of the year, it's still too early to make any modifications in our view
componenttext: Let me add, Rich. One of the things that I'll have you keep in mind is, we obviously had a good start to 2016 from a same-store perspective. And as we look at guidance for the balance of the year, it's still too early to make any modifications in our view. We want to get more into peak leasing season, but we do feel good about where we're at and we'll revisit again next quarter.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. And then one of the little tidbits that I find interesting is that your development pipeline is exceeded at the top end of your kind of range of incremental yields, so close to 200 basis points, and yet you're worried about supply all a
componenttext: I appreciate that. And then one of the little tidbits that I find interesting is that your development pipeline is exceeded at the top end of your kind of range of incremental yields, so close to 200 basis points, and yet you're worried about supply all around you. I mean, why do you suppose that, that's --  those 2 opposite sort of things are happening right now? I would think maybe with elevated levels of supply, your own development pipeline would be at least underperforming a little bit in that environment. Can you just kind of walk through that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Toomey. I think, one, it's a testament to Harry and his team. I mean, they found very good sites. They've done a good job of reading where the market opportunity is and providing a hell of a good product and I think you're seeing that both l
componenttext: Rich, this is Toomey. I think, one, it's a testament to Harry and his team. I mean, they found very good sites. They've done a good job of reading where the market opportunity is and providing a hell of a good product and I think you're seeing that both last year with Boston and this year with San Francisco. So I think it's a little bit of that aspect of it, if you will. I think it's a fair question. We'll probably want it a little bit more and try to come up with reasons. We're really focusing on the forward aspect of the business and want to stay disciplined about allocating our capital and sustaining that type of gap or accretion, if you will. And normally, that's -- people wander into the subject of would you expand it and I don't think we would, I think we're going to stay very disciplined about our development and keep going forward.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Nick Yulico with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to Nick Yulico with UBS.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was hoping you could shed a little bit more light on why the joint venture assets are underperforming so much on a same-store growth basis? They did 1% same-store NOI growth versus 8% for the rest of your portfolio. I guess, you talked about New York, but
componenttext: Was hoping you could shed a little bit more light on why the joint venture assets are underperforming so much on a same-store growth basis? They did 1% same-store NOI growth versus 8% for the rest of your portfolio. I guess, you talked about New York, but what else is going on there?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Jerry. When you really look at it and I think we stated this earlier, A and especially A-plus product competes more against new supply than B. We've stated before that the spread between As and Bs in our same-store pool is probably abou
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Jerry. When you really look at it and I think we stated this earlier, A and especially A-plus product competes more against new supply than B. We've stated before that the spread between As and Bs in our same-store pool is probably about 100 basis points. But when you do look at the MetLife assets and there's -- again there's 24 assets, I believe, in the same-store pool of MetLife, there's 5 of them that are in urban cores where heavy new supply is hitting and that's definitely hitting A-plus product: one of those is in downtown Seattle, one is in Washington, D.C.; one is Columbus Square up in the Upper West Side; one is in uptown Dallas; and then the last one is in downtown Austin. Those 5 properties make up 41% of the total NOI of the MetLife JV and they have revenue growth of 0.6%, so under 1%, because they are going head-to-head against so much new supply. But when you look at the expense side, you have situations where I believe last year in the first quarter we had pretty good real estate tax, the appraisals have benefited us. But it's predominantly because of those 5 properties that are in the urban core of heavy new supply urban locations.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's -- yes, that's helpful. I guess my follow-up on that was if we go through your proxy and I look at some of the short-term compensation metrics for executives, one piece is same-store revenue growth in markets versus your peer group. And then
componenttext: Okay, that's -- yes, that's helpful. I guess my follow-up on that was if we go through your proxy and I look at some of the short-term compensation metrics for executives, one piece is same-store revenue growth in markets versus your peer group. And then I'm wondering why then it makes sense to be carving out, I think, that calculation carves it out the MetLife JV assets, which seems like it would actually be then beneficial if you're thinking about how your portfolio is being comped versus your peers, which often have less JVs or don't have as much exposure with a JV in a market like New York or Boston.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Toomey. It's a good question. First, when we manage and set forth budgets with Met, we have them as a partner in the room and they weigh in on how they want the asset run and we weigh in on it. And we usually, somewhere in the middle of that
componenttext: Nick, this is Toomey. It's a good question. First, when we manage and set forth budgets with Met, we have them as a partner in the room and they weigh in on how they want the asset run and we weigh in on it. And we usually, somewhere in the middle of that, arrive at how we're going to manage the asset. I think, second, we saw the pressures that Jerry alluded to with Ultra A assets and we really have that conversation run those assets in that manner and we have since Day 1 disclosed it transparently. With respect to the comp point on the issue, we're very comfortable after the deliberation with the board internally that we've got the right comp plan and rewards the right action, which is to win our markets and I think we do that pretty darn consistently and I think it's a testament to Jerry and his operating team and the information that they drive. So we're comfortable with our plan and how we've treated the Met JVs and disclosed them.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: We'll go next to Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, just kind of going back to Nick's question on MetLife. The expense growth was relatively high in that JV. And to your point about working with MetLife to control the expenses, is there anything that you might do differently if you were in
componenttext: First question, just kind of going back to Nick's question on MetLife. The expense growth was relatively high in that JV. And to your point about working with MetLife to control the expenses, is there anything that you might do differently if you were in 100% of control of the property? Or is there anything that can be done on the expense side? Or is that kind of just an outsized impact from 421-a in New York?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some of it is outsized impact, some of it also is just real estate tax -- timing of real estate tax refunds last year versus this year and you really need to see a full year and not judge it purely on a quarter. But you will find also in some of these loc
componenttext: Some of it is outsized impact, some of it also is just real estate tax -- timing of real estate tax refunds last year versus this year and you really need to see a full year and not judge it purely on a quarter. But you will find also in some of these locations where there's heavy new supply, things like personnel growth. Because in places where there's heavy new supply, you're in constant competition to get the best employees to work for you, so that can drive that number up, too. But I can tell you this, we typically attempt on any initiatives that we're rolling out for expense reductions, whatever we do for UDR, we typically do, if UDR wholly owned, we typically do it in the MetLife portfolio also.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Makes sense. And then, secondly, just looking at the private equity appetite for real estate assets. Obviously, there's been a very strong bid for theoretically more stable suburban properties with Home Properties in associated states being bought, Starwo
componenttext: Makes sense. And then, secondly, just looking at the private equity appetite for real estate assets. Obviously, there's been a very strong bid for theoretically more stable suburban properties with Home Properties in associated states being bought, Starwood buying EQR's portfolio, et cetera. What are you seeing in these A markets and in CBDs in terms of who's looking at assets? Are you receiving any interest externally from any of the larger private equity players? Or is there appetite kind of more geared towards stable -- more stable assets with theoretically higher yield?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Harry. I think on the -- yes, but, sort of by and large, it's bifurcated buyer class between the main and main Class A assets, which are going to be pension funds, sovereign wealth funds and we're starting to see an influx of foreign investment fr
componenttext: This is Harry. I think on the -- yes, but, sort of by and large, it's bifurcated buyer class between the main and main Class A assets, which are going to be pension funds, sovereign wealth funds and we're starting to see an influx of foreign investment from Canada, from the Middle East and Asia, and perhaps to a lesser degree, the private equity funds who typically have slightly higher IRR hurdles than the these others. And therefore, while they do have buckets of money that would lend itself to buying A properties, they tend to buy kind of A-minus and B properties primarily. At least that's what you've seen historically, that's what we're seeing now. There's both asset classes we're seeing very deep buyer pools, which has obviously positively impacted asset pricing. In terms of others sort of reaching out to us, that's something that happens routinely whether it's from private equity firms or sovereign wealth firms or other buyers and that happens routinely at really at all points in the cycle.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick and Drew, if Nick you're still on the call, I want to loop back on the Met thing. A couple of points occurred to me, as I was just looking at my notes. Just a reminder, Met's 10% of our NOI. We've consistently treated it and sometimes it's better and
componenttext: Nick and Drew, if Nick you're still on the call, I want to loop back on the Met thing. A couple of points occurred to me, as I was just looking at my notes. Just a reminder, Met's 10% of our NOI. We've consistently treated it and sometimes it's better and sometimes it's worse than the wholly owned portfolio. But what I look at, and we go over every year with our board, our IRRs and our returns on our investments from beginning to the end and it's a good thorough review. And I'm just looking at the Met coming up on its sixth year that we've been co-investing with them in this JV and the IRRs are now at better than 15.5%. So I think it's been a very good investment, a very good relationship and one that we look forward to continuing into the future.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to John Pawlowski with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: And we'll go next to John Pawlowski with Green Street Advisors.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, thanks for the operating update for April on New York. Can you share new lease and renewal growth trends for April in San Francisco and what you're seeing heading into May?
componenttext: Jerry, thanks for the operating update for April on New York. Can you share new lease and renewal growth trends for April in San Francisco and what you're seeing heading into May?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I don't have May on me right now. But in April, San Francisco's new was 2.8%, and renewals were fairly stable with where they were in the first quarter at 7.5%.
componenttext: Sure. I don't have May on me right now. But in April, San Francisco's new was 2.8%, and renewals were fairly stable with where they were in the first quarter at 7.5%.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And lastly, what drove the decision to sell the 2 land parcels in California?
componenttext: And lastly, what drove the decision to sell the 2 land parcels in California?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Harry. The 2 projects are in Santa Monica. They both have sort of retail-type operating assets on the parcels. And as we pursued the re-entitlement of those sites over the past several years, it became obvious to us that the city was not going to
componenttext: This is Harry. The 2 projects are in Santa Monica. They both have sort of retail-type operating assets on the parcels. And as we pursued the re-entitlement of those sites over the past several years, it became obvious to us that the city was not going to sort of cooperate and allow a rezoning of those assets and so we sold them to retail use.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, I really appreciate the market outlook for supply and job growth. Do you think that we also need to see wage growth accelerate to continue the success you've had in your renewal increases?
componenttext: Jerry, I really appreciate the market outlook for supply and job growth. Do you think that we also need to see wage growth accelerate to continue the success you've had in your renewal increases?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it would hurt, obviously. I still think even with the wage growth that we've been having over the last several years, we've seen and growing along with the rent growth we've had, we still have rent-to-income level that's pretty consistent wi
componenttext: I don't think it would hurt, obviously. I still think even with the wage growth that we've been having over the last several years, we've seen and growing along with the rent growth we've had, we still have rent-to-income level that's pretty consistent with where it has been at about 23%. And we haven't seen a huge spike in turnover. So we're not driving many more people out because of rent growth. But I think any time you can see some wage growth improvement, it's helpful. I'd say a couple of things that have helped somewhat is, for our suburban, especially B renters, lower gas prices have kind of supplemented their wage growth. And I think when you look at the more urban dwellers, I don't think, again, it's so much wage growth that's affecting us there. It's their ability to jump to new lease-up. But I'm never going to argue against wage growth. When you see indications that whether it's California or different cities in California or if Seattle has done rates in the minimum wage to $15 even though it'll put a little bit of expense pressure maybe on operators like us because it'll drive, even though we don't have many people that make below $15 an hour for unskilled job, when you have skills that will drive that gap up that I think overall, I think wage growth like that is going to be good for our sector and would help us to continue to drive rate.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Rob Stevenson with Janney.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, in Tampa and Orlando, I mean, at this rate, how long do you expect to be able to keep this up? And is it a situation where you worry about now that you're at sort of $1,200 a month rent for largely Class B product that you're getting into the point
componenttext: Jerry, in Tampa and Orlando, I mean, at this rate, how long do you expect to be able to keep this up? And is it a situation where you worry about now that you're at sort of $1,200 a month rent for largely Class B product that you're getting into the point where people can afford townhouses and condos in those markets and you could start seeing some move-outs accelerate?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, you always worry about that and you have worried about that in the past. Today, about 15% -- a little over 15% of our move-outs in Tampa are to purchase homes, so it's not huge. The people that qualify for the homes want to have to own a home  and
componenttext: I mean, you always worry about that and you have worried about that in the past. Today, about 15% -- a little over 15% of our move-outs in Tampa are to purchase homes, so it's not huge. The people that qualify for the homes want to have to own a home  and -- but do I think down in that market you continue to see high-single digit new and renewal growth for a prolonged period of time? No, I don't think it's going to last forever. I think it's been a very good multiyear run. I think it continues to run for another year or 2 because we're not being affected by new supply. Job growth has been better than in the past. It's been higher-quality biotech and medical jobs that have been coming to places like Orlando. But now, do I think it can continue at the levels it's at today for multiple years? I don't think so, but I don't think it decelerates rapidly in 2017 either.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harry, in terms of land, I mean, how aggressive are you guys being these days? And is there anything reasonably priced in your core markets? Or is it now sort of going to condo developers and other bidders at higher levels than you guys are comfortable bu
componenttext: Harry, in terms of land, I mean, how aggressive are you guys being these days? And is there anything reasonably priced in your core markets? Or is it now sort of going to condo developers and other bidders at higher levels than you guys are comfortable buying land for, for future development?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I guess, a couple of things: one, we're continuing to look at land sites in markets where we historically have built on the coast; in addition, we're continuing to work through the MetLife land bank and we've got projects in Seattle and L.A.
componenttext: Well, I mean, I guess, a couple of things: one, we're continuing to look at land sites in markets where we historically have built on the coast; in addition, we're continuing to work through the MetLife land bank and we've got projects in Seattle and L.A. in the East Bay. And I expect that we'll continue to grind through those and again expect to start some of those over the next couple of years. Really, if you think about it, the sites that we're looking at, these are going to be sort of late '17 into 2018 starts. And so when we're looking at the fundamentals of these markets where we have declining supply really in '17 and '18, these are going to be '19 and '20 deliveries. But to answer your question specifically, it is somewhat more challenging. Clearly, the number of -- the percentage of the projects that pencil today is much lower than it had been historically. But we expect to continue to find enough projects both externally and within our MetLife JV using consistent underwriting standards without any type of aggressive rent growth assumptions, but we will continue to maintain similar development pipeline as we have historically and fit within our $900 million to $1.4 billion type target.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Does this force you to do more sort of Santa Monica type of things where you have to buy stuff on the anticipation that you could try to get it rezoned and take that sort of risk out there these days in order to find sites?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily. It doesn't mean that we won't do a little bit of that. Again, we try to manage the amount of sort of preconstruction risks we take. But for example, if you look at a market like Boston where we just started a project and therefore we expe
componenttext: Not necessarily. It doesn't mean that we won't do a little bit of that. Again, we try to manage the amount of sort of preconstruction risks we take. But for example, if you look at a market like Boston where we just started a project and therefore we expect to start the next project some time in 2 or 3 years, clearly if we found an adequate site, it's conceivable that we would take some entitlement risk. But we don't necessarily think that's something that we're going to have to do a lot of.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked quite a bit about supply peaking everywhere, but New York in 2016 and I was just wondering how comfortable you are that 2016 will be the peak supply year because as long as you have strong fundamentals, high occupancy, positive rent growth, low
componenttext: You talked quite a bit about supply peaking everywhere, but New York in 2016 and I was just wondering how comfortable you are that 2016 will be the peak supply year because as long as you have strong fundamentals, high occupancy, positive rent growth, low cap rates. It may entice more people to build. It's working for you, right? So it might work for others. So just curious where your thoughts are on that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Toomey. A very good question. And one thing that we alluded to a couple of years ago when we saw the banking industry becoming further and further consolidated and regulated is, we realized the impact would be is the Feds would have the a
componenttext: Michael, this is Toomey. A very good question. And one thing that we alluded to a couple of years ago when we saw the banking industry becoming further and further consolidated and regulated is, we realized the impact would be is the Feds would have the ability to choke off construction loans. And what was currently seen in the marketplace, and if you talk to private developers, is securing a loan for new development in the multifamily space is getting very, very difficult. And you're going to see them do less in deals because it's going to require more equity, there's going to be less proceeds out of construction and tougher underwriting. I think that, combined with the transparency of operating environments and city's difficulty around zoning and entitlement processes, is going to slow it down a great deal. And I didn't hear any development in the last 3 months talking with a lot of private guys that said, hey, we think we're going to do more business in '17 than we're doing right now. Everybody looks at it and says, we're pulling back, we're being forced to pull back and we'll have to relook at our numbers and come up with more equity. So I think that's going to be the biggest chokepoint about new supply. It's certainly not the demand side of the equation. It is certainly there and will persist for many more years. It's the supply is going to get choked down.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's actually a good -- your answer's a good lead into my second question, which is you have an outlook out there through 2017. Do you think by the time we get to the end of that outlook, this dynamic between the suburbs outperforming the center city an
componenttext: That's actually a good -- your answer's a good lead into my second question, which is you have an outlook out there through 2017. Do you think by the time we get to the end of that outlook, this dynamic between the suburbs outperforming the center city and Bs doing better than As, do you think that dynamic will have started to shift by the end of 2017? Or do you think we'll still be in an environment like that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're asking a very broad question and it is hard to draw a blanket over the whole U.S. We can take individual markets and probably take it off-line and go through those. But my view on the long term is that a lot of developers are moving out to th
componenttext: Well, you're asking a very broad question and it is hard to draw a blanket over the whole U.S. We can take individual markets and probably take it off-line and go through those. But my view on the long term is that a lot of developers are moving out to the suburbs where they're building kind of an A minus product to a price point-sensitive customer and they're going to be able to put up a lot more doors quicker in that type of environment. And the suburbs, by the time '17 arrives, will be probably turning over. I think they're going to be a good spot for '16 and '17. But after that, I would suspect that they're going to start seeing the same supply pressures that we're seeing in some of the urban markets today. And so they'll probably start turning over then.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Alex, at the time that we acquired it, there was a -- Santa Monica was granting these sort of rezoning types of projects that would allow for a certain density in a lot of these sites. Shortly after we acquired it, the city basically shut down and I
componenttext: Well, Alex, at the time that we acquired it, there was a -- Santa Monica was granting these sort of rezoning types of projects that would allow for a certain density in a lot of these sites. Shortly after we acquired it, the city basically shut down and I remember in, I think, the year 2014, they issued something like 50 total building permits. And so basically, over the 3 years, it became obvious to us that we were not get going to get these sites rezoned anytime soon given that they had existing retail uses and we had retail buyers available. We decided to get rid of them.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's been a few things that have come up. There were some meetings last week or the week before in San Mateo that talked about properties built, I think, before 1980 or it's 20- to 30-year old product, but it seemed like it got shot down pretty quickly
componenttext: There's been a few things that have come up. There were some meetings last week or the week before in San Mateo that talked about properties built, I think, before 1980 or it's 20- to 30-year old product, but it seemed like it got shot down pretty quickly. But I can tell you this, our 2 deals in San Mateo are older than that. So if it passed, those potentially would be affected. The other ones that we've heard about, but we're not directly affected are, I think, it was a 90-day restriction on renewal growth in Oakland. I'm not positive if that passed or if it was just talked about, directly affect us. And then the other one that was getting talked about, I believe, was in San Jose, putting a -- moving the cap on renewals on rent-controlled buildings, I think it was going from 8% to 5%. Ours is not a rent-controlled building, so I don't think it would have any effect on us in San Jose and our asset there is a little bit newer. So at this point, I think the only one that potentially in the future could affect us if it did get passed, but again it seems like it got shot down pretty quickly by City Council would be in San Mateo.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you all of you for being on this call today. I know it was a long call, but I thought it was very fruitful to have a good dialogue and go through the markets in detail. Reminder to you, as I listen to the questions and reading the call notes,
componenttext: Well, thank you all of you for being on this call today. I know it was a long call, but I thought it was very fruitful to have a good dialogue and go through the markets in detail. Reminder to you, as I listen to the questions and reading the call notes, a lot of you right now are focused on the short term. And really, we're focused on the long-term aspects of the business, which do not remain anything but positive. The demographics are on our side, the supply demand curve is on our supply -- side to be able to execute our strategy, deliver solid, growing cash flow and paying dividends. And so I think the construct of the business is great, where we are from a strategic standpoint of being in the markets we're in, the mix of portfolios and the management team to execute on that. And so we think the future is very bright. We think, just as we've always tried to be, very transparent about the operations of the business. But when you back up and you look at the end result of the cash flow growth, the prospects for the balance of the year, in '17 as well, we're very excited about those prospects and eager to just keep working on those. And so with that, I'll close and we thank you and look forward to seeing many of you in the next conferences over the next couple of months. Take care.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to UDR's Second Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. Our second quarter press release and supplement disclosure package were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted on our Investor Section on our website, ir.udr.com.In the suppleme
componenttext:
Welcome to UDR's Second Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. Our second quarter press release and supplement disclosure package were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted on our Investor Section on our website, ir.udr.com.
In the supplement, we have reconciled all non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements.
I would like to note that statements made during this call, which are not historical may constitute forward-looking statements. Although we believe the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, we can give no assurance that our expectations will be met.
A discussion of risks and risk factors are detailed in yesterday's press release and included in our filings with the SEC. We do not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to our President and CEO, Tom Toomey.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's Second Quarter Conference Call. On the call with me today are Shawn Johnston, Interim Principal Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss our results
componenttext:
Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's Second Quarter Conference Call. On the call with me today are Shawn Johnston, Interim Principal Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss our results; as well as senior officers, Warren Troupe and Harry Alcock, who will be available during the Q&A portion of the call.
The second quarter of 2016 was another great quarter for UDR, with 8% AFFO growth, driven by strong revenue growth of 5.7% and continued leasing strength in the 400 million developments in lease-up. This is a direct reflection of the continued execution of our strategic plan.
At the core of our strategic plan are 4 elements: First, a focus on cash flow growth for our shareholders through operational excellence, which Jerry will touch on later. Second, an accretive development pipeline that can be fully self-funded. Third, our diversed portfolio mix of 20 markets with A and B communities in urban and suburban locations. And lastly, a safe, low levered balance sheet.
Combined, these 4 elements are designed to provide the greatest predictability of cash flow growth through a variety of economic cycles. This is reflected in our updated guidance range for the full year, with the midpoint resulting in 8% AFFO growth per share, which Shawn will touch on his remarks. 
Before I turn the call over to Shawn, I want to add a couple of comments on the recent departure of Tom Herzog, our former CFO. While Tom was an exceptional CFO, he left UDR with an impressive bench, and I feel confident in the skills of those in the finance and accounting team to be more than adequate to handle his absence. At this time, Shawn Johnston, our Chief Accounting Officer, is serving as our Interim Principal Financial Officer, while we evaluate both internal and external candidates. Shawn is an exceptional candidate for the role, and we're glad to have him serving in his interim capacity now.
With that, I will turn the call over to Shawn for additional comments on the quarter.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. The topics I will cover today include our second quarter results, a balance sheet update, and our third quarter and full year guidance update. Our second quarter earnings results were at the top end of our previously provided guidance. FFO,
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. The topics I will cover today include our second quarter results, a balance sheet update, and our third quarter and full year guidance update. 
Our second quarter earnings results were at the top end of our previously provided guidance. FFO, FFO as adjusted, and AFFO per share were $0.44, $0.45 and $0.41, respectively. Second quarter same-store revenue expense and NOI growth were 5.7%, 5.5% and 5.7%, respectively. Second quarter expense growth was elevated due to a higher-than-expected property tax assessment on our 2014 development completion in San Francisco.
Historically, San Francisco is value developments for tax purposes by using a mix of cost to construct and income capitalization. While we budgeted for a mix that was weighted more towards the income method and President would indicate, a 100% of the valuation was eventually based on income capitalization.
This unexpected assessment resulted in a charge of $2.2 million during the quarter. $1.1 million of this was attributable to the period that the community was included in our same-store population, and was recognized as additional same-store expense during the quarter. The remaining portion of the charge is for real estate taxes, while the community was in lease-up, which can be found in Attachment 5. 
Excluding this negative tax variance, quarterly same-store expense growth for the portfolio in the San Francisco Bay Area would have been 3.4% and 9.9%, respectively, versus the 5.5% and 33.1% realized.
Next, the balance sheet. At quarter end, our liquidity, as measured by cash and credit facility capacity, was $876 million. Our financial leverage, on an underappreciated cost basis, was 33.2%. 
Based on quarter end market cap, it was 23.6%, and inclusive of JVs, it was 28.1%. Our net debt-to-EBITDA was 5.3x, and inclusive of JVs, was 6.3x. All balance sheet metric improvements were ahead of our strategic plan.
I would like to point out a few changes to our supplemental package. First, you'll note that we have provided additional GAAP metrics in both our release and supplement, in response of the recent SEC interpretation regarding GAAP and non-GAAP metrics.
I'd also like to direct you to Attachment 15, or Page 28 of our supplement, where we have updated our full year guidance. We're now providing both our previous and updated guidance for ease of comparison. With that, we have tightened our full year 2016 AFFO per share guidance range to $1.76 to $1.80, and tightened and increased our FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance ranges to $1.77 to $1.80, and $1.61 to $1.64 respectively.
A few key items have impacted our original guidance. First, our same-store portfolio is performing in line with original guidance, but our MetLife properties, which are primarily urban A, have underperformed our expectations. This underperformance has been offset by the outperformance of our development lease ups.
Second, the S&P 500 inclusion trade resulted in some deletion. However, this issuance gave us the flexibility to change the timing of other plan 2016 capital events, to offset the majority of the dilution, and ultimately resulted in an improved balance sheet.
Lastly, we expect a reduction on our full year incentive compensation, which is partially offset by higher-than-expected healthcare costs, resulting in a net reduction to G&A expense of $2 million at the midpoint.
A few other specifics from the page. We increased our sources guidance by $75 million at the midpoint, to a range of $650 million to $750 million for the year. This is due to an increase in planned dispositions, which we now anticipate being approximately $400 million for the year.
In addition to the $400 million of sales, we have issued $174 million of common equity, with the remainder of our sources coming from secured debt refinancings. We do not anticipate any additional equity issuances through the remainder of the year. 
Our debt maturities increased by $60 million as we have accelerated the accretive prepayment on some existing secured debt to the earliest possible date without penalty.
Additionally, we reduced our development, redevelopment and land acquisition guidance by $50 million at the midpoint, due to timing expense and we increased our acquisition guidance by $100 million in order to satisfy some section 1031 exchanges that we would like to complete this year. 
For same-store, our full year 2016 guidance remains unchanged, with revenue growth of 5.5% to 6%; expense, 3% to 3.5%; and NOI growth of 6.5% to 7%. Average 2016 occupancy remains forecasted at 96.6%. 
Third quarter 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance is $0.44 to $0.46, $0.44 to $0.46 and $0.39 to $0.41 respectfully. Finally, we declared a quarterly common dividend of $0.295 in the second quarter, or $1.18 per share when annualized, 6% above 2015's level, which represents the yield of approximately 3.2%. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jerry.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shawn, and good afternoon. In my remarks, I will cover the following topics. first, our second quarter performance metrics, leasing trends and rental rate growth we realized this quarter and early results for the third quarter. Second, how our pri
componenttext:
Thanks, Shawn, and good afternoon. In my remarks, I will cover the following topics. first, our second quarter performance metrics, leasing trends and rental rate growth we realized this quarter and early results for the third quarter. Second, how our primary markets performed during the quarter. And last, a brief update on our development lease ups. 
We're pleased to announce another strong quarter of operating results. In the second quarter, thanks to our net operating income, grew 5.7%. These results were driven by a 5.7% year-over-year increase in revenue, against a 5.5% increase in expenses. 
Year-to-date, through June 30, we have achieved NOI growth of 6.8%, behind revenue growth of 6% and expense growth of 4.1%.  Our same-store revenue, per occupied home, increased 6% year-over-year to $1,921 per month, while same-store occupancy of 96.6% was down 30 basis points versus the prior year period. 
Total portfolio revenue, per occupied home, was $2,027 per month, including pro rate JVs. Although we are feeling the impact of new supply in a few of our core markets, namely San Francisco and New York, a positive continued the outweigh the negatives, stable job growth, new household formations that are delaying home purchase, choosing to rent as well as empty nester baby boomers moving to an urban setting with the lift work lay atmosphere.
Our portfolio mix benefits from each of these scenarios. Turning to new and renewal lease rate growth, which detailed on Attachment 8G of our supplement. We grew our new lease rates by 4.4% in the second quarter, 330 basis points below the second quarter of 2015. Renewal growth remained robust at 6.3% in the second quarter, or 70 basis points behind last year.
On a blended rate basis, we averaged 5.3% during the second quarter, a reduction of 210 basis points versus the same period last year. If you look at the 76% of the same-store portfolio not located in New York and San Francisco, our decline in blended rate growth was only 100 basis points.
I'd like to point out the exceptional growth we achieved in 2015 was an anomaly, we are now back to a normal operating environment. Typically, renewal rate growth outpaces new lease rate growth by at least 100 basis points.
Because we were able to drive occupancy in late 2014 to the 96.5% to 97% level, we're able to push new lease growth in the peak leasing season in 2015, higher than that of renewal leases. 2016 has proven to be a more normalized year, with renewal growth outpacing new lease rate growth.
While we wish every year could be a strong as 2015, we are very happy with the strength seen in 2016 thus far, especially given that we are currently dealing with peak deliveries in the majority of our markets.
Next, moves out to home purchased were up 150 basis points year-over-year at 14.1%. And even with our strong renewal increases in the second quarter, less than 9% of our move outs gave rent increase as the reason for leaving.
Now moving on to the quarterly performance in our primary markets, which represents 70% of our same-store NOI and 75% of our total NOI. Metro DC, which represents 19% of our total NOI and 14% of our same-store NOI, posted year-over-year same-store revenue growth of 1.8%, a slight deceleration from first quarter, due primarily to very strong bad debt collections in the second quarter of 2015.
We are forecasting the market to generate top line growth in 2016 of between 2% and 3% as we will continue to benefit from our diverse 50-50 mix of A and B assets located both inside and outside the Beltway.
Our B product outperformed our As during the quarter, by 170 basis points, as sporadic supply issues continued to make for choppy results in some infill locations.
Orange County in Los Angeles combined, represents 16% of our total NOI and about 17% of our same-store NOI. Orange County posted year-over-year revenue growth of 8.9%, with both our As and Bs performing well above 8%, and all submarkets remaining very strong as we face very limit in supply.
Revenue growth in Los Angeles was 5.2% during the quarter. Our same-store portfolio is primarily concentrated within the Marina del Rey submarket, and is currently facing over 2,000 units of new supply, which we expect will be fully absorbed by year end. We continued to see good job growth in the supply picture improving in 2017 for our same-store L.A. portfolio.
New York City, which represents 12% of our total NOI and 13% of same-store NOI, posted 4.6% revenue growth for the quarter. While our same-store properties are not directly affected by any new developments, we are feeling the impact from new supply of the Manhattan market, as new lease growth during the quarter was 1.9%.  New Yorkers, who typically have been loyal to their preferred neighborhoods, are being enticed by pricing incentives in places like Midtown West.
For full year 2016, we expect New York to have revenue growth in the low 4% range, below our original estimates of approximately 5.5%. San Francisco which represents about 11% of both our total and same-store NOI, is continuing to feel the effects of new supply in several submarkets, including Southwood market. However, we still expect the Bay Area to be one of our best-performing markets this year, with revenue growth between 6% and 7%. 
Same-store revenue growth in the second quarter was 6.3%, due to the extremely strong blended rate growth we achieved in the third quarter of 2015. We currently see our portfolio being affected by lease up pressures through the middle of 2017.
Boston, which represents 7% of our total NOI and about 5% of same-store NOI, produced a strong 6.1% revenue growth during the second quarter. Our suburban assets in the North Shore, where our strongest performers, with growth over 7.5%. 
Even with new supply downtown, our one same-store asset in the Back Bay posted revenue growth of 4% for the quarter.
The Seaport District, home to our 2015 completion, 100 Pier 4, and the South end District, home to our under construction community, 345 Harrison, continued to see more growth with additional office and retail tenants in the submarket.
Seattle, which represents 6% of our total and same-store NOI, posted strong revenue growth of 8.5% for the quarter. 16% of our portfolio is B product, which posted revenue growth of 12.3%, while our A quality communities produced 6.6% growth. We continued to benefit from the strong growth inherent in these suburban B assets, which are located in submarkets that are less exposed to new supply.
Even with new supply pressure, our Bellevue assets posted revenue growth of 6.8% for the quarter, or revenue growth in downtown Seattle was essentially flat.
Last, Dallas, which represents just over 4% of our total and same-store NOI, posted 5% year-over-year same-store growth in the second quarter. Our B properties revenue growth that was 500 basis points higher than our As, is having new supply in uptown and along the tollways impacting rent growth in those submarkets.
While new supply remains elevated, we expect deliveries to decline after this year, and are confident they will be observed by the strengthened diversified job market in Dallas.
Our secondary markets, not just Portland, binary Peninsula, Florida, Asheville and Austin, which comprise roughly 20% of our portfolio, continued to have strong pricing power due to limited amounts of new supply and robust job growth. Our expectations that these models have a long runway of growth due to favorable economics.
July results came in, in line with our plan. As we look ahead to the next 2 months, we see stable pricing power and occupancy. Our 50-50 AB portfolio located throughout 20 markets, is enabled outperformance in our Sun Belt markets, Orange County, Seattle, Boston, Portland and Monterey, to offset markets that are being impacted by new supply, namely San Francisco, New York and Los Angeles.
I'll turn now to our 4 in lease-up developments, which you can find on Attachments 9A and 9B, or Pages 21 and 22 of our supplement. Our pro rata share of these 4 properties represents over $400 million or roughly 30% of our pipeline, inclusive of the West Coast development joint venture. In total, these properties are performing ahead of plan.
First, 399 Fremont, our 447 home, $318 million 50-50 MetLife JV lease-up in San Francisco, was 50% leased and 43% occupied at quarter end. Today, we are 57% leased and 48% occupied, with rents exceeding pro forma. We are currently offering 6 weeks concession as we begun to see increased competition from other lease ups in the submarket.
Over the last month, we have taken over 30 leases. The following 3 communities are all part of the West Coast development joint venture. [indiscernible] 1, our 399 home, $138 million lease-up in Anaheim, California, was 65% leased and 58% occupied at quarter end. And as of today, is 72% leased and 64% occupied. We are currently offering less than one month of concessions at this community, and leasing remains very strong, with about 30 applications per month.
8N Republican, our 211 home, $97 million lease-up in the South lake Union submarket of Seattle was 47% leased and 37% occupied at quarter end, and is currently 60% leased and 46% occupied, and we are averaging over one application per day.
CityLine, our 244 home, $80 million lease-up in the Columbia City submarket of Seattle, was 87% leased and 84% occupied at quarter end. Today, the property is 89% leased and 86% physically occupied.
All in, we had a very strong second quarter and we remained very positive on the outlook for multifamily fundamentals and our ability to execute throughout the remainder of 2016.
With that, we will open up the call to Q&A. Operator?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Nick Joseph with Citi.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, just sticking with operations, you outlined A versus B performance across many of the markets and with the 50-50 diversified portfolio, I think you have a unique perspective on this, so wouldn't you expect that spread between As and Bs to contract?
componenttext: Jerry, just sticking with operations, you outlined A versus B performance across many of the markets and with the 50-50 diversified portfolio, I think you have a unique perspective on this, so wouldn't you expect that spread between As and Bs to contract? And when could A has actually outperformed Bs, just given the current supply picture?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, and I tell you it varies market-by-market. But overall we stated this polity for the last 2 to 3 quarters. You know we would see A is getting closer to B, probably midyear next year, maybe a little bit after that. And then as you get
componenttext: It's a good question, and I tell you it varies market-by-market. But overall we stated this polity for the last 2 to 3 quarters. You know we would see A is getting closer to B, probably midyear next year, maybe a little bit after that. And then as you get deeper into '18, I think A is probably start competing more head-to-head with Bs. But it's definitely market dependent. For example, I would think in Washington, D.C, we've seen that spread contract and expand multiple times. Last quarter, it was about 50 basis points where Bs were outperforming. This quarter, we expanded to 1.7, but we do see a slowdown of new supply affecting our product in DC over the next 1.5 years. So I do think As because there typically better locations, by the second half of next year, should start doing much better there. When you look at a place like New York, it's probably a little more prolonged, call it may be even 2019 or further, where we see Bs continuing to outperform. And in San Francisco, I think it's similar, you're going to see supply continue to affect the market in some places like that, at least through the middle of next year. And I think that will cost As to continue to have to go head-to-head against new supply well into '18. So I think San Francisco, New York, Dallas, Austin, it's probably pushed out a bit, but several of the other markets that's saw new supply come a little bit earlier it's shorter. But on average, I'm guessing, it gets closer in late '17, and probably pulls even in '18.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And then as part of the 2-year outlook, you put out 2017 operating assumptions. You've maintained 2016 same-store revenue growth, just wondering if there's any update to the 2017 estimate of 4.75 to 5.25?
componenttext: Thanks. And then as part of the 2-year outlook, you put out 2017 operating assumptions. You've maintained 2016 same-store revenue growth, just wondering if there's any update to the 2017 estimate of 4.75 to 5.25?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I can tell you, clearly, we saw deceleration coming in 2017. As you said, we put that in our 2-year outlook. And you know, the range was the 4.75 to 5.25, which implied about a 75-basis-point decline from 2016. And we're continuing to project a slowd
componenttext: Yes. I can tell you, clearly, we saw deceleration coming in 2017. As you said, we put that in our 2-year outlook. And you know, the range was the 4.75 to 5.25, which implied about a 75-basis-point decline from 2016. And we're continuing to project a slowdown in '17, based on a lower blended rate growth in '16 compared to '15. But at this point, it's probably a little early to give guidance on where we think '17 is going to come in. We still don't have great visibility on pricing for September through the end the fourth quarter of this year and we really haven't fine tuned our expectations yet for 2017. So a little bit early, but it's probably leaning towards the lower end of that range.

componenttext: You know, it depends. The difference between an A and a B in Dallas is probably $250 to $300. When you get to New York, it's probably north of $1000 differential. San Francisco, it's going to be $800 to $1000. So we can vary, but you're typically looking at it, getting close to $1000 in some of the high-rise and urban markets in the coast. And when you get into the Sun Belt, it can contract down to just a couple of hundred dollars.

componenttext: Second half of the year, the blend, you know, we're looking at it being low 4s. Probably you're going to see in the second half. I can tell you this, renewals for July are coming in on an effective basis at about 5.9%. And you know as you look at the next month or 2, it's probably going to stay in that 5 7, 5 8 range. But in the fourth quarter, it will come down, probably mid-5s. And then we're seeing new lease rate growth in July is currently at about 3.2%. And our expectation would be it will just come down a hair. Over the last 3 months, we really -- we saw pricing last year in the fourth quarter come down a bit, so we're not anniversary-ing off such high prices. But yes, second half, it's probably going to be low 4s compared to the 5 3 that we have in the first half.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few quick questions. Jerry, on the operations, on the first quarter call, you guys were -- early in the year, you guys were asked about the high guidance and actually Herzog explained how the same-store NOI guidance, what the leak it was that it wa
componenttext: Just a few quick questions. Jerry, on the operations, on the first quarter call, you guys were -- early in the year, you guys were asked about the high guidance and actually Herzog explained how the same-store NOI guidance, what the leak it was that it wasn't necessarily translating into FFO growth, but now this quarter, where we see some of your peers dialing back their expectations for the year, what are some of the things that caused you guys to be able to maintain such a high guidance range? Is it the amount of lease that you have? Or just the fact that in your portfolio mix, you still have markets by Dallas, Norfolk, and other markets that are represented in some of the other -- in some of your other bicoastal peers?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start, first, I'll remind you we got out of Norfork in the fourth quarter of last year. So it's gone. But yes, I think a big part of it that you have to consider is we really drove rate very strongly in the second half [indiscernible] benefits t
componenttext: Yes, I'll start, first, I'll remind you we got out of Norfork in the fourth quarter of last year. So it's gone. But yes, I think a big part of it that you have to consider is we really drove rate very strongly in the second half [indiscernible] benefits this year. And when you look at the -- we anticipated there'll be a deceleration in rate growth that we get this year, and that has happened. And while I'll say directionally and in total, that reduction was pretty close, we missed on a market-by-market basis. For example, 29% of our portfolio, which is made of New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles, were missing our numbers. We came into the year thinking San Francisco would be an 8, now we think it's probably get end up at a 6.5. We thought New York was going to be high 5s, now we think it's going to be low 4s. And Los Angeles, you know we came in taking it's going to be call it a 7, and now we think it's going to be mid-5s. What we have, that a lot of people don't, is the diversified portfolio. In 20 markets, we've got the 50-50 split between A, Bs and urban. And what's really helping us is that 42% of our portfolio is performing better than we'd expected coming into the year, so it's offsetting those 3 markets that are doing work. So those are markets like Seattle, which I think all of us are doing well in right now, are Orange County portfolio with 8.9% revenue growth in the second quarter is doing exceptionally well. We're doing very well in Boston, where we have predominantly a suburban portfolio in our same-store pool. You know we held up about a little north of a 6 revenue there. The 2 markets in Florida, both Orlando and Tampa, are doing better than we expected. Nashville is on fire right now. And again, we're very suburban B there, we're not being impacted at all by the new supply. And then you have our Monterey in Portland portfolios that are doing well. So the beauty of our portfolio with that diversification is we're not dependent on a couple of markets doing well or not doing well. We realized diversified approach is in a continued to help us in the future because all markets are good and go through their natural cycle, so will always have some that are doing better, some that are doing worse. So I think it's more of the portfolio diversification that's really helping us [indiscernible]

componenttext: Yes. I think there's still a couple of markets that we probably are ready to exit a little more quickly than others. And I think Harry will talk soon as I get off this on which was are looking at and our disposition program this year. But markets that we've historically talk about that were not warehouse and we kind of stopped talking about that, because we really come to realize there good, strong markets, they're going to perform well over the long term. This is like Florida, again Orlando, Nashville, Tampa, places like that, I think we're satisfied to stay there over the midterm and probably long term. There's no rush to exit. But you know, will selectively sell assets and at times get out of markets to fund the development pipeline. But maybe Harry can give you a little bit more input on what we're looking to sell this year.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Alex, in the short term, we're always looking at the which assets to sell to fund our development pipeline. In particular, this year we've looked at we intent to sell Baltimore, or at least sell down our Baltimore portfolio to some extent. We have a group of assets in the market today. We're also going to sell a couple of properties in Dallas for the balance of the year.
