headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, Alex, as you know, we look at all these trades in the context of [indiscernible] adjusted return for the shareholders. La Jolla, the effective land price was over $400,000 per unit, which is a price that's unheard of in Los Angeles. We were ab
componenttext: Sure. Well, Alex, as you know, we look at all these trades in the context of [indiscernible] adjusted return for the shareholders. La Jolla, the effective land price was over $400,000 per unit, which is a price that's unheard of in Los Angeles. We were able to monetize most or all of our future development gain today and then convert this one-time gain into another structure deal, where we received nearly 7% return in our capital. It's while it's different in both in Steele Creek, it's another example of how we deployed capital in accretive transactions.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just turning back to the guidance, specifically same-store revenue growth, where you've done 6% year-to-date. And for the year, you're saying 5.5% to 6% is the range, how should we think about what level of conservatism is built into guidance, bec
componenttext: I guess just turning back to the guidance, specifically same-store revenue growth, where you've done 6% year-to-date. And for the year, you're saying 5.5% to 6% is the range, how should we think about what level of conservatism is built into guidance, because it doesn't seem to imply much of a deceleration in the back half of the year?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Jerry. I can tell you right now, we look at our model, we're coming in right in the midpoint of guidance. You know, there's a couple of things that can push us -- there's really one thing that could push us to the top end, and that woul
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Jerry. I can tell you right now, we look at our model, we're coming in right in the midpoint of guidance. You know, there's a couple of things that can push us -- there's really one thing that could push us to the top end, and that would be if we get a significant occupancy pick up, and we have been pushing to drive occupancy a little bit higher over the last month or 2. You know, the thing that could drive us in the bottom is if we see a further degeneration in operating fundamentals. And typically, those would probably have to come with more downside than we projected. And really New York and San Francisco, since the other ones has been reacting kind of stable. There's a couple of things though, because I get what you're talking about, we've got a 6 or so in the first half of the year, which would imply second half would be a 5 5, but there's a few things to keep in mind. This year, so far, we've had 6.3% rent per occupied home growth, that's been offset by about 30-basis-point decline in occupancy. We had very difficult occupancy comps in the first half of last year. Our occupancy in the second half of last year decelerated about 20 or 30 bps. Now still very high at 96 6, if it wasn't at 96 8, 96 9. Our expectation and what we're shooting for this year is to have a positive spread over last year's occupancy, so we're not going to be losing revenue growth because of an occupancy decline. We're hoping we get a little bit of pick up from that. And then the second thing, just that's interesting, is our fee income is up almost 10% year-over-year, and we would expect that to continue through the second half of the year, and that's really coming partially from lease break fees. People electing to move and relocate for jobs or buy houses or things like that. But the second part is, we started working on an initiative in the second half of last year, to drive higher revenues from our parking rent, which was an initiative we began working on, like I said, late last year, but we've got the fruits of it this year, to find a way to increase this underoptimize-ed real estate. So you've got 6% of our your revenue stock coming from fee income that's growing at a much higher rate than my rents. And you know, is -- how optimistic or pessimistic or conservative is our that midpoint, you know right now, we've factored in, like I said earlier that we think the blended rate growth for the second half of the year is going to be low 4s. Again you're looking at renewal growth in the low 5s, and new lease rate growth, may be right around 3, and that seems to us to be pretty sustainable right now.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay., I guess one other follow-up on that, you did talk about the second half blended lease growth of low 4%. But sounds like there's other items in your sort of revenue there are helping as you mentioned fee income, et cetera. So I guess the point is, we shouldn't really be using that low 4% lease rate growth as sort of a directionally where your same-store revenue growth is heading? How should we think about that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll tell you this, your lease rate growth, or what we get from new rents or renewals, benefits you over the next 12 months. So a portion of what we're realizing in the third quarter of this year is based on the very strong lease rate growth and ren
componenttext: Well, I'll tell you this, your lease rate growth, or what we get from new rents or renewals, benefits you over the next 12 months. So a portion of what we're realizing in the third quarter of this year is based on the very strong lease rate growth and renewal growth that we got at the end of last year. So it continues to pay benefits for the next 12 months. So what I'm telling you that I'm going to do over the next 6 months has some benefit over the next 6 months, but it also has a benefit over the following 6 months. So you can't just look at my current, what are my signing leases for, because that's only for the percentage of residents or expirations that are happening at that time.

componenttext: It does build. Yes, you're right, I mean it does build into 2017. The other thing is though, what are rents are going to do next year? So some of it's dependent on how we do next year, but you're right, we are building up part of our rent roll right now for 2017.

componenttext: Yes. That's about half of it. We're getting a portion -- we'll probably pick up a little over $1 million, $1.2 million this year of additional revenue from parking, and that's just basically. And it's predominantly in garden communities, charging people for parking and determining which spaces are the most preferable and trying to monetize that. But the other big mover is lease break fees, where somebody wants to cancel their lease ahead of the natural exploration day.

componenttext: Jerry, when you look at 2017 deliveries in the New York area, is that -- how much of that is concentrated in Manhattan? And would be sort of direct competition for you guys versus how much of that's stuff is in Queens and Brooklyn, where you don't have any assets?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: A quick question, I think I remember you asking at the outset of this call that you are seeing a little bit more supply pressures in the L.A. market, that's maybe a little bit different than some of the commentary we've heard from some of your peers. So I'm curious, how much of that is driven versus by Class A versus Class B? And are you actually starting to see more supply pickup? And maybe the Class B space versus the Class A?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a good question. I mean here's what the deal is, 90% of our same-store portfolio is located in Marina del Rey, so it's 3 properties, over Marina. Marina is about a 2-mile drive to Playa Vista, where all the tech firms are relocating to the area
componenttext:
Yes. It's a good question. I mean here's what the deal is, 90% of our same-store portfolio is located in Marina del Rey, so it's 3 properties, over Marina. Marina is about a 2-mile drive to Playa Vista, where all the tech firms are relocating to the area called Silicon Beach.
We've got 2 lease-ups occurring in Playa Vista right now, one is a 1,500 unit deal, the other one I think is 400 units, but they're coming in offering concessions of 1 to 2 months free. And what it's really done, it's directly impacting my 3 properties in Los Angeles that make up 90% of my portfolio. So yes. I don't think any of my peers would be feeling the same thing, because they don't have as much concentration in one submarket in Los Angeles as I have.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Richard Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Next, we have Richard Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're a little lax on headphones here in Brazil. I guess, you said something interesting earlier about how you're kind of abandoning, maybe Jerry, abandoning this warehousing concepts, and thinking about keeping some assets in some markets in the portf
componenttext: So we're a little lax on headphones here in Brazil. I guess, you said something interesting earlier about how you're kind of abandoning, maybe Jerry, abandoning this warehousing concepts, and thinking about keeping some assets in some markets in the portfolio. And so I was wondering if you could talk about any other adjustments you're making to the strategy, like that because one of them I recall we've spent some time together last year, the 50-50 Class A, Class B could actually morph into more like 60 or 70 Class A overtime. Do you feel like maybe there's an adjustment there that you'll make in the current environment, kind of like how you're adjusting yourr warehousing kind of concept?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Toomey. I think abandoning or changing is probably a little bit of an overstatement. I think what we're doing is constantly weighing our market mix and the price point and what we think cash flow is going to grow at. And so when we think we'
componenttext: Rich, this is Toomey. I think abandoning or changing is probably a little bit of an overstatement. I think what we're doing is constantly weighing our market mix and the price point and what we think cash flow is going to grow at. And so when we think we've market, for example, where Baltimore has performed in the last 5 years averaging 3% growth, we kind of look out the next 5 years and say, we don't think it's really going to change a whole lot, where else do we think we can redeploy that capital in the enterprise? Most immediately, in the development pipeline. So we're always revisiting our markets. On the balance of 50-50, the As that we're putting in today, 10 years from now, will be Bs. And so I think we'll probably hover around the 50-50, it might go 60-40, but I don't see a long-term directional change in that allocation. I think what ultimately we're trying to build, and have done so far and will continue to refine, is building cash flow, and where we see it can grow the best. And concentrated positions create concentrated risks. And so we're always going to have this diversification. We think, over time, it works. Some markets having Bs work better than As. Other cases where we look at jobs, where they think they're coming up in the price point, As are going to be better. So I think that's the overriding doctrine that we're overall thinking about our capital allocation and decisions. And markets from time to time, Florida is an example right now, talking off-the-cuff is going to enjoy another couple of year run, but the supply will start coming at Florida in the near future, and then we'll look at how we feel about our assets positioned in that market, and rather we should move more capital out of that into other places where opportunities will become available.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up, was there anything in the QR print that kind of cost used to at least take another look at your numbers and make sure you aren't missing anything, it mean there is one kind of cynical view is that the rest of the group is go
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up, was there anything in the QR print that kind of cost used to at least take another look at your numbers and make sure you aren't missing anything, it mean there is one kind of cynical view is that the rest of the group is going to have to revisit guidance, not this quarter, but maybe next quarter. And just curious if there was any level of reaction on your part from seeing that process going take effect?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, I'm not going to comment on EQR nor the results and their outlook, what I'm going to say is that Jerry and his team, run a culture from the bottom up, focusing greatly on what's going on in the ground, we forecasting to this is constantly, monitorin
componenttext: Rich, I'm not going to comment on EQR nor the results and their outlook, what I'm going to say is that Jerry and his team, run a culture from the bottom up, focusing greatly on what's going on in the ground, we forecasting to this is constantly, monitoring our traffic, our pricing power, and that feeds right up to us on a weekly basis, and we discuss how does that fit in our outlook for the future. And we're very comfortable with the guidance we just given. We feel like a lot of the year is pretty much behind us. There's not a lot of leases to price in that fourth quarter window. And we're trying to really focus our '17. And I think that's a credit to his team, to Shawn and his efforts in forecasting FP&L, that we have a pretty darn good handle on exactly where we're at, what are the levers that we can move and what's our range of outcomes, and that's why we tighten guidance the way we did. But we feel very good about the guidance we've given. And it's a credit to Jerry and his operating team, but also the portfolio in a way it's positioned.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, rent growth across a number of Sun Belt markets, namely Dallas, Tampa and Orlando, for example, seemed to have decelerated throughout the quarter, are you expecting a re-acceleration in the back half of the year across some of these Sun Belt market
componenttext: Jerry, rent growth across a number of Sun Belt markets, namely Dallas, Tampa and Orlando, for example, seemed to have decelerated throughout the quarter, are you expecting a re-acceleration in the back half of the year across some of these Sun Belt markets?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, Dallas I think is going to continue to be difficult. It's -- there's heavy new supply there. Our B product is continuing to do well, but we've got properties in uptown as well as Plana, that are going up against new supply. So I think you're goi
componenttext: You know, Dallas I think is going to continue to be difficult. It's -- there's heavy new supply there. Our B product is continuing to do well, but we've got properties in uptown as well as Plana, that are going up against new supply. So I think you're going to continue to see a struggle in Dallas, but I don't think it's getting get any worse. I think when you look at the other Sun Belts, Orlando and Tampa, I think you're going to see Orlando turn back around. What happened in the quarter, second quarter, is we probably got a bit aggressive on renewal growth where we're popping out 7.9%, and it opened the backdoor a little, put a little pressure on occupancy levels and we had to cut new lease rate growth to get occupancy back up. Our occupancy in Orlando today is 97.1%, that compares to an average of 96 5 during the second quarter. And we see new lease growth in the month of July jumped back up to 6.6% compared to the 4 9 that we reported in 2Q. So I think Orlando feels good. And then Tampa just feel stable. You know, we've had a few lease ups in a submarket of Tampa that's affected us and I think they're starting to stabilize now, and I think our numbers will too.

componenttext: This is Harry, so I think there's a couple of questions there. One, we sell a number of properties every year to fund -- a bucket of capital to fund have various uses, including specifically development. We do have a 1031 opportunity that we're going to look at. The pricing on the acquisition, we think, is likely to be generally market. Have a look at markets, such as DC, Boston, Southern California, Northern California, Seattle, to redeploy to capital. We think that will be largely market. I think cap rates on the sales, typically are Baltimore assets, are going to be are somewhere in the neighborhood of 6%. The cap rate on our one of our Dallas acquisitions that it's in the market today called [indiscernible] which is the MetLife JV assets, should be somewhere in the neighborhood of 5.25. We've got one additional Dallas asset that will definitely be a component of the 1031, and we think that's probably a mid-5s type trade.

componenttext: Sure. Yes, downtown is definitely our hardest hit submarket in Manhattan for same stores. But our 2 downtown properties had revenue growth in -- during the quarter of just under 3%. componenttextpreview: Sure. You know, when we look at DC, in '16, our expectation for new supply. Now ] I'll tell you we get this data from Axiometrics. So if you've got data is going to be roughly the same, but D C, '16 is about a 13,500 units, and '17 is projected to be abou
componenttext: Sure. You know, when we look at DC, in '16, our expectation for new supply. Now ] I'll tell you we get this data from Axiometrics. So if you've got data is going to be roughly the same, but D C, '16 is about a 13,500 units, and '17 is projected to be about 9,000. New York is going to go from 25,000 this year to 30,000 next year, and that is the one market we see where supply in our major markets is going to be higher next year than this year. San Francisco goes from about 13,000 to about 7,000. Seattle goes from about 10,000 to 6,000, and I guess the last market I would highlight is, we showed Dallas going from about 18,000 units this year to about 13,000 next year.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of your peers have commented that they maybe see numbers higher than would uses, is there any concern on your part that those numbers may be understated? And could your '17 figures could be under more pressure than where the numbers may currently s
componenttext: Couple of your peers have commented that they maybe see numbers higher than would uses, is there any concern on your part that those numbers may be understated? And could your '17 figures could be under more pressure than where the numbers may currently spit out to?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] this is Tom. This is an interesting topic, and I'm glad you kind of got us there. What is the supply picture look like in the future? Because I think everybody is got throwing around different numbers. I would tell you some anecdotal infor
componenttext: [indiscernible] this is Tom. This is an interesting topic, and I'm glad you kind of got us there. What is the supply picture look like in the future? Because I think everybody is got throwing around different numbers. I would tell you some anecdotal information that's critical to this conversation would be, is what are banks lending on? And what is the bank lending environment? And if you start digging into that with the bankers, you're realizing very rapidly that the terms on construction loans, the pricing on them and the availability is contracting at a rapid pace and we've seen several large banks just redline and say we're not doing multifamily loans any longer, or throwing up price terms that are prohibitive to make the deals work. So I think you're going to start to see the autos construction numbers start really coming down rapidly as people start to get into their construction loan draws, and trying to get their terms and their penciling work. I think it also creates an opportunity for UDR to look at Wolff and steel type creek opportunities that might start becoming available in '17 should this come to fruition. So I would stay very focused on what the supply of money looks like, the terms of that and watch how that ultimately unfolds. I know everybody's numbers are all over the map right now, but what I look at this what are the drivers. And it's not the opportunities, not the fundamentals, those are there, it's the question of capital and price of that capital and where deals work. And we'll stay focused on that, would be my recommendation for '17.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then on your opening remarks, Tom, you talked about being focused on operational excellence, and I think you had a little bit on the parking upside, any other things you could point to that you're working on that maybe would see some marg
componenttext: Okay, great. And then on your opening remarks, Tom, you talked about being focused on operational excellence, and I think you had a little bit on the parking upside, any other things you could point to that you're working on that maybe would see some margin upside? And any target commerce you could talk to?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Jerry clean it up, but I'll start with this. I mean, one, we're very a operationally focused company, and it comes a lot through innovation. So there's always, as you can see from our prior roadshows, we've always listed out initiatives that we'r
componenttext: I'll let Jerry clean it up, but I'll start with this. I mean, one, we're very a operationally focused company, and it comes a lot through innovation. So there's always, as you can see from our prior roadshows, we've always listed out initiatives that we're focused on. We have basically a biweekly meeting on innovation here, and we're talking about the products, the initiatives that we have underway, what's working, what's not. And we're always constantly pressing the next envelope for our customer. And we do a great job of listening to what they want and what they're willing to pay for. And it's Jerry and his team to filter through that innovation list and put it in a practical terms. This parking conversation that he alluded to earlier is really a conversation that started 2 years ago. And ultimately we built systems out, condense the field about the pricing scheme and they've done a great job of executing it. And I can tell you that the last count, there were 57 initiatives on that schedule, some will not work, many of them will. So we're going to continue to be innovative operationally. And that's how it makes the difference at the enterprise.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll give you a few examples. Tom spoke, and you mentioned the parking. Another one, and they're not all revenue enhancing, some are expense reducing. So we've -- and some are capital expenditures that get us there. But one is converting common area
componenttext: Yes, I'll give you a few examples. Tom spoke, and you mentioned the parking. Another one, and they're not all revenue enhancing, some are expense reducing. So we've -- and some are capital expenditures that get us there. But one is converting common area space, lighting, with LED lighting, which dramatically drops down both your electrical costs as well as the maintenance time people have to spend replacing those light bulbs. And we've seen a reduction in our electric cost this year from doing that. Secondly, package lockers, some people believe in them, and some people don't. I will tell you, we do. We've installed well over 40 lockers, we've got another 35, they're being installed right now. And we're doing it for 2 reasons: It's dealing with package management as a huge time slot on our on-site teams, so it opens them up to do more work that makes money for us. And secondly, it's a benefit that residents enjoy to have 24/7 access to pick up their own packages. So we get a little bit of a redemption pop from doing that too. And the package lockers have an IRR, when you look at it, a little over 25% to 30%. So financially it makes a lot of sense, but we always do things that the residents want and it typically is good for us. And you know, what both of those things do, you heard me mention on the LED lights that it takes less it gives it back sometime to our maintenance teams. You heard be on the package dollars, that we've been able to give some time back to our lease and maintenance because it if you look at our personnel numbers, personal expense number, you'll see that it's roughly flat for the quarter. We've been able to reduced about 1.5% to 2% of our site headcount this year because of some of these efficiencies that we've been able to do. So those are just a couple of examples, but like Timmy said, we're always looking, there are some that we'll spend a great deal of time, they don't work, but we're always trying to stretch for the next thing to expand our margins.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Toomey, we see it across the template. And so when we talk to people about how they're sourcing their capital, they happened to go to other pools of money, foreign banks, local regional banks, all of which do not have the capacity of our big natio
componenttext: This is Toomey, we see it across the template. And so when we talk to people about how they're sourcing their capital, they happened to go to other pools of money, foreign banks, local regional banks, all of which do not have the capacity of our big national banks. And so by virtue of just pricing and the size, we expect that will drive some of the geography of where supply is going to come. So it's going to start moving to the Sun Belts and it's start going to be moving suburban. And then also, I think it's going to decrease that urban pressure. So that's the way we see the market shifting.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, we can follow up. And then just separately, more bigger picture, it sounds like right now it's widely accepted that San Fran and New York are going to an adjustment phase, but these are markets that I think most come in below expectations and weaker
componenttext: Okay, we can follow up. And then just separately, more bigger picture, it sounds like right now it's widely accepted that San Fran and New York are going to an adjustment phase, but these are markets that I think most come in below expectations and weaker that even may be 6 months ago. But it doesn't sound like there's any assumption that other markets could follow that path, is that right? And then, I guess, what gives you confidence that there's not another one sort of uncertainty around the corner, especially with the urban portfolio? I understand the suburban protection, but in the urban environment where supply is pretty pronounced virtually across the country?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, Dennis, here's how I would think about it.  First, New York and San Francisco are not really surprises to us. The urban settings, when you see supply coming, you see it coming years in advance. Second, we've had great job growth in both those ma
componenttext: You know, Dennis, here's how I would think about it.  First, New York and San Francisco are not really surprises to us. The urban settings, when you see supply coming, you see it coming years in advance. Second, we've had great job growth in both those markets, and both of them have tapered off to more of the norm. And so that combination kind of gives you what those markets are. As we look towards the future, we don't see the big supply pressures coming in at the urban portfolios, but we do have a concern about job growth sustaining itself, and I think everybody should. And we'll wait and see how the election turns out, and how the economy turns out. But in both of those camps, that's the future will be what it's going to be. So I'm not at all surprised about those 2 markets. We're not surprised about our L.A. exposure, we saw it coming. What we see is this, these are supply driven numbers that are changing our pricing power. It is not the underlying fundamentals of demographics and/or job markets that are driving our business right out here those are still in very good shape. And so we're very focused on the supply pressure. And I think we have a very good handle on it, feel good about the way we're running the business to deal with that supply, when it updates, we think we're back to guns on pricing and we'll do very well in that environment.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, even though we don't see any markets right now, if one does pop up for, let's say, there's job loss in a particular market, or something like that, that goes back to the benefit of being in 20 markets and having that A B portfolio. Y
componenttext: And I would just add, even though we don't see any markets right now, if one does pop up for, let's say, there's job loss in a particular market, or something like that, that goes back to the benefit of being in 20 markets and having that A B portfolio. You got other markets that can counterbalance something like that.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you again for all of your time. Again, I think we had a very solid quarter on all fronts. Certainly, we remained focused on the strategic plan and the execution of it. A big part of that is just execution, and we're doing it right now. What i
componenttext: Great. Thank you again for all of your time. Again, I think we had a very solid quarter on all fronts. Certainly, we remained focused on the strategic plan and the execution of it. A big part of that is just execution, and we're doing it right now. What is the strategic plan focused on? Growing cash flow through all points in the cycle. We're going through one of those right now. You can see from our results, we're still able to sustain and guide to a strong cash flow number. And I think that's attribute to the team in the room, in particular, Jerry and his operating team, and they're focused on adjusting their strategies by individual assets, by unit types, to meet the market and get ahead of it, if you will. And also, we're enjoying a very good strong development pipeline that's leasing up very well and gives us confidence for the future. So with that, we thank you again for your time, and look forward to talking to you next quarter.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to UDR's Second Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. Our second quarter press release and supplemental disclosure package were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investor Relations section of our website, ir.udr.com. In t
componenttext:
Welcome to UDR's Second Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. Our second quarter press release and supplemental disclosure package were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investor Relations section of our website, ir.udr.com. In the supplement, we have reconciled all non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements.
I would like to note that statements made during this call, which are not historical may constitute forward-looking statements. Although we believe the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, we can give no assurance that our expectations will be met.
A discussion of risks and risk factors are detailed in yesterday's press release and included in our filings with the SEC. 
We do not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to our President and CEO, Tom Toomey.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's Second Quarter Conference Call. On the call with me today are Shawn Johnston, Interim Principal Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss our results
componenttext:
Thank you, Shelby, and good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to UDR's Second Quarter Conference Call. On the call with me today are Shawn Johnston, Interim Principal Financial Officer; and Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss our results; as well as senior officers, Warren Troupe and Harry Alcock, who will be available during the Q&A portion of the call.
The second quarter of 2016 was another great quarter for UDR with 8% AFFO growth, driven by strong revenue growth of 5.7% and continued leasing strength in the 400 million developments in lease-up. This is a direct reflection of the continued execution of our strategic plan.
At the core of our strategic plan are 4 elements: First, a focus on cash flow growth for our shareholders through operational excellence, which Jerry will touch on later. Second, an accretive development pipeline that can be fully self-funded. Third, our diversed portfolio mix of 20 markets with A and B communities in urban and suburban locations. And lastly, a safe, low-levered balance sheet.
Combined, these 4 elements are designed to provide the greatest predictability of cash flow growth through a variety of economic cycles. This is reflected in our updated guidance range for the full year, with the midpoint resulting in 8% AFFO growth per share, which Shawn will touch on in his remarks. 
Before I turn the call over to Shawn, I wanted to add a couple of comments on the recent departure of Tom Herzog, our former CFO. While Tom was an exceptional CFO, he left UDR with an impressive bench, and I feel confident in the skills of those in the finance and accounting team to be more than adequate to handle his absence. 
At this time, Shawn Johnston, our Chief Accounting Officer, is serving as our Interim Principal Financial Officer, while we evaluate both internal and external candidates. Shawn is an exceptional candidate for the role, and we are glad to have him serving in his interim capacity now.
With that, I will turn the call over to Shawn for additional comments on the quarter.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. The topics I will cover today include our second quarter results, a balance sheet update, and our third quarter and full year guidance update. Our second quarter earnings results were at the top end of our previously provided guidance. FFO,
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. The topics I will cover today include our second quarter results, a balance sheet update, and our third quarter and full year guidance update. 
Our second quarter earnings results were at the top end of our previously provided guidance. FFO, FFO as adjusted, and AFFO per share were $0.44, $0.45 and $0.41, respectively. Second quarter same-store revenue, expense and NOI growth were 5.7%, 5.5% and 5.7%, respectively. Second quarter expense growth was elevated due to a higher-than-expected property tax assessment on our 2014 development completion in San Francisco.
Historically, San Francisco is value developments for tax purposes by using a mix of cost to construct in income capitalization. While we budgeted for a mix that was weighted more towards the income method and then president would indicate 100% of the valuation was eventually based on income capitalization.
This unexpected assessment resulted in a charge of $2.2 million during the quarter, $1.1 million of this was attributable to the period that the community was included in our same-store population and was recognized as additional same-store expense during the quarter. The remaining portion of the charge is for real estate taxes, while the community was in lease-up, which can be found in Attachment 5. 
Excluding this negative tax variance, quarterly same-store expense growth for the portfolio in the San Francisco Bay Area would have been 3.4% and 9.9%, respectively, versus the 5.5% and 33.1% realized.
Next, the balance sheet. At quarter end, our liquidity, as measured by cash and credit facility capacity, was $876 million. Our financial leverage on an underappreciated cost basis was 33.2%. 
Based on quarter-end market cap, it was 23.6%, and inclusive of JVs, it was 28.1%. Our net debt-to-EBITDA was 5.3x, and inclusive of JVs, was 6.3x. All balance sheet metric improvements were ahead of our strategic plan.
I would like to point out a few changes to our supplemental package. First, you'll note that we have provided additional GAAP metrics in both our release and supplement in response to the recent SEC interpretation regarding GAAP and non-GAAP metrics.
I'd also like to direct you to Attachment 15 or Page 28 of our supplement, where we have updated our full year guidance. We are now providing both our previous and updated guidance for ease of comparison. With that, we have tightened our full year 2016 AFFO per share guidance range to $1.76 to $1.80 and tightened and increased our FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance ranges to $1.77 to $1.80 and $1.61 to $1.64, respectively.
A few key items have impacted our original guidance. First, our same-store portfolio is performing in line with original guidance, but our MetLife properties, which are primarily urban A, have underperformed our expectations. This underperformance has been offset by the outperformance of our development lease-ups.
Second, the S&P 500 inclusion trade resulted in some deletion. However, this issuance gave us the flexibility to change the timing of other plan 2016 capital events to offset the majority of the dilution and ultimately, resulted in an improved balance sheet.
Lastly, we expect a reduction on our full year incentive compensation, which is partially offset by higher-than-expected health care costs, resulting in a net reduction to G&A expense of $2 million at the midpoint.
A few other specifics from the page. We increased our sources guidance by $75 million at the midpoint to a range of $650 million to $750 million for the year. This is due to an increase in planned dispositions, which we now anticipate being approximately $400 million for the year.
In addition to the $400 million of sales, we have issued $174 million of common equity with the remainder of our sources coming from secured debt refinancings. We do not anticipate any additional equity issuances through the remainder of the year. 
Our debt maturities increased by $60 million as we have accelerated the accretive prepayment on some existing secured debt to the earliest possible date without penalty. Additionally, we reduced our development, redevelopment and land acquisition guidance by $50 million at the midpoint due to timing expense, and we increased our acquisition guidance by $100 million in order to satisfy some Section 1031 exchanges that we would like to complete this year. 
For same-store, our full year 2016 guidance remains unchanged with revenue growth of 5.5% to 6%; expense, 3% to 3.5%; and NOI growth of 6.5% to 7%. Average 2016 occupancy remains forecasted at 96.6%. 
Third quarter 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance is $0.44 to $0.46, $0.44 to $0.46 and $0.39 to $0.41, respectively. Finally, we declared a quarterly common dividend of $0.295 in the second quarter or $1.18 per share when annualized, 6% above 2015's level, which represents a yield of approximately 3.2%. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jerry.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shawn, and good afternoon. In my remarks, I will cover the following topics: First, our second quarter portfolio metrics, leasing trends and the rental rate growth we realized this quarter and early results for the third quarter. Second, how our p
componenttext:
Thanks, Shawn, and good afternoon. In my remarks, I will cover the following topics: First, our second quarter portfolio metrics, leasing trends and the rental rate growth we realized this quarter and early results for the third quarter. Second, how our primary markers performed during the quarter. And last, a brief update on our development lease-ups. 
We're pleased to announce another strong quarter of operating results. In the second quarter, thanks to our net operating income grew 5.7%, these results were driven by a 5.7% year-over-year increase in revenue against a 5.5% increase in expenses.
Year-to-date, through June 30, we have achieved NOI growth of 6.8%, behind revenue growth of 6% and expense growth of 4.1%. Our same-store revenue per occupied home increased 6% year-over-year to $1,921 per month, while same-store occupancy of 96.6% was down 30 basis points versus the prior year period. 
Total portfolio revenue per occupied home was $2,027 per month, including pro rata JVs. Although we are feeling the impact of new supply in a few of our core markets, namely San Francisco and New York, the positives we see continued to outweigh the negatives: stable job growth; new household formations that are delaying home purchase in choosing to rent; as well as empty nester baby boomers moving to an urban setting with the lift, work, play atmosphere. Our portfolio mix benefits from each of these scenarios. 
Turning to new and renewal lease rate growth, which is detailed on Attachment 8G of our supplement. We grew our new lease rates by 4.4% in the second quarter, 330 basis points below the second quarter of 2015. Renewal growth remained robust at 6.3% in the second quarter or 70 basis points behind last year.
On a blended rate basis, we averaged 5.3% during the second quarter, a reduction of 210 basis points versus the same period last year. If you look at the 76% of the same-store portfolio not located in New York and San Francisco, our decline in blended rate growth was only 100 basis points.
I'd like to point out the exceptional growth we achieved in 2015 was an anomaly. We are now back to a normal operating environment. Typically, renewal rate growth outpaces new lease rate growth by at least 100 basis points. Because we were able to drive occupancy in late 2014 to the 96.5% to 97% level, we're able to push new lease rate growth in the peak leasing season in 2015, higher than that of renewal leases. 2016 has proven to be a more normalized year with renewal growth outpacing new lease rate growth.
While we wish every year could be a strong as 2015, we are very happy with the strength seen in 2016 thus far, especially given that we are currently dealing with peak deliveries in the majority of our markets.
Next, move outs for home purchased were up 150 basis points year-over-year at 14.1%. And even with our strong renewal increases in the second quarter, less than 9% of our move outs gave rent increase as the reason for leaving.
Now moving on to the quarterly performance in our primary markets, which represents 70% of our same-store NOI and 75% of our total NOI. Metro D.C., which represents 19% of our total NOI and 14% of our same-store NOI, posted year-over-year same-store revenue growth of 1.8%, a slight deceleration from first quarter due primarily to very strong bad debt collections in the second quarter of 2015.
We are forecasting the market to generate top line growth in 2016 of between 2% and 3%, as we will continue to benefit from our diverse 50-50 mix of A and B assets located both inside and outside the Beltway.
Our B product outperformed our As during the quarter by 170 basis points, as sporadic supply issues continued to make for choppy results in some infill locations.
Orange County and Los Angeles combined represent 16% of our total NOI and about 17% of our same-store NOI. Orange County posted year-over-year revenue growth of 8.9% with both our As and Bs performing well above 8% and all submarkets remaining very strong as we face very little in the supply.
Revenue growth in Los Angeles was 5.2% during the quarter. Our same-store portfolio is primarily concentrated within the Marina del Rey submarket, and is currently facing over 2,000 units of new supply, which we expect will be fully absorbed by year-end. We continue to see good job growth in the supply picture improving in 2017 for our same-store L.A. portfolio.
New York City, which represents 12% of our total NOI and 13% of same-store NOI, posted 4.6% revenue growth for the quarter. While our same-store properties are not directly affected by any new developments, we are feeling the impact from new supply of the Manhattan market as new lease growth during the quarter was 1.9%. New Yorkers, who typically have been loyal to their preferred neighborhoods, are being enticed by pricing incentives in places like Midtown West.
For full year 2016, we expect New York to have revenue growth in the low 4% range, below our original estimates of approximately 5.5%. San Francisco, which represents about 11% of both our total and same-store NOI, is continuing to feel the effects of new supply in several submarkets, including Southwood market. However, we still expect the Bay Area to be one of our best-performing markets this year with revenue growth between 6% and 7%. 
Same-store revenue growth in the second quarter was 6.3% due to the extremely strong blended rate growth we achieved in the third quarter of 2015. We currently see our portfolio being affected by lease-up pressures through the middle of 2017.
Boston, which represents 7% of our total NOI and about 5% of same-store NOI, produced a strong 6.1% revenue growth during the second quarter. Our suburban assets in the North Shore were our strongest performers with growth over 7.5%. 
Even with new supply downtown, our one same-store asset in the Back Bay posted revenue growth of 4% for the quarter.
The Seaport District, home to our 2015 completion, 100 Pier 4, and the South End District, home to our under construction community, 345 Harrison, continued to see more growth with additional office and retail tenants in the submarket.
Seattle, which represents 6% of our total and same-store NOI, posted strong revenue growth of 8.5% for the quarter. 16% of our portfolio is B product, which posted revenue growth of 12.3%, while our A quality communities produced 6.6% growth. We continued to benefit from the strong growth inherent in these suburban B assets, which are located in submarkets that are less exposed to new supply.
Even with new supply pressure, our Bellevue assets posted revenue growth of 6.8% for the quarter or revenue growth in downtown Seattle was essentially flat.
Last, Dallas, which represents just over 4% of our total and same-store NOI, posted 5% year-over-year same-store growth in the second quarter. Our B properties revenue growth that was 500 basis points higher than our As is having new supply in uptown and along the tollways impacting rent growth in those submarkets.
While new supply remains elevated, we expect deliveries to decline after this year and are confident they will be observed by the strengthened diversified job market in Dallas.
Our secondary markets, not just Portland, Monterey Peninsula, Florida, Nashville and Austin, which comprise roughly 20% of our portfolio, continued to have strong pricing power due to limited amounts of new supply and robust job growth. Our expectation out of these markets have a long runway of growth due to favorable economics.
July results came in, in line with our plan. As we look ahead to the next 2 months, we see stable pricing power and occupancy. Our 50-50 AB portfolio located throughout 20 markets has enabled outperformance in our Sun Belt market, Orange County, Seattle, Boston, Portland and Monterey to offset markets that are being impacted by new supply, namely San Francisco, New York and Los Angeles.
I'll turn now to our 4 in lease-up developments, which you can find on Attachments 9A and 9B or Pages 21 and 22 of our supplement. Our pro rata share of these 4 properties represents over $400 million or roughly 30% of our pipeline, inclusive of the West Coast development joint venture. In total, these properties are performing ahead of plan.
First, 399 Fremont, our 447-home, $318 million 50-50 MetLife JV lease-up in San Francisco was 50% leased and 43% occupied at quarter end. Today, we are 57% leased and 48% occupied with rents exceeding pro forma. We are currently offering 6 weeks concession as we began to see increased competition from other lease-ups in the submarket. Over the last month, we have taken over 30 leases. 
The following 3 communities are all part of the West Coast development joint venture. Katella Grand I, our 399-home, $138 million lease-up in Anaheim, California was 65% leased and 58% occupied at quarter end. And as of today, it's 72% leased and 64% occupied. We are currently offering less than 1 month of concessions at this community, and leasing remains very strong with about 30 applications per month.
8th & Republican, our 211-home, $97 million lease-up in the South lake Union submarket of Seattle was 47% leased and 37% occupied at quarter end and is currently 60% leased and 46% occupied, and we are averaging over 1 application per day.
CityLine, our 244-home, $80 million lease-up in the Columbia City submarket of Seattle was 87% leased and 84% occupied at quarter end. Today, the property is 89% leased and 86% physically occupied.
All in, we had a very strong second quarter, and we remained very positive on the outlook for multifamily fundamentals and our ability to execute throughout the remainder of 2016.
With that, we will open up the call to Q&A. Operator?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Nick Joseph with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Nick Joseph with Citi.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, just sticking with operations. You outlined A versus B performance across many of the markets. And with the 50-50 diversified portfolio, I think you have a unique perspective on this. So when do you expect that spread between As and Bs to contract?
componenttext: Jerry, just sticking with operations. You outlined A versus B performance across many of the markets. And with the 50-50 diversified portfolio, I think you have a unique perspective on this. So when do you expect that spread between As and Bs to contract? And when could A's actually outperformed Bs, just given the current supply picture?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's good question, and I tell you it varies market-by-market. But I think, overall, and we stated this probably for the last 2 to 3 quarters, we would see A is getting closer to B, probably midyear next year, maybe a little bit after that. And then as yo
componenttext: It's good question, and I tell you it varies market-by-market. But I think, overall, and we stated this probably for the last 2 to 3 quarters, we would see A is getting closer to B, probably midyear next year, maybe a little bit after that. And then as you get deeper into '18, I think A is probably -- start competing more head-to-head with Bs. But it's definitely market dependent. For example, I would think in Washington, D.C, we've seen that spread contract and expand multiple times. Last quarter, it was about 50 basis points where Bs were outperforming. This quarter, we expanded to 1.7, but we do see a slowdown of new supply affecting our product in DC over the next 1.5 years. So I do think As because they're in typically better locations. By the second half of next year, it should start doing much better there. When you look at a place like New York, it's probably a little more prolonged, call it maybe even 2019 or further, where we see Bs continuing to outperform. And in San Francisco, I think it's similar. You're going to see supply continue to affect the market in some places like that, at least through the middle of next year. And I think that will cost As to continue to have to go head-to-head against new supply well into '18. So I think San Francisco, New York, Dallas, Austin, it's probably pushed out a bit. But several of the other markets that saw new supply come a little bit earlier, it's shorter. But on average, I'm guessing it gets closer in late '17 and probably pulls even in '18.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as part of the 2-year outlook, you put out 2017 operating assumptions. You've maintained 2016 same-store revenue growth, just wondering if there's any update to the 2017 estimate of 4.75 to 5.25?
componenttext: And then as part of the 2-year outlook, you put out 2017 operating assumptions. You've maintained 2016 same-store revenue growth, just wondering if there's any update to the 2017 estimate of 4.75 to 5.25?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I can tell you, we -- clearly, we saw deceleration coming in 2017. As you said, we put that in our 2-year outlook. And the range was the 4.75 to 5.25, which implied about a 75 basis point decline from 2016. And we're continuing to project a slowdown
componenttext: Yes. I can tell you, we -- clearly, we saw deceleration coming in 2017. As you said, we put that in our 2-year outlook. And the range was the 4.75 to 5.25, which implied about a 75 basis point decline from 2016. And we're continuing to project a slowdown in '17 based on a lower blended rate growth in '16 compared to '15. But at this point, it's probably a little early to give guidance on where we think '17 is going to come in. We still don't have great visibility on pricing for September through the fourth -- end of fourth quarter of this year, and we really haven't fine tuned our expectations yet for 2017. So a little bit early, but it's probably leaning towards the lower end of that range.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It depends. The difference between an A and a B in Dallas is probably $250 to $300. When you get to New York, it's probably north of $1,000 differential. San Francisco, it's going to be $800 to $1,000. So we can vary, but you're typically looking at it, g
componenttext: It depends. The difference between an A and a B in Dallas is probably $250 to $300. When you get to New York, it's probably north of $1,000 differential. San Francisco, it's going to be $800 to $1,000. So we can vary, but you're typically looking at it, getting close to $1,000 in some of the high-rise and urban markets in the -- on the coast. And when you get into the Sun Belt, it can contract down to just a couple of hundred dollars.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Second half of the year, the blend, we're looking at it being low 4s. Probably you're going to see in the second half -- I can tell you this, renewals for July are coming in on an effective basis at about 5.9%. And as you look out the next month or 2, it'
componenttext: Second half of the year, the blend, we're looking at it being low 4s. Probably you're going to see in the second half -- I can tell you this, renewals for July are coming in on an effective basis at about 5.9%. And as you look out the next month or 2, it's probably going to stay in that 5.7%, 5.8% range. But in the fourth quarter, it will come down, probably mid-5s. And then we're seeing new lease rate growth in July is currently at about 3.2%. And our expectation would be -- it will just come down a hair. Over the last 3 months, we really -- we saw pricing last year in the fourth quarter come down a bit, so we're not anniversary-ing off such high prices. But yes, second half, it's probably going to be low 4s compared to the 5.3% that we have in the first half.

componenttextpreview: Just a few quick questions. Jerry, on the operations, on the first quarter call, you guys were early in the year. You guys were asked about the high guidance, and actually Herzog explained how the same-store NOI guidance, what the leakage was that it wasn
componenttext: Just a few quick questions. Jerry, on the operations, on the first quarter call, you guys were early in the year. You guys were asked about the high guidance, and actually Herzog explained how the same-store NOI guidance, what the leakage was that it wasn't necessarily translating to FFO growth. But now this quarter, where we see some of your peers dialing back their expectations for the year, what are some of the things that caused you guys to be able to maintain such a high guidance range? Is it the amount of Bs that you have? Or just the fact that, in your portfolio mix, you still have markets by Dallas, Norfolk and other markets that are represented in some of the other -- in some of your other bicoastal peers?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start. First, I'll remind you we got out of Norfork in the fourth quarter of last year. So it's gone.
componenttext: Yes, I'll start. First, I'll remind you we got out of Norfork in the fourth quarter of last year. So it's gone.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, sorry. Okay.
componenttext: Sorry, sorry. Okay.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's okay. But yes, I think a big part of it that you have to consider is we really drove rate very strongly in the second half less [ph] as paid benefits this year. And when you look at the -- we anticipated there'll be a deceleration in rate growth that
componenttext: It's okay. But yes, I think a big part of it that you have to consider is we really drove rate very strongly in the second half less [ph] as paid benefits this year. And when you look at the -- we anticipated there'll be a deceleration in rate growth that we get this year, and that has happened. And while I'll say, directionally and in total, that reduction was pretty close, we missed on a market-by-market basis. For example, 29% of our portfolio, which is made up of New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles, we're missing our numbers. We came into the year thinking San Francisco would be an 8, now we think it's probably going to end up at a 6.5. We thought New York was going to be high 5s, now we think it's going to be low 4s. And Los Angeles, we came in thinking it was going to be call it a 7, and now we think it's going to be mid-5s. What we have that a lot of people don't is the diversified portfolio: 20 markets; we've got the 50-50 split between A, Bs and urbans. And what's really helping us is that 42% of our portfolio is performing better than we'd expected coming into the year. So it's offsetting those 3 markets that are doing work. So those are markets like Seattle, which I think all of us are doing well in right now. Our Orange County portfolio with 8.9% revenue growth in the second quarter is doing exceptionally well. We're doing very well in Boston, where we have predominantly a suburban portfolio in our same-store pool. We held up at about a little north of a 6 revenue there. The 2 markets in Florida, both Orlando and Tampa, are doing better than we expected. Nashville is on fire right now. And again, we're very suburban B there, so we're not being impacted at all by the new supply. And then we have our Monterey and Portland portfolios that are doing well. So the beauty of our portfolio with that diversification is we're not dependent on a couple of markets doing well or not doing well. We realized the most diversified approach is going to continue to help us in the future because all markets are going to go through their natural cycle. So we'll always have some that are doing better, some that are doing worse. So I think it's really more of the portfolio diversification that's really helping us compared to some others.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so historically, like [indiscernible] expecting about the harvest market, the markets that you would use to source capital to help fund the development. Based on what you're seeing in this cycle, does this -- does the weakness in some of the coastal m
componenttext: And so historically, like [indiscernible] expecting about the harvest market, the markets that you would use to source capital to help fund the development. Based on what you're seeing in this cycle, does this -- does the weakness in some of the coastal markets, especially at the high end, change your view? And maybe some of the coastal markets are going to be seen for harvesting rather than some of the markets like Richmond in some of those others.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there's still a couple of markets that we probably are ready to exit a little more quickly than others. And I think Harry will talk maybe as soon as I get off this on which ones we're looking at in our disposition program this year. But marke
componenttext: Yes. I think there's still a couple of markets that we probably are ready to exit a little more quickly than others. And I think Harry will talk maybe as soon as I get off this on which ones we're looking at in our disposition program this year. But markets that we've historically talk about that were not warehouse and we've kind of stopped talking about that because with that, we really come to realize they're good strong markets, and they're going to perform well over the long term. Places Florida, again Orlando, Nashville, Tampa, places like that, I think we're satisfied to stay there over the midterm and probably long term. There's no rush to exit. But we'll selectively sell assets and at times get out of markets to fund the development pipeline. But maybe Harry can give you a little more input on what we're looking to sell this year.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Alex, in the short term, I mean, we're always looking at which assets to sell to fund our development pipeline. In particular, this year, we've looked at -- we intent to sell Baltimore or at least sell out of -- sell down our Baltimore portfolio to s
componenttext: Yes. Alex, in the short term, I mean, we're always looking at which assets to sell to fund our development pipeline. In particular, this year, we've looked at -- we intent to sell Baltimore or at least sell out of -- sell down our Baltimore portfolio to some extent. We have a group of assets in the market today. We're also going to sell a couple of properties in Dallas for the balance of the year.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, Harry, while you're on, can you just walk us through the ground lease deal that you did in L.A. and the economics? And how this spits in within UDR's investment game plan?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, Alex, as you know, we look at all these trades in the context of [indiscernible] return for the shareholders. La Jolla, the effective land price was over $400,000 per unit, which is a price that's unheard of in Los Angeles. We were able to mon
componenttext: Sure. Well, Alex, as you know, we look at all these trades in the context of [indiscernible] return for the shareholders. La Jolla, the effective land price was over $400,000 per unit, which is a price that's unheard of in Los Angeles. We were able to monetize most or all of our future development gain today and then convert this onetime gain into another structure deal, where we received nearly 7% return in our capital. It's a while -- it's different than Wolff and Steele Creek, it's another example of how we deploy capital in accretive transactions.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess just turning back to the guidance, specifically on same-store revenue growth where you've done 6% year-to-date. And for the year, you're saying 5.5% to 6% is the range. How should we think about what level of conservatism is built into guidance
componenttext: So I guess just turning back to the guidance, specifically on same-store revenue growth where you've done 6% year-to-date. And for the year, you're saying 5.5% to 6% is the range. How should we think about what level of conservatism is built into guidance because it doesn't seem to imply much of a deceleration in the back half of the year?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, this is Jerry. Can I tell you right now? We look at our model, we're coming in right in the midpoint of guidance. There's a couple of things that could push us through. There's only one thing that could push us to the top end, and that would be
componenttext: Yes, Nick, this is Jerry. Can I tell you right now? We look at our model, we're coming in right in the midpoint of guidance. There's a couple of things that could push us through. There's only one thing that could push us to the top end, and that would be -- if we get a significant occupancy pick up, and we have been pushing to drive occupancy a little bit higher over the last month or 2. The thing that could drive us to the bottom is if we see a further deterioration in operating fundamentals. And typically, those would probably have to come with more downside than we projected. And really New York and San Francisco, since the other ones have been reacting kind of stable. There's a couple of things though, because I get what you're talking about, we've got a 6 or so in the first half of the year, which would imply second half would be a 5.5%. But there's a few things to keep in mind. This year, so far, we've had 6.3% rent per occupied home growth that's been offset by about 30 basis point decline in occupancy. We had very difficult occupancy comps in the first half of last year. Our occupancy in the second half of last year decelerated about 20 or 30 bps. Now we're still very high at 96.6%, but it wasn't at 96.8%, 96.9%. Our expectation and what we're shooting for this year is to have a positive spread over last year's occupancy. So we're not going to be losing revenue growth because of an occupancy decline. We're hoping we get a little bit of pick up from that. And then the second thing, just -- that's interesting is our fee income is up almost 10% year-over-year, and we would expect that to continue through the second half of the year. And that's really coming partially from lease break fees, people electing to move and relocate for jobs or buy houses or things like that. And -- but the second part is we started working on an initiative in the second half of last year to drive higher revenues from our parking rent, which was an initiative we began working on. Like I said, late last year, we've got the fruits of it this year to find a way to increase this under-optimized real estate. So you've got 6% of our your revenue stock coming from fee income that's growing at a much higher rate than my rents. And it's how optimistic or pessimistic or conservative is our -- is that midpoint. Right now, we've factored in, like I said earlier, that we think the blended rate growth for the second half of the year is going to be low 4s. So again, you're looking at renewal growth in the low 5s and new lease rate growth, maybe right around 3, and that seems, to us, to be pretty sustainable right now.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And, I guess, just one other follow-up on that, you did talk about the second half blended lease growth of low 4%. But it sounds like there's other items in your sort of revenue there helping as you mentioned fee income, et cetera. So I guess the po
componenttext: Okay. And, I guess, just one other follow-up on that, you did talk about the second half blended lease growth of low 4%. But it sounds like there's other items in your sort of revenue there helping as you mentioned fee income, et cetera. So I guess the point is, we shouldn't really be using that low 4% lease rate growth as a sort of directionally where your same-store revenue growth is heading? How should we think about that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll say this, your lease rate growth, or what we get from new rents or renewals, benefits you over the next 12 months. So a portion of what we're realizing in the third quarter of this year is based on the very strong lease rate growth and renewal
componenttext: Well, I'll say this, your lease rate growth, or what we get from new rents or renewals, benefits you over the next 12 months. So a portion of what we're realizing in the third quarter of this year is based on the very strong lease rate growth and renewal growth that we got at the end of last year. So it continues to pay benefits for the next 12 months. So what I'm telling you that I'm going to do over the next 6 months has some benefit over the next 6 months, but it also has a benefit over the following 6 months. So you can't just look at my current, what am I signing leases for, because that's only for the percentage of residents or expirations that are happening at that time.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, right. I meant that the second half blended lease growth of low 4%, whether that's sort of an indicator about where 2017 same-store revenue growth would be?  Not this year.
componenttext: Yes, right. I meant that the second half blended lease growth of low 4%, whether that's sort of an indicator about where 2017 same-store revenue growth would be?  Not this year.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It does build. I mean, you're right, it does build into 2017. The other thing is though, what are rents going to do next year? And we're going to have some markets where you're probably going to see rate growth continue to go down, but we have other marke
componenttext: It does build. I mean, you're right, it does build into 2017. The other thing is though, what are rents going to do next year? And we're going to have some markets where you're probably going to see rate growth continue to go down, but we have other markets, for example, Los Angeles, where we're fighting heavy new supply right now, that I expect that went to pick up quite a bit next year. So some of it's dependent on how we do next year, but you're right, we are building up part of our rent roll right now for 2017.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And just to clarify, when you talk about the fee income being strong, I mean, has any of that, from actual lease termination, lease break fees of residence, is that helping you at all?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And just to clarify, when you talk about the fee income being strong, I mean, has any of that, from actual lease termination, lease break fees of residence, is that helping you at all?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's about half of it. We're getting a portion. We'll probably pick up a little over $1 million, $1.2 million this year of additional revenue from parking, and that's just basically -- and it's predominantly in garden communities, charging people f
componenttext: Yes. That's about half of it. We're getting a portion. We'll probably pick up a little over $1 million, $1.2 million this year of additional revenue from parking, and that's just basically -- and it's predominantly in garden communities, charging people for parking and determining which spaces are the most preferable and trying to monetize that. But the other big mover is lease break fees, where somebody wants to cancel their lease ahead of the natural exploration day.  They're contractually obligated to pay us to get out of the lease, so a portion of it is that.

componenttext: I can tell you, most of it is not directly impacting us. It's Midtown West, Brooklyn, you have people in Jersey, as well as Queens, they're all kind of stealing some people away if you get a nice new product for a lower effective rate. I don't have the numbers off the top of my head about how much is in Manhattan versus Queens though.
