componenttext: Yes. So I think as you think about how we're going to deploy capital next year, development is going to continue to be sort of our preferred means to deploy capital. Second, between the West Coast JV assets and, again, Steele Creek, where we have an option window that opens next year, we'll make a determination as to which of those assets we want to buy and which we want to sell. I think you're right in that regard.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then one more question on Boston. While it's still going strong year-to-date, there was a bit of a deceleration in 3Q, which was somewhat surprising given kind of the exposure, the suburban exposure there, and most of the supply being
componenttext: That's helpful. And then one more question on Boston. While it's still going strong year-to-date, there was a bit of a deceleration in 3Q, which was somewhat surprising given kind of the exposure, the suburban exposure there, and most of the supply being urban. Is there anything going on there? Or is that just kind of a little hiccup in what should be a pretty stable market going forward?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- this is Jerry. It's predominantly a hiccup. We did -- we saw a bit of a backup in occupancy throughout that portfolio. And there are 4 assets in our same-store pool, 2 are up in the -- their B assets in the north end, those continue to do
componenttext: I think it's -- this is Jerry. It's predominantly a hiccup. We did -- we saw a bit of a backup in occupancy throughout that portfolio. And there are 4 assets in our same-store pool, 2 are up in the -- their B assets in the north end, those continue to do well. Our downtown Back Bay property, probably had revenue growth in 2.5% range, so it definitely is starting to feel more of the competition from urban supply. And then we also have one of our same-store assets that's down in the south and in Braintree, and it's been competing against new supply that's been popping up in Quincy. So the north end, continuing to hold up well. Downtown felt some supply pressures as did the South End, but I think they'll continue to do pretty well.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of your competitors today recently increased expense guidance. You've been able to maintain expense growth at a moderate level, but I was wondering if there are any components to expenses that you're feeling more upward pressure?
componenttext: One of your competitors today recently increased expense guidance. You've been able to maintain expense growth at a moderate level, but I was wondering if there are any components to expenses that you're feeling more upward pressure?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Real estate taxes for sure have been giving us pressure for really the last year or so. You've got -- the Sun Belt assets have typically been seeing real estate taxes go up high-single digits. That's really a function of the NOI growth that's taken t
componenttext:
Yes. Real estate taxes for sure have been giving us pressure for really the last year or so. You've got -- the Sun Belt assets have typically been seeing real estate taxes go up high-single digits. That's really a function of the NOI growth that's taken the valuations up. Similarly, Seattle has felt that kind of pressure. And then because of our 421 abatement burn-offs, we're going to feel it there, too. We're always watching personnel costs, and there is a lot of demand for the quality people that we hire, especially in high new supply areas. Fortunately for the quarter and year-to-date, we've kept that growth at 1.1%, and we did it really because we realize quite a few efficiencies over the last year or 2 at our site staff that allowed us this year to reduce staffing levels by 1.5% or so, and that's through things like our inside sales group, who assist in renewals and leasing. And secondly, we've deployed about 70 package lockers out into the field that take the burden of package handling off of our site people, so that they can spend more time on sales and service. And we've been able to turn that into some headcount savings.
But I'd say the biggest expense pressure continues to be real estate taxes as our valuations for real estate continue to go up.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And at the same time, you've kept turnover relatively stable versus last year despite new supply really picking up. Can you just elaborate on what you've done strategically to address just the markets where you're seeing a lot of supply pressure?
componenttext: Okay. And at the same time, you've kept turnover relatively stable versus last year despite new supply really picking up. Can you just elaborate on what you've done strategically to address just the markets where you're seeing a lot of supply pressure?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we probably -- 2 things: One is earlier this year, based on the success we'd had, again, with this inside sales team that helped us won new leases, we created a department of a few people that really assist our people on renewals. So they call
componenttext: Yes. Well, we probably -- 2 things: One is earlier this year, based on the success we'd had, again, with this inside sales team that helped us won new leases, we created a department of a few people that really assist our people on renewals. So they call everybody that hasn't made a decision to renew or give notice yet, as our renewal offer has been out there for a while, and trying to answer any questions to prompt them to renew more quickly. We ask them as a secondary source to go out to people that have given notice to try to convince them to stay. And sometimes this may result in slight negotiation on renewal rates. I think those are the biggest things. I think we've obviously seen the renewal increases come from. Last year, they were north of 7%. Right now, they're in the mid-5. So there's not quite as much pressure. But I think we've got a focus on service and a focus on sales. And I think doing things like, again, putting these package lockers and that -- we don't look at it as just a savings to our site's times. We see it as an amenity that people can self-serve 24/7. We're always looking for opportunities to provide our residents with more of what they're looking for.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, just following along that -- John's questions. It sounds like your -- you guys have been pretty proactive on the portfolio this year as well as budgeting guidance that you're able to maintain while peers have revised down. So as you look at your gu
componenttext: Jerry, just following along that -- John's questions. It sounds like your -- you guys have been pretty proactive on the portfolio this year as well as budgeting guidance that you're able to maintain while peers have revised down. So as you look at your guidance for next year, back in June when we met, you guys expressed confidence that you would still be on track for your 2017. But earlier in this call, you guys said that you'll address 2017 later. So just looking at your multiyear plan, where you guys are now, it would seem you're still on track to hit 2017, is that fair? Or there's some things that are coming up that you think could cause you guys to deviate from that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex. As I indicated in my prepared remarks, without providing 2017 guidance, we do expect same-store growth to continue to decelerate in 2017 on a year-over-year basis, and we're currently projecting, as I said earlier, the earn-in of about 2% compa
componenttext: Yes, Alex. As I indicated in my prepared remarks, without providing 2017 guidance, we do expect same-store growth to continue to decelerate in 2017 on a year-over-year basis, and we're currently projecting, as I said earlier, the earn-in of about 2% compared to 2.75 that was baked in at the beginning of '16. As a result, we see it unlikely that we'll be able to achieve the lower end of the 4.75 to 5.25 2017 same-store revenue growth range that we originally provided in our 2016, 2017 2-year plan that was published earlier this year. At that time, we -- the operating environment at some of our higher-rent coastal markets was much more accommodating when we originally provided the range. And that next year's top line growth is still expected to compare favorably against our long-term revenue growth of about 3%. That being said, we're going to give more detailed 2017 guidance and our update to the 2-year strategic plan on our fourth quarter call.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But is it fair to say -- because back in June, you guys expressed confidence to still meet. Is it that your range this year was wide enough to accommodate? Or did the market further decelerate post June NAREIT that's caused you to revise, think that
componenttext: Okay. But is it fair to say -- because back in June, you guys expressed confidence to still meet. Is it that your range this year was wide enough to accommodate? Or did the market further decelerate post June NAREIT that's caused you to revise, think that you won't even -- that the bottom end will be lower?

componenttext: Okay. And then this is a question maybe -- I don't know if it's Toomey or Warren who wants to take it. But on the MetLife JV, the simplification that's going on, is any of that related to MetLife's overall business model where they're breaking down parts of their businesses and you expect more of the MetLife JV to unwind? Or were these totally independent of what Met is doing corporately, and therefore, we should still see you guys maintaining the relationship with Met?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Toomey. With respect to Met, and you've seen it every year that we've been in this relationship for the last 6, we've always had some degree of some trade going on during -- throughout the life of this joint venture, and I would probably see
componenttext: Alex, this is Toomey. With respect to Met, and you've seen it every year that we've been in this relationship for the last 6, we've always had some degree of some trade going on during -- throughout the life of this joint venture, and I would probably see us continuing that same pattern the future. We see no impact from what's going on at Met at corporate to real estate appetite, views of the world or their capital availability or deployment of capital. So I think we'll just continue to have these dialogues that we do with a great partner at future opportunities that help us advance UDR and help them advance their capital deployment. So I don't see any change to that. I think it was just one of those years where we decided to sell an asset, buy 2, shrink land inventory. And I'd like the side of the trade that we ended up on.

componenttext: So Jerry, it doesn't sound like your kind of dangerously close to going negative in any market either next year or the year after. Just to get it on the record, if you can, do you feel like anything? Is going that south in the next couple of years? Or do you still think you'll stay above the Mendoza line or whatever?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't see that at this point. There's differences in our portfolio mix, specially in New York, with some of our peers. Again, remember, we're more of a B operator there. We don't have anything in places like Brooklyn, we don't have any specific --
componenttext: Yes. I don't see that at this point. There's differences in our portfolio mix, specially in New York, with some of our peers. Again, remember, we're more of a B operator there. We don't have anything in places like Brooklyn, we don't have any specific -- any properties that are directly in Midtown West. So while we're affected and it will hamper our ability to really push rate, I don't see us going negative anywhere.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Tom, you mentioned 6% to 10% cash flow per share growth kind of strategy. Obviously, that's not really a trend number or at trend or kind of average number over the course of many, many years. What do you think -- while you're not going to
componenttext: Okay. And then Tom, you mentioned 6% to 10% cash flow per share growth kind of strategy. Obviously, that's not really a trend number or at trend or kind of average number over the course of many, many years. What do you think -- while you're not going to give the outlook for '17, but what do you think sort of the average number would be? 6% to 10% is a premium growth rate. Do you think the number for bottom line AFFO growth is significantly below that? Or what's your view using your history as a guide?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a long history, Rich, and a darn good question. For the last 3 years, make it 4, we had 3 years of 10%, we had this year looks like an 8%, and as we're looking now towards the future, I think in a stable supply-demand demographics that we're in
componenttext: Well, it's a long history, Rich, and a darn good question. For the last 3 years, make it 4, we had 3 years of 10%, we had this year looks like an 8%, and as we're looking now towards the future, I think in a stable supply-demand demographics that we're in a phase, it's probably in the 6% to 8% kind of range. What it would take to get below that 6%, I think, is a recession and the depth and the nature of that. I'm not calling for one, but I think that has been my historical pattern, is when the country goes into recession, it's where is our exposure to it. How deep of a portfolio do we have in those particular areas or industry exposure, it's hard to forecast that element in it -- of it. But what we're trying to do is build a company that can stay in that 6% to 10% through most cycles, and I think we've done that. And I think we're going continue in the future, and when you look at the next strategic plan, you're going to see a lot of the same strategies that we've been executing on in the last 4 years, very focused on capital deployment, operations and continued balance sheet improvement.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I hope Chris doesn't get mad at me because he's way bigger. I want one more question. The self-funding strategy hinges a lot on dispositions, decelerating fundamentals. Do you see any risk that people or buying public of multifamily real estate migh
componenttext: Okay. I hope Chris doesn't get mad at me because he's way bigger. I want one more question. The self-funding strategy hinges a lot on dispositions, decelerating fundamentals. Do you see any risk that people or buying public of multifamily real estate might make it more difficult for that self-funding strategy to stay intact over the next couple of years?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Harry. I think the short answer is no. What I can tell you is that there continues to be plenty of liquidity in the market that there's still cheap that's available. There's plenty of buyers, although buyer pools are somewhat shallower. What
componenttext: Rich, this is Harry. I think the short answer is no. What I can tell you is that there continues to be plenty of liquidity in the market that there's still cheap that's available. There's plenty of buyers, although buyer pools are somewhat shallower. What you could see is that the buyers continue to underwrite lower growth rates that cap rates could increase a bit. Remember, you still have solid fundamentals in most of the markets so that even if cap rates increase a little bit, NOI should continue to increase, so there's no obvious impact to absolute value. But the big point is that it's a very liquid market. If you look at 2016 transaction volume, it's still going to be very robust. It will be slightly lower than the 2015 kind of record levels but should be similar to '13 and '14, and there's no evidence that that's going to abate anytime soon.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, I'd follow-on a little bit by saying even in the depths of '09 and '10, transactions were getting done. You may not have liked the price, but there is still liquidity, and Fannie and Freddie were still doing business. So I think there's going to be
componenttext: Rich, I'd follow-on a little bit by saying even in the depths of '09 and '10, transactions were getting done. You may not have liked the price, but there is still liquidity, and Fannie and Freddie were still doing business. So I think there's going to be always a supply capital. I think we've got a diversified portfolio that we can always look at and say there is a liquidity opportunity there. And so I don't see much risk from us at the sales level that we're anticipating being able to execute.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the risk of concentrated supply and you also highlighted Bellevue as having a bit of a supply increase. Do you think that job growth is sufficient to absorb the supply and the developers be more rational? We saw in L.A. where demand was pret
componenttext: You mentioned the risk of concentrated supply and you also highlighted Bellevue as having a bit of a supply increase. Do you think that job growth is sufficient to absorb the supply and the developers be more rational? We saw in L.A. where demand was pretty solid, yet the pressure on your existing properties existed. So I'm wondering how you see those 2 markets being different.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess there's -- we don't see rational concession levels in Bellevue at this point that they've actually been offering a month free on lease-ups, if not something less. Our portfolio in Bellevue has been able to maintain to date as the supply has b
componenttext: Yes. I guess there's -- we don't see rational concession levels in Bellevue at this point that they've actually been offering a month free on lease-ups, if not something less. Our portfolio in Bellevue has been able to maintain to date as the supply has been delivering north of 6% revenue growth and getting very good renewal as well as new lease rate growth. And yes, I think the job growth, when you look at Amazon coming in next year, if you look at Apple that's looking to come, you consider that Bellevue is pretty close to Redmond. So it doesn't just have to be job growth in Bellevue. It's a lot of those places on the east side that benefit. I think Bellevue is a bit different, and I do think job growth will continue in that. That core of Bellevue will eventually run out of developable space. The other thing to keep in mind, and this is a little more long term, but in about 5 or 6 years, the light rail is going to reach across Lake Washington and really connect both Bellevue as well as Redmond to the west side of town, and I think it will enhance the east side even more.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then going back to L.A., you obviously had 2 large developments out there, are weighing on your results, abnormally pressuring you guys this year. Do you see any other large developments that might cause a hiccup in another market next year?
componenttext: Okay. And then going back to L.A., you obviously had 2 large developments out there, are weighing on your results, abnormally pressuring you guys this year. Do you see any other large developments that might cause a hiccup in another market next year?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: There's a couple of developers that come in with very aggressive pricing that can affect us. And the places that we've seen it happened this year has been the Platinum Triangle of Orange County. I could see it potentially happening in Irvine. And we've also felt it up at San Jose. But I don't foresee it at this point anywhere else.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And next is Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And next is Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just I'm curious on your take on this. A handful of jurisdictions in Northern California are looking at rent control. It's elections season. And I think a few more than a half dozen of your properties fall into those areas and maybe just a portion of that
componenttext: Just I'm curious on your take on this. A handful of jurisdictions in Northern California are looking at rent control. It's elections season. And I think a few more than a half dozen of your properties fall into those areas and maybe just a portion of that is -- would be subject to the laws that are contemplated. What's your take on that legislation, maybe the odds of its passage? And I guess how do you think that affects valuation if it came to light?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll talk about our assets there. Harry can talk valuations afterwards. But when you look at it, there's 5 cities in Northern California that are bringing forth some rent control issues to the ballots. There's 2 markets where were located that are bringin
componenttext: I'll talk about our assets there. Harry can talk valuations afterwards. But when you look at it, there's 5 cities in Northern California that are bringing forth some rent control issues to the ballots. There's 2 markets where were located that are bringing it, San Mateo and Mountain View. We really only have 3 properties that constitute about 2.5% of UDR's NOI that are going to be affected by it. It's only for pre-1995 built assets that would still be -- the rent control would range from 1% to 5% on increases. I'd say I know the California Apartment Association has been finding it pretty strongly and thinks the probability of passage is probably limited, but we'll have to wait and see. But right now, I can tell you over the next year or so, I don't think those up to 5% on increases would make much of a difference. It's not the way it was 2 or 3 years -- or a year to 3 years ago, when we're getting very high rent increases. But again, it's relatively low exposure, 2.5% of UDR. And Harry, you can talk more about what you think would be the valuations.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Where we've sort of really dealt with this type of issue was in New York City, where you have rent stabilization. And I can tell you -- I guess I'd answer it a couple of different ways. One, the short term that will have probably a slight negative i
componenttext:
Sure. Where we've sort of really dealt with this type of issue was in New York City, where you have rent stabilization. And I can tell you -- I guess I'd answer it a couple of different ways. One, the short term that will have probably a slight negative impact on value, where the absolute rent growth in the near term will be slightly lower because you do have these base cap on increases. However, the way you look at it over the long term is truly a timing issue that typically you have vacancy B control. So over time, you capture those sort of embedded shortfalls as your tendency turns over.
In the long term, if you get say 5 years into a rent control program, these assets actually traded lower cap rates because of the embedded upside that exist on the rent roll, so that you have a certain number of units that are well below sort of market rent. You assume that over time, just really on an actuarial basis, you're going to get 5% or 10% or 15% of those assets or those units to turn over and are able to capture that upside.

We're going to continue to maintain at least -- our business plan is to maintain our $900 million to $1.4 billion type development pipeline, so you won't see it increase above that level. And again, we'll continue to use a disciplined underwriting approach.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to UDR's Third Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. Our third quarter press release and supplemental disclosure package were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investor Relations section of our website, ir.udr.com.In th
componenttext:
Welcome to UDR's Third Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. Our third quarter press release and supplemental disclosure package were distributed yesterday afternoon and posted to the Investor Relations section of our website, ir.udr.com.
In the supplement, we reconciled all non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure in accordance with Reg G requirements. I would like to note that statements made during this call, which are not historical, may constitute forward-looking statements. Although we believe the expectations reflected in any forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, we can give no assurance that our expectations will be met.
A discussion of risks and risk factors are detailed in yesterday's press release and included in our filings with the SEC. We do not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to our President and CEO, Tom Toomey.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to UDR's third quarter conference call. On the call with me today are Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer; and Shawn Johnston, Interim Principal Financial Officer, who will discuss our results, as w
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to UDR's third quarter conference call. On the call with me today are Jerry Davis, Chief Operating Officer; and Shawn Johnston, Interim Principal Financial Officer, who will discuss our results, as well as senior officers Warren Troupe and Harry Alcock, who will be available during the Q&A portion of the call.
UDR reported another strong quarter of results, highlighted by solid same-store and cash flow growth, strong leasing velocities in rental rates at our development communities, several strategic transactions and continued improvement of our balance sheet. Jerry and Shawn will provide additional details in their prepared remarks.
As we near the end of 2016, I'd like to take a couple of minutes to discuss our strategic plan and how we've executed on it. As you know, consistently generating 6% to 10% cash flow per share growth has been the cornerstone of our plan since it was first published in 2013. In 2016, we expect to again achieve that goal with full-year AFFO per share growth of approximately 8%, at the midpoint of our guidance.
Next, a deeper look into how the primary drivers of our cash flow growth have performed. First, operations. We expect that our full year 2016 same-store growth metrics will compare well on an absolute and relative basis, in spite of the headwinds that New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles generated this year. We have successfully weathered this storm and continued to do so, partly because of our diversified portfolio, but much of our success stems from our operating platform.
Starting with the team's ability to quickly adjust operating tactics to maximize revenue growth in a shifting market as well as a consistent implementation of innovative technologies. I'm grateful for our team's hard work.
Next, capital allocation. We delivered $163 million of accretive development in 2016 and believe that our $937 million under-construction pipeline will be no different. Our development pipeline provides our shareholders with a strong risk adjusted return on their capital and allows us to consistently refresh our portfolio via our self-funding model.
Fully funding our development growth in a non-dilutive manner through retained cash flow and capital recycled from asset sales is a funding mechanism that we can employ year in and year out.
Moving forward, we remain comfortable with this strategy. Last, our balance sheet continues to improve. Our leverage metrics at the end of the third quarter were better than those originally envisioned for the year ended 2016.
As we look into 2017 and without providing guidance, we remain confident in our ability to execute on our strategic plan. Currently, we are in the midst of building the 2017-'18 plan from the ground up. We see no need to change our strategies, as they continue to work well as we move through this part of the business cycle. We will share the updated details of the plan with you on the fourth quarter call.
In summary, while 2016 has presented challenges, we have successfully worked through them and will achieve the guidance provided at the beginning of the year as part of our strategic plan. Given the outlook for sound intermediate and long-term multifamily fundamentals, we remain confident that adhering to our strategic plan's core principles will continue to help us drive strong cash flow growth for many years to come.
With that, I will turn the call over to Jerry for additional comments on the quarter.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. We are pleased to announce another quarter of strong operating results. During the third quarter, year-over-year same-store revenue and NOI growth were 5.3% and 6.4%, respectively. On a year-to-date basis, same-s
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good afternoon, everyone. We are pleased to announce another quarter of strong operating results. During the third quarter, year-over-year same-store revenue and NOI growth were 5.3% and 6.4%, respectively. On a year-to-date basis, same-store revenue and NOI growth totaled 5.9% and 6.9%, respectively.
During the third quarter, operating trends further normalized as compared to 2015, when the majority of markets were accelerating. Localized demand/supply dynamics today are creating strength in some markets and weakness in others. Making up 45% of our NOI, strength was evident in Seattle, Orange County, the Monterey Peninsula, Boston and our Sun Belt markets. While New York City, the Bay area and Los Angeles, which comprised 28% of our NOI, remain challenged due to concentrated new supply and concessions.
Overall, our highly diversified portfolio is defined by market mix, price point and location within markets, continued to perform well during the quarter, and we expect will generate growth that compares favorably versus the multifamily group average over the foreseeable future.
Turning to operating tactics. As you know, driving rate growth was our primary focus over the past 2 to 3 years. This approach was successful, largely as a result of the robust multifamily fundamentals present throughout the majority of our markets and evidenced by our cumulative same-store revenue growth of 16% between 2013 and 2015.
As 2016 has progressed, diminished pricing power due to concentrated new supply caused us to reevaluate this tactic. Towards the end of the second quarter, we made a change, pivoting our operating tactics to favor higher occupancy over rate growth in markets that were more challenged by new supply. Higher occupancy in select markets prior to the seasonally slower fourth and first quarters, when few of our leases expire, is a more prudent approach to maximizing revenue and cash flow growth in the current environment. This strategic shift bore fruit with third quarter occupancy averaging 96.8%, a 20 basis point sequential increase. We will operate the portfolio in the high 96% range through at least the end of this year.
With regard to the prime leasing season, 2016 results were clearly not as robust as those realized in 2015 but still compared favorably versus historical standards. For the third quarter, portfolio-wide new lease and renewal growth totaled 2.7% and 5.6%.
We continue to see minimal pressure from single-family competition with move-outs to home purchase totaling 13% during the third quarter. A lack of affordability is also not meaningfully affecting us as portfolio-wide move-outs due to rent increases remains relatively constrained at 7%. Net bad debt remains at 0.1% of rents, at levels consistent with that of third quarter 2015.
Next, forward expectations. Without providing 2017 guidance, we are projecting a revenue earn-in of about 2% going into 2017 versus the 2.75% earn-in that was baked into the beginning of 2016. Directionally, we continue to expect deceleration in 2017 same-store growth metrics as elevated new supply is further absorbed in some of our higher rent markets.
With that being said, next year is still expected to look good when compared against our long-term 15-year revenue growth average of about 3%. We will provide detailed 2017 guidance and an update to our 2-year strategic plan on our fourth quarter call.
Now moving on to the quarterly performance at our largest markets, which represents 72% of our total NOI. Metro D.C., which contributes 19% of our total NOI, continues to incrementally improve. Job growth is gaining steam versus a couple of years ago, though new supply remains persistent in some infill locations. We expect our highly diversified D.C. portfolio to see continuing improvement throughout 2017.
Orange County and Los Angeles contributed 16.5% of our total NOI. Orange County has been one of our strongest markets in 2016, primarily because our portfolio is concentrated west of the 405 freeway and has benefited from good job growth set against limited new supply.
Conversely, Los Angeles has struggled this year due to significant new supply in excess of concessions hitting our highly concentrated Marina del Rey portfolio. This pressure is now subsiding, and we expect pricing power in L.A. to improve in 2017 and for Orange County to remain stable.
New York City makes up 12% of our total NOI, and it continues to struggle due to concentrated new supply at Midtown West as well as Brooklyn and excessive concessions. Given the glut of building permits issued prior to 421-As expiring, we expect that driving meaningful growth in Manhattan will be problematic through at least 2018.
Like New York City, San Francisco, which contributes about 12% of our total NOI, continues to be negatively affected by supply, especially South of Market Street. Expected 2016 job growth of 2.9% still looks good versus long-term averages but has decelerated from 2015's 4.5% growth rate.
Our data providers indicate that supply pressures should subside in the city as we move into the second half of 2017, at which time pricing power should improve.
Boston, which contributes 7% of our total NOI, has held up well, largely due to our suburban B exposure. On a relative basis, our downtown and Back Bay communities have also outperformed due primarily to their differentiated characteristics. Boston continues to look like a good market for us going forward.
Seattle contributes 6% of our total NOI. It remains UDR's strongest core market on the West Coast. The MSAs' relatively higher affordability, strong [Audio Gap] jobs and urban renewal continued to attract educated, tech savvy residents. We expect that Seattle will continue to put up good numbers moving forward, although we are keeping our eye on near-term Bellevue supply as that submarket further transforms.
Our secondary markets, such as Portland, Monterey Peninsula, Florida, Nashville and Austin, comprise roughly 25% of our portfolio. Pricing power remained strong in the majority of these markets and continues to help offset the relative weakness in some of our higher-rent coastal locales. Move-outs to home purchase remained constrained, and our expectation is that these markets have a long runway for growth due to continued favorable multifamily fundamentals.
Last, our development lease-ups continued to perform well, achieving rates above original expectations and with leasing velocities ahead of original forecast. Thus far, in October, these trends have remained firm, and our development pipeline remains highly accretive than the average value creation spread in excess of the top end of our targeted 150 to 200 basis point range. Community specific quarter end lease-up statistics are available on Attachment 9 or Page 21 of our supplement.
Summing it up, we had another good quarter, proactively pivoted our strategy to maximize revenue growth and remained positive on the outlook for multifamily fundamentals and our ability to execute throughout the remainder of 2016 and into 2017.
With that, I'll turn it over to Shawn.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jerry. The topics I will cover today include our third quarter results, a transactions update, a capital markets and balance sheet update and our fourth quarter and full year guidance.Our third quarter earnings results were at the mid- to high e
componenttext:
Thanks, Jerry. The topics I will cover today include our third quarter results, a transactions update, a capital markets and balance sheet update and our fourth quarter and full year guidance.
Our third quarter earnings results were at the mid- to high end of our previously provided guidance. FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share were $0.46, $0.45 and $0.41, driven by solid same-store revenue expense and NOI growth of 5.3%, 2.5% and 6.4%, respectively.
Next, transactions. We are under contract to sell 7 communities in Baltimore and 1 community in Dallas for $285 million. We expect to close these transactions in the fourth quarter at a cash flow cap rate of approximately 6% and a weighted average IRR of 13%. We also completed a series of strategic transactions with MetLife that further simplified our joint venture.
First, we completed a swap of our land interest in 3 development sites where we acquired MetLife's 95% interest in a land site located in Dublin, California in exchange for our 5% weighted average ownership interest in 2 land sites located in Bellevue, Washington and Los Angeles California. The Dublin site is within walking distance of the Bay Area BART line and provides the opportunity to develop a differentiated product in that submarket.
Next, UDR/MetLife joint venture sold 100% of Cirque, a high-rise community located in Dallas, to an unrelated third party for approximately $75 million at a cash flow cap rate in the mid-4s and an IRR of 10%.
Subsequent to quarter end, we also acquired MetLife's 50% ownership interest in Ashton Bellevue and TEN20, 2 adjacent highrise communities located in Bellevue, Washington, for $68 million plus the assumption of $38 million of debt, at a cash flow cap rate in the mid-4s. We know both of these assets well. They complement our other assets in the Bellevue submarket, and we like the long-term prospects as more established tech companies continue to create a presence on the east side of metro Seattle.
After accounting for joint venture refinancings, these MetLife transactions were net cash positive to the company by approximately $14 million and reduced the size of the UDR/MetLife joint venture by approximately 10% or $355 million.
Next, capital markets. During the third quarter, we issued $300 million of 10-year unsecured notes priced at 2.95%. $158 million of the proceeds were used to prepay 2017 debt maturities with an average interest rate of 5.61%. The majority of the remaining proceeds were used to pay down our revolver.
With the prepayment of the 2017 debt, next year's maturities now total only $71 million. Development will likely represent our largest use of capital in 2017. We will continue to self-fund our accretive development pipeline via retained earnings and asset sales, and we'll provide a detailed update of our 2017 sources and uses on the fourth quarter call.
As a result of the unsecured offering, our weighted average maturities increased by nearly half a year to 5.3 years and improved our near-term liquidity by approximately $140 million. At quarter end, our liquidity, as measured by cash and credit facility capacity, was $931 million. Our financial leverage on an undepreciated cost basis was 33.5%. Based on quarter end market cap, it was 24.4%, and inclusive of joint ventures, it was 29%. Our net debt-to-EBITDA was 5.3x and inclusive of joint ventures was 6.4x. All balance sheet metrics continue to track ahead of our strategic outlook.
I would now like to direct you to Attachment 15 or Page 28 of our supplement, where we have updated our full year guidance. We have tightened and increased our full year 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance ranges to $1.77 to $1.80, $1.78 to $1.80 and $1.62 to $1.64, respectively, by increasing the bottom end of the range by $0.01.
For same-store, our full year 2016 guidance remains unchanged with revenue growth of 5.5% to 6%, expense growth of 3% to 3.5% and NOI growth of 6.5% to 7%. Average 2016 forecasted occupancy is unchanged at 96.6%.
Fourth quarter 2016 FFO, FFO as adjusted and AFFO per share guidance is $0.44 to $0.46, $0.45 to $0.47 and $0.39 to $0.41, respectively.
Next, we declared a quarterly common dividend of $0.295 in the third quarter or a $1.18 per share when annualized. This is 6% above 2015's level and represents a yield of approximately 3.3% as of quarter end.
Finally, a housekeeping item. We moved and consolidated our preferred equity investments and participating loan information and economics to a new attachment, 12B. All information that was previously provided for these investments is still available on the new attachment. With that, I will open up the call for Q&A. Operator?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, it's Jerry. For the Baltimore pool, it's somewhere between 10 and 15 basis points. I would tell you that when we set guidance at the beginning of the year, we anticipated that would be the Baltimore assets that were sold, so it really had no ef
componenttext: Yes, Nick, it's Jerry. For the Baltimore pool, it's somewhere between 10 and 15 basis points. I would tell you that when we set guidance at the beginning of the year, we anticipated that would be the Baltimore assets that were sold, so it really had no effect on our guidance range. And then the asset in Dallas that we pulled out to do a readout, that's a 17-year-old deal that we started the redevelopment late in the third quarter. It should last through a good portion of next year. That was probably more like 3 basis points.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jordan Sadler with KeyBanc.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jordan Sadler with KeyBanc.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just curious if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing in L.A. Jerry you talked previously about some new lease-ups in Playa Vista that were causing some issue that you expected to subside sometime ar
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just curious if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing in L.A. Jerry you talked previously about some new lease-ups in Playa Vista that were causing some issue that you expected to subside sometime around the fourth quarter. And it looked like new lease rates snapped back in L.A. since the mid-quarter update. Can you just give a little color on the Marina del Rey portfolio?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And you're right, that is -- 90% of our same-store pool is in Marina del Rey, and it competes with Playa Vista. Through the first, call it, 7 to 9 months of this year, we were competing against that new supply that was offering up to 2 months free re
componenttext: Yes. And you're right, that is -- 90% of our same-store pool is in Marina del Rey, and it competes with Playa Vista. Through the first, call it, 7 to 9 months of this year, we were competing against that new supply that was offering up to 2 months free rent. Luckily, the properties in that submarket that we were battling with have come very close to hitting stabilized occupancies, pushing 90%. We've seen concession levels late in the third quarter start to come back down to 1 month free. And what's really encouraging is, like you said, we had new lease rate growth in the third quarter of 0.1%, and when I look at where we're at in Los Angeles so far in the month of October, it's over 3%. So we are starting to emerge out of our problem area in Los Angeles.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then looking at supply and sort of your submarkets next year, what's the expectation? Any other potential supply headwinds that you see?
componenttext: And then looking at supply and sort of your submarkets next year, what's the expectation? Any other potential supply headwinds that you see?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably the place you see new supply, and we don't have any same-store assets, we have a MetLife asset in downtown Los Angeles, you're going to see a continuation of new supply being delivered as well as leased up. So I think that's going to be difficult
componenttext:
Probably the place you see new supply, and we don't have any same-store assets, we have a MetLife asset in downtown Los Angeles, you're going to see a continuation of new supply being delivered as well as leased up. So I think that's going to be difficult. I think you're going to see a continuation of some supply pressures in SOMA at least through the first quarter, maybe second quarter of 2017.
Downtown Seattle continues to battle new supply. We do not have any same-store assets there, but we do have 2 different JV properties there. And the other one that I've been keeping my eye on but we really haven't seen a downturn in fundamentals has been Bellevue, Washington. We're very high on Bellevue, even though there's probably 5 or 6 properties delivering there. Bellevue, as you know, we just purchased the other 50% of 2 assets from MetLife there. And you've got jobs that are coming in there, Amazon is creating a mini campus, if you will, over on the east side of Lake Washington, where they just signed a lease for a 350,000 square-foot office space that rumor has it, Apple was looking at the same building and is continuing to look in Bellevue. So Bellevue, I think, is going to have job growth that should absorb the new supply, but we are watching the new supply there. And other than that, obviously, when you get up to New York City, where we've been battling not direct competition in a submarket but throughout Manhattan, we're going to continue to face supply headwinds throughout our Manhattan portfolio all through next year and probably well into 2018.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know that the Southeast and Southwest are a little smaller pieces of the portfolio but seemed to have held up fairly well here even into the third quarter. What's sort of your outlook on the supply side for those markets?
componenttext: I know that the Southeast and Southwest are a little smaller pieces of the portfolio but seemed to have held up fairly well here even into the third quarter. What's sort of your outlook on the supply side for those markets?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We see -- again, we use predominantly Axiometrics for this. But we see Tampa delivering supply in '16 of about 4,500 units. Next year, it's going to be about 4,000. Orlando is going to be about 5,500 to 6,000, each of the 2 years. Nashville, where mo
componenttext: Yes. We see -- again, we use predominantly Axiometrics for this. But we see Tampa delivering supply in '16 of about 4,500 units. Next year, it's going to be about 4,000. Orlando is going to be about 5,500 to 6,000, each of the 2 years. Nashville, where most of the new supply has hit the downtown urban core, is going to slow from 9,000 units to 6,000 next year. And then Orange County is probably going to see a tick-up as some deliveries have slipped from '16 into '17. That's going to go from about 4,000 units to about 6,500. A lot of those are concentrated in Irvine. One deal that we'll start leasing up and--or occupying in the next month or so is going to compete against that new supply. But a good portion of our product in Orange County is more B product and its west to the 405, and it's held up pretty well, specially our Costa Mesa and Huntington Beach assets.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: And we'll go next to Juan Sanabria with Bank of America.

componenttext: Sorry. If you could just talk a little bit about the performance between the A and B assets in your portfolio and maybe specifically to New York and San Francisco?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess on a national basis, I would say that Bs continued to outperform As probably by about 125, 150 basis points. But it does definitely vary market-by-market. In New York, most of our portfolio is B, especially in the same-store. But our Bs toda
componenttext: Sure. I guess on a national basis, I would say that Bs continued to outperform As probably by about 125, 150 basis points. But it does definitely vary market-by-market. In New York, most of our portfolio is B, especially in the same-store. But our Bs today, when you look at same-store as well as our MetLife property, our Bs are coming in at about 3.4% for the quarter, and our As are about 4.3. Our Chelsea property is also included in that 4.3. So fairly tight. You're seeing concessions and pricing issues affect both As and Bs as people in Bs at times now can step up to As.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: San Francisco?
componenttext: San Francisco?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: San Francisco, and again, ours is San Francisco and San Jose. Combined, interestingly for the quarter. They were fairly even. And again, it's the same type situation where B renters, when you have an A property down the Street that's offering 1.5 to 2 mon
componenttext: San Francisco, and again, ours is San Francisco and San Jose. Combined, interestingly for the quarter. They were fairly even. And again, it's the same type situation where B renters, when you have an A property down the Street that's offering 1.5 to 2 months free, it's priced probably on an effective basis just above what you were paying at your B, so you can pay a little bit more, and you're got a step-up in quality.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then if you could just speak a little bit to supply expectations across some of the Sun Belt markets, do you see kind of more supply heading to those kind of suburban Sun Belt markets versus the urban coastal markets? Or how do you see th
componenttext: Okay, great. And then if you could just speak a little bit to supply expectations across some of the Sun Belt markets, do you see kind of more supply heading to those kind of suburban Sun Belt markets versus the urban coastal markets? Or how do you see that trend playing out as we look forward sort of 12 to 18 months?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we -- again, AXIO recently revised their supply data from what we were seeing 2 to 3 months ago. And now 2016, 2017, in total, are roughly even at about 360,000 to 370,000 multifamily homes. And when you look at individual markets, there's not a w
componenttext: Yes. As we -- again, AXIO recently revised their supply data from what we were seeing 2 to 3 months ago. And now 2016, 2017, in total, are roughly even at about 360,000 to 370,000 multifamily homes. And when you look at individual markets, there's not a whole lot of differentiation. I gave the numbers on prior question. But basically, the Florida markets are roughly flat between '16 and '17. Nashville is going to come down about 3,000 homes. And then like I said earlier, you're going to see a bit of a tick-up in Orange County. You're going to see Boston stay roughly flat. Dallas should stay roughly flat. Austin is going to see a reduction of about 4,000 homes from '16, so you're going to hopefully get a little bit of easing. And if job growth continues to be strong in Austin, you should see a pickup.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird & Co.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird & Co.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on West Coast JV assets. As we get closer to the time window where you have the option of purchasing those, I was curious as to: A, the probability that you would do so, and B, where NOI yields may be on the option pricing relative to th
componenttext: First question is on West Coast JV assets. As we get closer to the time window where you have the option of purchasing those, I was curious as to: A, the probability that you would do so, and B, where NOI yields may be on the option pricing relative to the 6.5% preferred return you currently get.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Harry Alcock. The first 3 of the assets are in lease-up, and they've all leased up very well. The first asset in Seattle was stabilized. The next 2 in Anaheim, the second Seattle asset, again, leased up very well with a raise that are at or
componenttext: Drew, this is Harry Alcock. The first 3 of the assets are in lease-up, and they've all leased up very well. The first asset in Seattle was stabilized. The next 2 in Anaheim, the second Seattle asset, again, leased up very well with a raise that are at or above original expectation. I think when we talked about this, we thought that the all-in sort of return on cost on these assets will be somewhere in the neighborhood of 5%. We don't have anything that changes our view on that. And again, as we look at the option windows that begin opening up next year, we'll make a determination as to which assets we want to buy and which assets we want to sell. But again, the first ones will be the 2 Seattle assets and the Anaheim asset. First half of the year, we'll make that determination.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you go forward into next year, in 2018, in terms of acquisitions that make sense for UDR, is kind of the main research priority going to be these JV assets versus going out and kind of looking at what's become a pretty frothy market in terms of the
componenttext: And as you go forward into next year, in 2018, in terms of acquisitions that make sense for UDR, is kind of the main research priority going to be these JV assets versus going out and kind of looking at what's become a pretty frothy market in terms of the asset pricing?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think as you think about how we're going to deploy capital next year, development is going to continue to be sort of our preferred means to deploy capital. Second, between the West Coast JV assets and, again, Steele Creek, where we have an optio
componenttext: Yes. So I think as you think about how we're going to deploy capital next year, development is going to continue to be sort of our preferred means to deploy capital. Second, between the West Coast JV assets and, again, Steele Creek, where we have an option window that opens next year, we'll make a determination as to which of those assets we want to buy and which we want to sell. I think you're right in that regard.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then one more question on Boston. While it's still going strong year-to-date, there was a bit of a deceleration in 3Q, which was somewhat surprising given kind of the exposure, the suburban exposure there, and most of the supply being
componenttext: That's helpful. And then one more question on Boston. While it's still going strong year-to-date, there was a bit of a deceleration in 3Q, which was somewhat surprising given kind of the exposure, the suburban exposure there, and most of the supply being urban. Is there anything going on there? Or is that just kind of a little hiccup in what should be a pretty stable market going forward?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- this is Jerry. It's predominantly a hiccup. We did -- we saw a bit of a backup in occupancy throughout that portfolio. And there are 4 assets in our same-store pool, 2 are up in the -- they're B assets in the north end, those continue to d
componenttext: I think it's -- this is Jerry. It's predominantly a hiccup. We did -- we saw a bit of a backup in occupancy throughout that portfolio. And there are 4 assets in our same-store pool, 2 are up in the -- they're B assets in the north end, those continue to do well. Our downtown Back Bay property, probably had revenue growth in 2.5% range, so it definitely is starting to feel more of the competition from urban supply. And then we also have one of our same-store assets that's down in the South End in Braintree, and it's been competing against new supply that's been popping up in Quincy. So the north end, continuing to hold up well. Downtown felt some supply pressures as did the South End, but I think they'll continue to do pretty well.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of your competitors today recently increased expense guidance. You've been able to maintain expense growth at a moderate level, but I was wondering if there are any components to expenses that you're feeling more upward pressure?
componenttext: One of your competitors today recently increased expense guidance. You've been able to maintain expense growth at a moderate level, but I was wondering if there are any components to expenses that you're feeling more upward pressure?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Real estate taxes for sure have been giving us pressure for really the last year or so. You've got -- the Sun Belt assets have typically been seeing real estate taxes go up high-single digits. That's really a function of the NOI growth that's taken t
componenttext:
Yes. Real estate taxes for sure have been giving us pressure for really the last year or so. You've got -- the Sun Belt assets have typically been seeing real estate taxes go up high-single digits. That's really a function of the NOI growth that's taken the valuations up. Similarly, Seattle has felt that kind of pressure. And then because of our 421 abatement burn-offs, we're going to feel it there, too. We're always watching personnel costs, and there is a lot of demand for the quality people that we hire, especially in high new supply areas. Fortunately for the quarter and year-to-date, we've kept that growth at 1.1%, and we did it really because we've realize quited a few efficiencies over the last year or 2 at our site staff that allowed us this year to reduce staffing levels by 1.5% or so, and that's through things like our inside sales group, who assist in renewals and leasing. And secondly, we've deployed about 70 package lockers out into the field that take the burden of package handling off of our site people, so that they can spend more time on sales and service. And we've been able to turn that into some headcount savings.
But I'd say the biggest expense pressure continues to be real estate taxes as our valuations for real estate continue to go up.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And at the same time, you've kept turnover relatively stable versus last year despite new supply really picking up. Can you just elaborate on what you've done strategically to address the markets where you're seeing a lot of supply pressure?
componenttext: Okay. And at the same time, you've kept turnover relatively stable versus last year despite new supply really picking up. Can you just elaborate on what you've done strategically to address the markets where you're seeing a lot of supply pressure?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we probably -- 2 things: One is earlier this year, based on the success we'd had, again, with this inside sales team that helped us won new leases, we created a department of a few people that really assist our people on renewals. So they call
componenttext: Yes. Well, we probably -- 2 things: One is earlier this year, based on the success we'd had, again, with this inside sales team that helped us won new leases, we created a department of a few people that really assist our people on renewals. So they call everybody that hasn't made a decision to renew or give notice yet, if our renewal offer has been out there for a while, and trying to answer any questions to prompt them to renew more quickly. We ask them as a secondary source to go out to people that have given notice to try to convince them to stay. And sometimes this may result in slight negotiation on renewal rates. I think those are the biggest things. I think we've obviously seen the renewal increases come from-- last year, they were north of 7%. Right now, they're in the mid-5. So there's not quite as much pressure. But I think we've got a focus on service and focus on sales. And I think doing things like, again, putting these package lockers and that -- we don't look at it as just a savings to our site's times. We see it as an amenity that people can self-serve 24/7. We're always looking for opportunities to provide our residents with more of what they're looking for.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I may have missed this, but what were the new and renewal leases trending so far this month?
componenttext: I may have missed this, but what were the new and renewal leases trending so far this month?

componenttext: The month of October, new is at 1.1% and renewals so far in October are at 5.3%.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And our next question is from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, just following along that -- John's questions. It sounds like your -- you guys have been pretty proactive on the portfolio this year as well as budgeting guidance that you're able to maintain while peers have revised down. So as you look at your gu
componenttext: Jerry, just following along that -- John's questions. It sounds like your -- you guys have been pretty proactive on the portfolio this year as well as budgeting guidance that you're able to maintain while peers have revised down. So as you look at your guidance for next year, back in June when we met, you guys expressed confidence that you would still be on track for your 2017. But earlier in this call, you guys said that you'll address 2017 later. So just looking at your multiyear plan, where you guys are now, it would seem you're still on track to hit 2017, is that fair? Or there's some things that are coming up that you think could cause you guys to deviate from that?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex. As I indicated in my prepared remarks, without providing 2017 guidance, we do expect same-store growth to continue to decelerate in 2017 on a year-over-year basis, and we're currently projecting, as I said earlier, the earn-in of about 2% compa
componenttext: Yes, Alex. As I indicated in my prepared remarks, without providing 2017 guidance, we do expect same-store growth to continue to decelerate in 2017 on a year-over-year basis, and we're currently projecting, as I said earlier, the earn-in of about 2% compared to 2.75 that was baked in at the beginning of '16. As a result, we see it unlikely that we'll be able to achieve the lower end of the 4.75 to 5.25 2017 same-store revenue growth range that we originally provided in our 2016, 2017 2-year plan that was published earlier this year. At that time, we -- the operating environment at some of our higher-rent coastal markets was much more accommodating when we originally provided the range. And that next year's top line growth is still expected to compare favorably against our long-term revenue growth of about 3%. That being said, we're going to give more detailed 2017 guidance and our update to the 2-year strategic plan on our fourth quarter call.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But is it fair to say -- because back in June, you guys expressed confidence to still meet. Is it that your range this year was wide enough to accommodate? Or did the market further decelerate post June NAREIT that's caused you to revise, think that
componenttext: Okay. But is it fair to say -- because back in June, you guys expressed confidence to still meet. Is it that your range this year was wide enough to accommodate? Or did the market further decelerate post June NAREIT that's caused you to revise, think that you won't even -- that the bottom end will be lower?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there has continued to be slowing, especially in New York and San Francisco throughout the summer months that have made it more clear to us that, again, that 4.75 is probably not in the cards.
componenttext: I think there has continued to be slowing, especially in New York and San Francisco throughout the summer months that have made it more clear to us that, again, that 4.75 is probably not in the cards.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then this is a question maybe -- I don't know if it's Toomey or Warren who wants to take it. But on the MetLife JV, the simplification that's going on, is any of that related to MetLife's overall business model where they're breaking down parts
componenttext: Okay. And then this is a question maybe -- I don't know if it's Toomey or Warren who wants to take it. But on the MetLife JV, the simplification that's going on, is any of that related to MetLife's overall business model where they're breaking down parts of their businesses and you expect more of the MetLife JV to unwind? Or were these totally independent of what Met is doing corporately, and therefore, we should still see you guys maintaining the relationship with Met?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Toomey. With respect to Met, and you've seen it every year that we've been in this relationship for the last 6, we've always had some degree of some trade going on during -- throughout the life of this joint venture, and I would probably see
componenttext: Alex, this is Toomey. With respect to Met, and you've seen it every year that we've been in this relationship for the last 6, we've always had some degree of some trade going on during -- throughout the life of this joint venture, and I would probably see us continuing that same pattern the future. We see no impact from what's going on at Met at corporate to real estate appetite, views of the world or their capital availability or deployment of capital. So I think we'll just continue to have these dialogues that we do with a great partner at future opportunities that help us advance UDR and help them advance their capital deployment. So I don't see any change to that. I think it was just one of those years where we decided to sell an asset, buy 2, shrink land inventory. And I'd like the side of the trade that we ended up on.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And does this take care -- your 5% stakes that you had with Met, does this take care of them all? Or are there still more of those?
componenttext: Okay. And does this take care -- your 5% stakes that you had with Met, does this take care of them all? Or are there still more of those?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So basically down to land inventory with them is [indiscernible].
componenttext: Yes. So basically down to land inventory with them is [indiscernible].

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: We'll go next to Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jerry, it doesn't sound like you're kind of dangerously close to going negative in any market either next year or the year after. I'm not looking for guidance, but clearly residential did suggest that New York is probably going to go negative for them
componenttext: So Jerry, it doesn't sound like you're kind of dangerously close to going negative in any market either next year or the year after. I'm not looking for guidance, but clearly residential did suggest that New York is probably going to go negative for them next year. Just to get it on the record, if you can, do you feel like anything is going that south in the next couple of years? Or do you still think you'll stay above the Mendoza line or whatever?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't see that at this point. There's differences in our portfolio mix, specially in New York, with some of our peers. Again, remember, we're more of a B operator there. We don't have anything in places like Brooklyn, we don't have any specific --
componenttext: Yes. I don't see that at this point. There's differences in our portfolio mix, specially in New York, with some of our peers. Again, remember, we're more of a B operator there. We don't have anything in places like Brooklyn, we don't have any specific -- any properties that are directly in Midtown West. So while we're affected and it will hamper our ability to really push rates, I don't see us going negative anywhere.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Tom, you mentioned 6% to 10% cash flow per share growth kind of strategy. Obviously, that's not really a trend number or at trend or kind of average number over the course of many, many years. What do you think -- while you're not going to
componenttext: Okay. And then Tom, you mentioned 6% to 10% cash flow per share growth kind of strategy. Obviously, that's not really a trend number or at trend or kind of average number over the course of many, many years. What do you think -- while you're not going to give the outlook for '17, but what do you think sort of the average number would be? 6% to 10% is a premium growth rate. Do you think that the number for bottom line AFFO growth is significantly below that? Or what's your view using your history as a guide?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a long history, Rich, and a darn good question. For the last 3 years, make it 4, we had 3 years of 10%, we had this year looks like an 8%, and as we're looking out towards the future, I think in a stable supply-demand demographics that we're in
componenttext: Well, it's a long history, Rich, and a darn good question. For the last 3 years, make it 4, we had 3 years of 10%, we had this year looks like an 8%, and as we're looking out towards the future, I think in a stable supply-demand demographics that we're in a phase, it's probably in the 6% to 8% kind of range. What it would take to get below that 6%, I think, is a recession and the depth and the nature of that. I'm not calling for one, but I think that has been my historical pattern, is when the country goes into recession, it's where is our exposure to it. How deep of a portfolio do we have in those particular areas or industry exposure. It's hard to forecast that element in it -- of it. But what we're trying to do is build a company that can stay in that 6% to 10% through most cycles, and I think we've done that. And I think we're going continue in the future, and when you look at the next strategic plan, you're going to see a lot of the same strategies that we've been executing on in the last 4 years, very focused on capital deployment, operations and continued balance sheet improvement.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I hope Chris doesn't get mad at me because he's way bigger. I want one more question. The self-funding strategy hinges a lot on dispositions, decelerating fundamentals. Do you see any risk that people or buying public of multifamily real estate migh
componenttext: Okay. I hope Chris doesn't get mad at me because he's way bigger. I want one more question. The self-funding strategy hinges a lot on dispositions, decelerating fundamentals. Do you see any risk that people or buying public of multifamily real estate might make it more difficult for that self-funding strategy to stay intact over the next couple of years?

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Harry. I think the short answer is no. What I can tell you is that there continues to be plenty of liquidity in the market that there's still cheap debt available. There's plenty of buyers, although buyer pools are somewhat shallower. What y
componenttext: Rich, this is Harry. I think the short answer is no. What I can tell you is that there continues to be plenty of liquidity in the market that there's still cheap debt available. There's plenty of buyers, although buyer pools are somewhat shallower. What you could see is that the buyers continue to underwrite lower growth rates that cap rates could increase a bit. Remember, you still have solid fundamentals in most of the markets so that even if cap rates increase a little bit, NOI should continue to increase, so there's no obvious impact to absolute value. But the big point is that it's a very liquid market. If you look at 2016 transaction volume, it's still going to be very robust. It will be slightly lower than the 2015 kind of record levels but should be similar to '13 and '14, and there's no evidence that that's going to abate anytime soon.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, I'd follow-on a little bit by saying even in the depths of '09 and '10, transactions were getting done. You may not have liked the price, but there was still liquidity, and Fannie and Freddie were still doing business. So I think there's going to be
componenttext: Rich, I'd follow-on a little bit by saying even in the depths of '09 and '10, transactions were getting done. You may not have liked the price, but there was still liquidity, and Fannie and Freddie were still doing business. So I think there's going to be always a supply of capital. I think we've got a diversified portfolio that we can always look at and say there is a liquidity opportunity there. And so I don't see much risk from us at the sales level that we're anticipating being able to execute.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the risk of concentrated supply and you also highlighted Bellevue as having a bit of a supply increase. Do you think that job growth is sufficient to absorb the supply and are the developers being more rational? We saw in L.A. where demand w
componenttext: You mentioned the risk of concentrated supply and you also highlighted Bellevue as having a bit of a supply increase. Do you think that job growth is sufficient to absorb the supply and are the developers being more rational? We saw in L.A. where demand was pretty solid, yet the pressure on your existing properties existed. So I'm wondering how you see those 2 markets being different.

headline: UDR, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess there's -- we don't see irrational concession levels in Bellevue at this point that they've actually been offering a month free on lease-ups, if not something less. Our portfolio in Bellevue has been able to maintain to date as the supply has
componenttext: Yes. I guess there's -- we don't see irrational concession levels in Bellevue at this point that they've actually been offering a month free on lease-ups, if not something less. Our portfolio in Bellevue has been able to maintain to date as the supply has been delivering north of 6% revenue growth and getting very good renewal as well as new lease rate growth. And yes, I think the job growth, when you look at Amazon coming in next year, if you look at Apple that's looking to come, you consider that Bellevue is pretty close to Redmond. So it doesn't just have to be job growth in Bellevue. It's a lot of those places on the east side that benefit. I think Bellevue is a bit different, and I do think job growth will continue in that, that core of Bellevue will eventually run out of developable space. The other thing to keep in mind, and this is a little more long term, but in about 5 or 6 years, the light rail is going to reach across Lake Washington and really connect both Bellevue as well as Redmond to the west side of town, and I think it will enhance the east side even more.

But I don't foresee it at this point anywhere else.
